PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions and Fringe Benefits Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth;

That we are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities, and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision be made to protect savings against inflation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ZAKHAROV

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate a petitioning letter, bearing 19 signatures, requesting that Colombia's human rights record be placed on the agendas of the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations and other major intergovernmental and bilateral government meetings:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned, are members of the Sandringham Chapter of Amnesty International, Group No. 318. We are currently involved in a world wide Colombia Campaign to raise public awareness of the situation in Colombia and to exert political pressure for change. Colombian human rights groups have estimated that around 200 people `disappeared' in 1985 after being seized by security forces and that 1000 remain unaccounted for by November 1987. Over 140 `death squads' have been publicly recognized by the authorities but not one person has been convicted for a political killing.

The long-term aim of this campaign is to stop any further disappearances and political killings and to ensure that all those responsible for the human rights violations are fairly tried by civilian criminal courts. We have the names of 32 people who are currently threatened with death because of their political beliefs. By our actions we intend to save their lives.

We urge the Australian Government to press for Colombia's record to be placed on the agendas of the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations and major intergovernmental meetings, such as those of the Organization of American States, as well as bilateral government meetings. We request you to present this matter to Mr Bill Hayden and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We further request a reply to this letter, stating your views, together with copies of the letter from yourself to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and their reply. Should you desire, we would be most pleased to provide further information or have a representative of Amnesty call on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Trade Practices (Telecommunications Exemptions) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1988 No. 99 and made under the Trade Practices Act 1974, be disallowed.

Notice of this motion was originally given by my colleague Senator Messner but it has now been taken over by me. What has happened here is that the Government is moving by way of a regulation and not by way of a Bill, which means that the Parliament is deprived of its right to amend the proposal currently before us. We have, by way of the Standing Orders, the right to disallow these regulations but we have no right to propose amendments. It may very well be that had the Government had the courage to bring in this matter in a Bill-and after all it gave notice of these Trade Practices (Telecommunications Exemptions) Regulations on 25 May, some months ago-we might have been able to accept some parts of it. But the Parliament is now faced with the position of either disallowing these regulations as a whole or allowing them to go through.

I also point out that this arrogant and out of touch Government has introduced this measure without any consultation with industry, as it did in relation to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill, yet to be debated in the Senate. This once again demonstrates how out of touch with the people this Government is and continues to be as it administers this country on the basis that it is the sole fount of all wisdom.

On 25 May this year the Treasurer, Mr Keating, put down a major economic statement in which he said a number of things with which the coalition parties totally agree. On page 3018 of the House of Representatives Hansard for 25 May, the Treasurer said:
. . . economic reforms must extend to every business and workplace in the economy.
The way forward for Australia is not to be closeted and sheltered, but to be open and dynamic, trading aggressively in the world.
Only this kind of economy can provide the employment and rising living standards that Australians aspire to.
We totally agree with those words, and we wish this Government would fulfil its rhetoric. The Treasurer went on to claim:
This is the very point of the measures contained in this economic statement.
As we have indicated from time to time, we have doubts as to whether those measures go far enough. The Treasurer went on to say:
Accordingly, the Government will peel away more of this protection.
He then outlined certain reductions in protection for the private sector. We do not disagree with those proposed reductions. He turned to the public sector, and he said:
More competitive pressure will also be applied to the operations of Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission to provide better and cheaper services to business and consumers.

Having said that, he went on to introduce these regulations-the Trade Practices (Telecommunications Exemptions) Regulations-which, in fact, do the very opposite of what he had said earlier. The Treasurer said that the Government would apply more competitive pressure, but these regulations confirm and extend the monopoly position of Telecom Australia.

On the day that the Government introduced these regulations exempting Telecom from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act, which prohibits certain anti-competitive practices and restrictive trade practices, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, said this:
Transport and communications infrastructure forms the very fabric of our economy.
How right he was. He continued:

Without it, the industry could not function, our exports could not reach their markets and we would be limited in our participation in global financial markets and the growing service industries such as tourism.

It is clear, accordingly, that every improvement we can make in the way we deliver transport and communications services is vital as this flows through to improvements throughout our economy and assists in improving our international competitiveness.

Let me make it clear that the coalition parties support those two paragraphs of Senator Evans's statement on these matters. Why then, one asks, has the Government introduced these regulations, which do the very opposite of what Mr Keating and Senator Evans said? The Opposition fully supports these sentiments, but let me make it clear that when we get the opportunity we will act and take the hard decisions which this Government is not yet prepared to take. It may well be that the Cabinet wanted to take the hard decisions here, but of course this Government is locked in by its Caucus committees and that may be the reason why it was unable to implement the words that were uttered by Senator Evans and Mr Keating.

The Opposition is committed to increase the degree of competition faced by Telecom Australia and that is why Senator Messner gave notice of disallowance. On the day that Senator Messner announced he would move the notice of disallowance, he issued a press release which said:
The Government's regulations will severely restrict the pace of structural change that is urgently needed in Australia's telecommunications industry.
He went on to say that it was disgraceful for the Government to sneak these regulations through without any consultation with industry or the public. His press release went on:

The Opposition will not support these regulations as they reduce competition in the telecommunications industry. It is imperative for the development of a fair and competitive telecommunications system that Telecom not be exempted from the operations of the Trade Practices Act.

The Trades Practices Act would provide the competition that is necessary. These regulations exempt Telecom from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. I go to the major statement by Senator Evans entitled `Australian Telecommunications Services: A New Framework' which he tabled on 25 May 1988 and in which he referred, for example, to the question of cellular mobile telephone services. He pointed out that it was necessary to face the question of the need for cellular mobile telephone services to remain as a Telecom monopoly. He said:
Experience overseas has pointed to possible benefits for that service from competition, including increasing customer responsiveness and faster tech- nological innovation.
I agree with what Senator Evans said. He went on to say in paragraph 3.68 of this very large statement:

Extension of competition to the provision of mobile telephone services themselves would not appear likely to affect Telecom's capacity to fund its community service obligations by cross-subsidies: the services would, in fact, provide additional trunk and local traffic on the Telecom network through interconnection between the mobile services and the basic network infrastructure.

Again I thoroughly agree with what Senator Evans said. I ask him: Why, having said that about the cellular mobile telephone service, did he introduce this regulation on the very same day, which prevents competition, and maintains the Telecom monopoly over this service? Senator Evans went on to say later, in paragraphs 3.71 and 3.72:
. . . the Government considers that there is too much uncertainty to make a decision now to introduce competition . . .
What an incredible statement! He was saying how great it would be for this nation to introduce competition, yet he also said:
. . . the Government considers that there is too much uncertainty to make a decision now to introduce competition.
He told us that the Government had decided that further examination of the issue would be required and he said:
The Government had decided that: On its establishment the new independent regulatory authority-
which is now known as Austel-
will be required to report on the implications of licensing an additional operator of cellular mobile telephone services with rights of interconnection to Telecom's public switched telephone network.
The Government will, after receiving that report, review the case for licensing such an additional operator.

Austel will not come into existence until 1 July next year. It will then conduct an inquiry and, when the Government gets that report, it will start to talk about introducing some competition in this area. We keep saying that this Government is full of rhetoric; it is always telling us how good it is and what it is going to do. It keeps raising the issues but the truth of the matter is that it will not allow this country to get firing in the way it desperately needs to get firing. Senator Button comes in here day after day and talks about the need for manufacturers to go out and do things. But there is a fundamental need for this Government to fix up the infrastructure of this community first in order to give Australian manufacturers, entrepreneurs and people who have the ability an opportunity to go out and do things in this community. Until such time as this Government faces up to the need to do things instead of talking about doing things, this country will not get out of the quagmire that it is currently in, losing money, as it does, at the rate of $1.4m per hour. Every hour of the day, 365 days of the year, this country goes down the drain at the rate of $1.4m. That is, our money we are spending overseas exceeds the money that we are earning by $1.4m an hour. This Government keeps going down at the rate of $10 billion to $11 billion a year. We will not overcome that situation until the Government introduces and implements some of the rhetoric that people like the Treasurer talk about and Senator Evans when he was the Minister for Transport and Communications used to talk about.

I might add that, having brought down the statement in May of this year when Mr Keating talked about all of these things, the very next day he had an interview with Mr Geoff Kitney in which he said, `The Government has done all the hard work. Now we have to look at another area', and he raised another area where there is desperate need for reform-that is, the labour market. He said, and rightly so, that there is a massive need to reform the Australian labour market. We again agree with that. But what the Treasurer was saying to Geoff Kitney was that all the hard work in the other areas has been done. This Government seems to think that if it talks about a matter and talks about what needs to be done, it is as if it has been done.

This regulation that I am asking the Senate to disallow today is a perfect example of that not being true. This regulation in fact continues the restrictions on competition. It does the very opposite of what Mr Keating and Senator Evans were talking about. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has gone on record that the most fundamental reform is yet to come-as if they have reformed things. They have not reformed anything. They have talked about reforming things. They have added a few peripherals and they have changed some of the government business enterprises from a statutory authority to a company. They have changed the external appearances, but the fundamental reforms have not been done.

Let me talk about the future of Telecom. What this Government has done under this regulation is to restrict any competition forever in relation to certain areas. The restriction is not just for some period of time. In relation to Telecom being the sole provider of telephone services, the Government has ensured that the monopoly will continue until 30 June 1991. So that monopoly will be carried on until then. In relation to the provision of PABX maintenance and service agreements, that monopoly will be continued until the end of this year. Why? If the Government is prepared to allow competition with that monopoly to start on 31 December this year, why did it not allow the competition to commence from 25 May? What on earth is gained by deferring that competition for those seven months?

Let me go on and say that in regard to the shared use and resale of carriage of traffic over private networks, that monopoly is continued forever and similarly with regard to basic switched voice communication services, public switched data services, public switched integrated digital network services, leased circuit services and public mobile telephone services. Those monopolies under this regulation continue forever. There is no date for the commencement of that competition that Mr Keating and Senator Gareth Evans were talking about.

We say to the Government that quite frankly it is just misleading the people when it talks about introducing basic and fundamental reforms. The truth of the matter is that it is not introducing any basic and fundamental reforms. It is talking about that and about the sorts of things that have to be done. The Government subsequently carries on as if it has already done those things. When we are faced with the legislation we know the situation as it actually exists and we know that the reforms have not been carried out. Let me refer to what my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) in the other place said on 1 November, just a few days ago, in relation to these matters. On page 2141 of the House of Representatives Hansard he said:

The whole area of transport and communications, including aviation, is an example of piecemeal, ad hoc policy, driven by partisan considerations and what the factions will allow the Government to do from time to time, depending upon which way the wind is blowing and how they think the opinion polls are standing up. It is not in the best interests of this country, it is not in the best interest of the taxpayers-the people who use the network-and it is certainly operating to the detriment of our standard of living.

He was talking about the government business enterprise legislation which will come into this chamber in due course and which I will have an opportunity to talk more about. All that legislation does is talk about the changes at the periphery. Even in the Minister's second reading speech in relation to that matter he acknowledges that the major reforms are yet to come. I see Senator Robert Ray looking at me as if to say that that is not so. That is so. The Minister says it in his second reading speech. He said that the major changes were yet to come and we look forward to them. Why is the Government not bringing them in now? Why did the Government not bring them in on 25 May when it introduced some of these other changes? All the Government did was talk about the major reforms that need to be conducted within the economy.

There is no doubt that the problem with the Australian Labor Party is that the factions are interfering with the rhetoric and the polls are probably interfering with the factions. The truth is that, instead of getting on with meaningful reform, this Government is trying to con Australians with rhetoric which obscures the real reasons for these unnecessary regulations. These regulations are not about freeing up the economy and providing more competition for government business enterprises. They are, on the contrary, doing the very opposite of that. On 12 August Senator Evans said of Austel:

Austel, which will come into being on 1 July 1989, will be responsible for technical regulation of the industry, for protecting consumers against misuse of the carriers' monopoly powers, for protecting the carriers' remaining monopolies, for protecting competitors from unfair carrier practices and for promoting efficiency.

But in the provisions in the regulations which my motion will disallow, if the Senate will carry it, the Government is saying to Telecom Australia that it is all right to infringe the rights of consumers and potential competitors. It is giving Telecom free reign until some time in 1990 or thereabouts when Austel will report. The provisions of the Trade Practices Act-if the Government would only allow them to operate-already protect consumers and competitors from anti-competitive actions by Telecom Australia. But the Government wants to remove that protection with these regulations and, accordingly, they should be disallowed.

These regulations also exemplify another failing of this Government. It cannot get its legislation or regulations right and is continually having to amend its own Bills at the committee stage. We had examples of this in the recent Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill and there were many amendments to the national companies legislation package. Honourable senators will recall that the Government had to amend a referendum question because it found it had got it all wrong. I might add that on 3 September we discovered that it had got all the questions wrong. The regulations we are moving to disallow today are also wrong. The Government admitted as much when on 26 August this year it gazetted more regulations to amend these regulations which I am moving to disallow.

It is possible that the legality of these regulations will be tested in the courts as they may be inconsistent with the general intent and specific provisions of the Trade Practices Act. All seven of the regulations which are amended cover the conduct of Telecom that is exempted from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. One of the amendments changes a date by two years and the Government says it is due to a drafting error. The reason for the drafting error, of course, is that Cabinet wanted the first phone monopoly to end on 30 June 1989 but the Caucus committee apparently overrode it and gave another two years of protection to Telecom. That is two years at this stage. By that time we will be in government and that will be terminated.

Most of the amendments were claimed to address unintended effects of some of the provisions. The Government should get it right when it brings in these Bills and regulations. The amendments to the regulations do not overcome the fundamental problems revealed by the Opposition and we remain totally opposed to the misuse of regulatory powers. The coalition is committed to increasing the degree of competition faced by Telecom. These regulations have the opposite effect, and I call upon the Senate to disallow them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much struck by the analogy of Liberal Party members being the bogong moths of politics. Here they are, blown off direction, attracted to the first light they come upon, and then hanging around uselessly, just waiting to drop off on these particular issues. I want to respond to three points made by Senator Lewis. What we are considering here is not a blanket exemption for Telecom Australia from the Trade Practices Act. Some of the regulations do have sunset clauses. They will allow phasing in of competition in those areas. Other regulations will provide protection for Telecom only until the new Telecommunications Act is in force. Senator Lewis made a great play of consultation. However, I point out that there were eight months of intensive consultation throughout the policy review process prior to the Government's policy being announced on 25 May. The regulations simply implement the policy reached after extensive consultation with all parties in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis criticises this Government for indecisiveness. He would have us negotiate, consult, make a decision, and then go into another round of consultation. What rubbish. The open-ended regulations protect the basic reserve services which the Government has decided should be reserved to government carriers. The services referred to constitute the national public telecommunications network. If these basic network services are not protected, it will be impossible for Telecom to provide the cross-subsidies which fund universal telephone services to all Australians at reasonable uniform prices. The cross-subsidies enable all rural consumers access to the telephone service at reasonable prices.

Senator Lewis referred to the fact that the parliamentary Labor Party Caucus committee has had an input into this system. Of course it has. We on this side of the chamber are not ashamed about having elected parliamentarians determine policy. It is not like the system used by the Opposition. It set up an extensive party committee inquiry into immigration. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) then ignored that committee and announced a new policy without reference to it. We do not act in that way. We are a democratic party. Caucus committees have the right to have an input into government. That never happens under the Liberal Party system in which the leader is all powerful. He determines all positions, which means that members of the Opposition toady to that leader or try to replace him, whichever they think is the most operative course for their own career patterns. The sort of toadying, obsequious attitude that we often see on the part of those opposite, is a creature of that system. If Opposition members want to improve their performance, maybe they should implement the Caucus committee system which does have a genuine input into and can change policy. Cabinet is not all knowing or perfect. Why should it not seek the guidance of those Caucus committees?

I turn to the more factual part of our approach on this matter. Let us look at the background. The purpose of the regulations is no more than to give effect to the Government's decision that Telecom Australia should continue to exercise a monopoly in those services identified by the Government as being reserved to Telecom. Essentially, the regulations support Telecom's position as the provider of basic telecommunications services and allow a transition period for the introduction of competition in the consumer premises market, pending deregulation. It should be stressed that the Government has reaffirmed its commitment to universal access to standard telephone services throughout Australia on an equitable basis and at affordable prices, in recognition of the social importance of those services.

It is widely known in the community that Telecom's basic network monopoly has enabled internal cross-subsidies that have supported universal access to standard telephone services at uniform and affordable prices. This has been particularly important to people living in Australia's rural and remote areas. It is quite clear that the Opposition is undecided about supporting universal service and Telecom's ability to cross-subsidise. For instance, Senator Alston, the chairman of the Opposition's privatisation task force, this week called for the privatisation of both Telecom and Australia Post. He also urged reconsideration of Telecom's cross-subsidy arrangements. Senator Alston stated:
There are no valid public policy reasons why Australia Post and Telecom should be protected from competition and indeed compelling economic efficiency arguments to the contrary.

It would seem to me that Senator Alston believes in the user pays approach to telecommunications, particularly for those people in rural areas. We will no doubt hear from him in a moment. This will come as unhappy news to some rural constituents of his National Party colleagues. Still, one quick course at Monash University really does make a person dry. I am not saying that that course was entirely wasted because I am sure it has improved his knowledge in these areas. Dare I also say that had he gone to a different university we may have heard a different view; I am not sure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I went to Melbourne as well.

—Right, he has it all covered. An immediate effect of disallowing the regulations would be to eliminate the regulatory protection of Telecom's monopolies in specified services where opening them to competition would impose excessive adjustment burdens on the carrier and, just as importantly, the customers. These services are: public switched data; public switched text and video; public switched integrated service digital networks leased circuits; and mobile telephones.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations also authorise the prohibition of resale or sharing of telecommunication capacity. This is in line with existing practice. The regulations with respect to the above services are intended as a transitional mechanism to protect Telecom's reserved services during the period between the Government's telecommunications policy statement of May 1988 and the passage of the new telecommunications regulation legislation in the autumn session of Parliament in 1989-one might also say the winter session. The new legislation will clearly establish the legal status of Telecom's reserved services monopolies, including the application of the Trade Practices Act.

Likewise, the regulations which exempt certain activities with regard to customer premises equipment are also transitional measures. They allow Telecom to retain certain monopolies with the important proviso that they are subject to sunset clauses. Thus Telecom's monopolies over PABX maintenance and standard telephone handsets will last until 31 December of this year. Its monopoly over the supply of small business systems will end on 30 June 1989. Finally, Telecom's first telephone monopoly will lapse after 30 June 1991 unless--

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless the Caucus liaison committee overturns it.
—The honourable senator will get his turn. I was just about to add: unless continuing exemption is specified after a review which must be held by 31 December 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: These regulations pertaining to customer premises equipment are not arbitrary. They have been specifically designed to allow an adequate transition period for Australian industry pending deregulation of these markets. There is no substance to any of the charges that the regulations will permit Telecom to abuse its monopoly power. Until the establishment of Austel, Telecom is to perform regulatory functions under a Ministerial direction issued on 18 July 1988, which will ensure that Telecom administers its regulations on a fair and non-discriminatory basis and that it does not position itself to unfair advantage in the market. In summary, the regulations are intended as a transitional measure to give full clarification to Telecom's position in the market and to ensure that there are no conflicts between the trade practices legislation and the Government's policies for a new regulatory environment in telecommunications.

The only other matter I wish to address in responding to the Opposition's disallowance motion is those again oft repeated remarks I have heard in this chamber from Senator Lewis. He says that this Government talks a good game about deregulation but does nothing about it. In a whole range of areas this Government has seen benefit in deregulation. In other areas, it has seen benefit in being interventionist. But the one clear point for anyone with any knowledge of any Australian history and Australian political history is that the great regulationists in this country sit opposite me.

In the Fraser years from 1975 to 1983, the then Government members were regulation mad. What industries did they seek to deregulate? They initiated a couple of surveys like the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the Bradley Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission, as my colleague Senator Maguire reminds me, and then jibbed at any decision making whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Davidson inquiry.

—The Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia (1982)-Senator Maguire is feeding me my lines perfectly-is another inquiry to note. All these reports recommended deregulation. What did those opposite do in 7 1/2 years? The answer is: absolutely nothing. The new Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Stone) was a great regulationist. He was always opposed to deregulation, even the floating of our currency on the international markets. He opposed regulation. There used to be an old saying, `How do you define a Trotskyist?' The answer is, `Simply a Stalinist out of power'. It continued by asking, `How do you define a Liberal?'. The answer is, `Simply a regulationist out of power'. The Opposition has a record of being more interventionist and more protective than any other group. In the end, there is no such thing as a philosophical position really that should support total regulation or total interventionism. It should be applied to the industry and in the circumstances that are necessary at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: In some industries and in some cases, interventionism happens to be the best way for the public good. In other areas, deregulation happens to be in the interests, to the benefit and for the welfare of the public of Australia. In the telecommunications area, it is very difficult to know where to draw the line. There is a need always for some competition; there is a need for some deregulation: but, in many cases, some of those regulations and some of those monopoly positions can clearly and demonstrably be in favour of the public at large. The absolute assumption that monopoly is per se bad and that oligopoly or whatever follows it is necessarily good is a false assumption. Given such concepts as barriers to entry, quite often a monopoly will give one a cheaper service than an oligopoly. Anyway, I might ask Senator Alston to reflect on that point at this stage. I urge all honourable senators who have not made up their minds-I confess I cannot see any-to support the Government on this position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to intervene between the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) and Senator Alston's no doubt learned dissertation to come, I rise to say that the Australian Democrats made up their minds on this matter some time ago and we shall not be supporting the disallowance motion before the Senate today. The regulations, which the Opposition is asking the Senate to disallow, allow, as the Minister has said, certain prescribed conduct by Telecom Australia to be exempt from sections 46 and 47 of the Trade Practices Act. These exemptions dealing with Telecom's area of monopoly are in most cases for a limited time, as part of a phasing-in process in the Government's policy of introduction of increased competition in this area, and sunset clauses apply in those cases.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats believe that these exemptions are absolutely critical in ensuring Telecom's ability to generate sufficient revenue in order to cross-subsidise its less profitable community service obligations. We can argue about what those obligations should include, or about how much cross subsidisation is being done. Is it $200m worth, $600m worth, or more? Those questions are open questions. Answers to them will become clearer in the next 12 months or so as inquiries are undertaken. But what is important is that in that period the regulations should remain in operation. That is why the Democrats will not support the disallowance at present.

Throughout the continuing debate on telecommunications, the Democrats will be repeatedly putting the case for consumers and the need to protect Telecom's universal service obligations. Whilst it is important that government enterprises, public service enterprises, are as efficient as they can be, and whilst aspects of the Government's approach are supported by the Democrats, it is very important that we maintain a strong view of what is best for consumers, and certainly a strong stance on the universal service obligation in this area.

I have noted in some of the voluminous literature on this issue some comments by, interestingly enough, Tony Staley, the Chairman of the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, on the question of what the Government is doing in its deregulation approach. At a conference in August in Sydney Mr Staley was welcoming the decision to make Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) into companies. To quote him:

. . . the big question is: when budget time comes around will the government live to the rules of the game, or will it behave as governments in the past and rip them off because help is needed with the budget?

We must remember that Mr Staley has been a member of governments of the past. That is an issue which ought to be raised in this debate when we are talking about increasing the efficiency of a major public enterprise such as Telecom, one which has a universal service obligation, which, as I say, the Democrats strongly support and will work to protect in the interests of the community. The question arises, as Mr Staley has put it, of how government will act in that process, and past performance raises a bit of a worry. The Democrats believe that it is not widely recognised, or not recognised enough, not even by the Government. It would have been comforting to have the Government and the Opposition acknowledge in this debate that Telecom contributes to the Australian economy, and when we are questioning its efficiency or lack of efficiency, the issue of the money that Telecom increasingly-some of these imposts are very recent-puts into our economy needs to be acknowledged. I take this opportunity to acknowledge and welcome the question raised by Mr Staley, and certainly it is a matter that needs far more acknowledgment in this debate.

The argument has been put quite strongly to the Australian Democrats, amongst others, I am sure, that the cellular mobile telephone service should be exempted from this set of regulations. Of course that option is not open to us because we have either to allow or disallow the regulations in toto. But be that as it may, I am not convinced that the replacement of a public monopoly in this instance with what I think would probably simply be a private monopoly, or at best an oligopoly, would really be to the benefit of users. I have not been convinced, even in the cellular mobile telephone area, that had the Government been able to be persuaded to make this particular exemption we would be advancing things, at this time at least, much further. Of course this issue will be inquired into, as has already been said in the debate, by Austel and therefore the Democrats believe it is appropriate that there be no exemption prior to the time Austel reports on the issue. I do not believe there is any prejudging of the Austel inquiry, and I do not think there is any undermining of the independence of Austel, the regulatory body which of course at this stage remains not much more than a twinkle in the eye of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). We have not seen anything too concrete as yet. I take this opportunity, too, to express some concern about that. Nevertheless, the proposal for the exemption of the cellular mobile telephone service is not one with which at this time at least we would be happy.

I want to make a couple of comments about community service obligations and their cost and productivity. One of the major elements of the Government's whole reform package is establishing how much community service obligations cost. The Government is committed to controlling the level of national resources going to meet social objectives. This is a fine balance that any government has to strike and, as I have said, the Democrats will consistently put the view of the importance of the community service obligation. The Government is looking towards increasing the productivity of the work force in its enterprises of capital and in management systems. It is attempting to keep down the cost of services, and I think no taxpayer and probably nobody in either chamber of this Parliament would disagree with that goal. Nevertheless, it is important that the proper balance be struck and that the economic rationalists do not strike to the extent that they appear to have done within the Opposition.

One really wonders how serious members of the Opposition are about this disallowance motion and about telecommunications policy in general. I notice that, according to today's press, the privatisation issue within the Opposition has risen from the grave and that indeed it is a matter for some contention within Opposition ranks. The move being made by the Opposition here, or which at least is being pushed by some in the Opposition, is designed to reduce rural subsidies within Telecom, benefiting the business sector at the expense of ordinary phone users-particularly people in rural Australia. I wonder what Senator Lewis, the current occupant of the job once held by his esteemed colleague Ian Macphee, really thinks about this. I do not know whether Senator Ray forgot momentarily, but Senator Lewis himself is a country lad, as of course I am a country girl. I am not surprised at the reported tensions in the Opposition about this matter. After all, one of the reasons Senator Ray sits on the Government side and Senator Alston, Senator Puplick and Senator Lewis sit on the other side is that country people, and country Victorians in particular, again voted for the Australian Labor Party in government. The swinging seats are the seats of Ballarat and Bendigo, as well as some seats in the metropolitan areas.

The Opposition seems to be taking a fairly cavalier attitude, particularly when Senator Alston is pushing privatisation at the moment. We all know where Senator Alston stands and I am not at all surprised that he is creating some tension within his own party. I wonder what the National Party members think about it. I wonder whether we will have a National Party speaker in this debate. It looks as though we will not. The National Party benches do seem rather bare. (Quorum formed) As I was saying before the Opposition chose to draw attention to the state of the House, the disallowing of a series of regulations relating to Telecom I think is one of the sensitive issues within Opposition ranks. I was about to speculate on whether this was one of the reasons why, in the current seating arrangements for this chamber, the National Party has chosen not to leave one seat between its members and us. We often hear in this place the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Stone) berate the odious Democrats for being on the far far left of the Left of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. The seating arrangements in this chamber are worked out amongst the Whips, and the present arrangement results from the Democrats insisting on the way they wanted to sit and being totally uncooperative about having it any other way than the way they wanted it. So it is not for Senator Powell to talk about the way Opposition senators are seated in this chamber.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The question of the sensitivity of the issue before the Senate is perhaps one of those motivating factors behind leaving one seat vacant between the Liberals and the Nationals in this chamber rather than between the Nationals and the Australian Democrats. As the National Party claims to have, the Australian Democrats do have great concern for isolated and underprivileged Australians. Indeed, as we have seen in the last few minutes, this is a matter of great sensitivity. Whatever members of the National Party think about this matter, they can be assured that until within the Opposition they knock the idea of privatisation on the head, I and my Democrat colleagues will continue to travel around the part of the country which they claim is theirs telling country people about their betrayal.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by mentioning some comments by Mel Ward, the Managing Director of Telecom Australia, who takes the view, as do the Australian Democrats, that telecommunications policy must always be transitional because of the rate of change in this field. As I have said, this is an extraordinarily sensitive area in which to have government attempting to introduce profitability and competitiveness, along with the continuing provision of community service. In the case of these regulations we believe that the Government has displayed a sensitivity to the needs of Telecom. In the current context we believe these regulations should and must stand. Indeed, they will stand because the Australian Democrats will not support the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief. I will support the disallowance motion and will do so for one reason and one reason alone. My reason is not related necessarily to the subject matter of the Trade Practices (Telecommunications Exemptions) Regulations. I will support the disallowance motion because the Government has brought in quite a wide range of changes in the form of regulations. It would have been more appropriate had it introduced legislation to effect these changes so that that legislation would then be the subject of scrutiny by the Parliament. Members of parliament would then have the opportunity to consider the clauses of such a Bill at the committee stage. They would be able to amend them if they chose to do so in order to improve the legislation, either by deleting certain clauses or adding thereto.

SPEECH.PARA: This is something to which the Senate itself should have regard when it considers regulations and subordinate legislation such as we have now. The regulations procedure inhibits the function of members of parliament because when a regulation such as this is placed before us we have only two options-either to agree to it or to disallow it. We cannot amend it. We may support some parts of the regulation while we may vigorously oppose other parts. What sort of situation are we placed in when we have only Hobson's choice or none? That is not an appropriate way to deal with major questions. This is a diminution of our functions of audit and control and that is why I propose to support the disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Trade Practices (Telecommunications Exemptions) Regulations because I believe they are matters of considerable public importance. It is regrettable in the first instance that the Minister for Local Government, Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, is not present to hear my remarks because I wished to provide him with some enlightenment. He trotted out a number of fairly moth-eaten comments and assessments which clearly reflected the fact that he had not read my remarks and was at a very early stage of development in terms of the policy debate. I intended to offer him the option of a crash course at the summer school at Monash University, where he might have been able to learn the difference between privatisation and competition. That is really what these regulations are about and what the public debate should be about.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations provide a mechanism for protecting not simply the basic network but also other areas that are not in any way crucial to maintenance of that network. In particular, there is the first phone monopoly which, Senator Ray has said, has a sunset clause attached to it and has to be subject to review within six months of the end of 1989. As we well know, the Caucus liaison committee, headed by my good friend Roger Price, was able to achieve a number of significant backdowns by the task force and I have no confidence at all that logic or economic sensibility will prevail. Indeed, the whole approach of the Government is typified by these regulations because there has not been any desire to have these matters debated in the public arena. The establishment of the task force in the first instance was essentially a private inquiry. The interaction of that committee with the Caucus liaison committee was quite unprecedented and undesirable, resulted in a number of unfortunate compromises, and ultimately led to a secret report again being provided to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) and a statement being tabled reflecting the Government's response.

I will develop that point to its conclusion. The process adopted by the Government in this area is, I believe, very unhealthy because at the crux of the whole question of community service obligations and cross-subsidies is the nature, extent and true cost of Telecom Australia's cross-subsidies. Yet we are no closer at all to getting to the bottom of that conundrum. The Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia in 1982 reflected quite adversely on Telecom's estimates of the extent of cross-subsidy. From memory, I think Telecom estimated it to be in the vicinity of $290m. Since that time we have had ever increasing estimates. In Telecom's annual reports in recent years it has talked about the extent of the cross-subsidy being of the order of $600m. In a press release put out last December, Telecom suggested that it was of the order of $1 billion. In its submission to the task force, I am reliably informed that at one stage Telecom was arguing that a figure closer to $2.5 billion could be arrived at, depending on what measure was adopted.

Nonetheless, ultimately the Minister's statement comes down to this: `Telecom claimed that the extent of its cross-subsidy was $670m; on the other hand, we have an official estimate that it may well be only $250m. In the circumstances we are quite unable to determine the extent of the cross-subsidy and we therefore believe it is a matter requiring further investigation'. Accordingly, that question was referred to the Bureau of Transport and Communications but, once again, for a private inquiry. That is currently under way and has been for some months. If one is familiar with the `capture thesis', it is intriguing to note that Telecom has been `providing assistance' to Telecom during that period but the Bureau has not yet engaged the services of independent consultants in order to test the information being provided by Telecom, let alone take on board some of the international data in this area.

We are looking at yet another private report to the Minister in due course. There is no obligation for it to be released or for the Minister to accept it. No doubt there will be every opportunity for the Caucus liaison committee, Senator Childs and a number of others to kick it to death if it in any way suggests that the extent of the cross-subsidy might be relatively modest. If it is of the order of $250m, as postulated by the task force, then it is eminently achievable without the need to maintain the iron clad grip of monopoly on a whole range of Telecom services-not just the basic network.

It is worth remembering that, until these regulations were proclaimed, Telecom had been staunchly denying that it was even subject to the Trade Practices Act. It was established in the Federal Court of Australia about 18 months ago, in the case of Tytel, that it was. But Telecom never accepted that result and persuaded the Government not to take further action to ensure that its monopoly was protected by law.

In the aftermath of the May statement the Trade Practices Commission recommended that the way in which to proceed was to seek an exemption under the Trade Practices Act. But, of course, that was very quickly rejected by the Government because, again, it would have involved a public inquiry. The Trade Practices Commission could have required all interested parties to present submissions, to canvass the real issues and to decide on the extent of the level of cross- subsidies. But no, the Government chose to ignore that advice and it went down that surreptitious back passage that concerned Senator Harradine to the extent that he is supporting us in our motion of disallowance, and he is absolutely right.

There is no justification at all for presenting the Parliament with an all or nothing choice. Indeed, there are some areas that are much more significant than others. There are some sunset clauses attaching to the regulations, but it is very interesting to note that there is no sunset clause attached to any of those areas provided for in paragraph 4 (f) of the regulations dealing with prescribed conduct. These areas include not just the basic network, which is basic public switched voice telecommunications services, but also public switched data. There is no justification at all for an absolute protection in that area. Again, public switched text has nothing to do with what we ordinarily understand to be the basic network, the basic voice transmission that is encompassed in the rubric of universal service. I concede that public switched integrated services digital networks and leased circuits are an integral part of the monopoly because once we allow leasing and buying of excess capacity we certainly undermine the price monopoly position of Telecom. But the most outrageous area of all-even Senator Powell referred to it-is the public mobile telephone services. It is an open secret that the task force was very much inclined to take that out of the monopoly area but ultimately, of course, Caucus prevailed and it is in there. But it is in there without limit. There is no sunset clause attaching to it.

I suppose in due course the economic inevitability and utter irrationality of maintaining the present position will become apparent and mobile telephone services will be opened up to the public. We can buy the equipment now; there is plenty of competition in that market. But it is the actual service and its interconnection with the network that is absolutely protected. As a result, we are paying about 40 per cent more than we need to pay. When we take account of import duties and purchasing power parity arrangements we can make fairly direct comparisons with the United States position. It has been a growth area of enormous dimensions around the Western world yet, for no good reason, it is thrown in there to protect the monopoly. It is thrown in there because it is an area of easy money for Telecom. Telecom knows that there is a great demand for this service. There is no particular reason why it provides it better than anyone else, but it is free money for Telecom and that is why that is in there. I find that a thoroughly undesirable justification for including it in these regulations. These regulations are not just a response to the Tytel case and other legal advice that the Government has obtained that the basic network needs specific protection; they go well beyond the protection of the basic network.

I was intrigued by Senator Powell's comment that somehow we are pulling the rug out from those in rural and remote areas. I hope she does not pretend that Ballarat and Bendigo come under that category. Undoubtedly, there is a whole range of beneficiaries of cross-subsidies who do not reside in country areas. I think we all know that subscriber trunk dialling between major capital cities provides the vast bulk of the cross-subsidy. That is where the revenue comes from. If we live in urban areas and if we are users of the local network we are beneficiaries. People in rural and remote areas are beneficiaries. There is a range of beneficiaries who are deserving, to a greater or lesser extent, irrespective of their need. Irrespective of whether I need to have my telephone calls subsidised in metropolitan areas, I am a beneficiary. If I wanted to start up a new multi-million dollar tourist resort on the islands off Queensland and I regarded it as purely a commercial venture, the most I would have to pay for a telephone service would be $1,425, even though the actual cost of installation is likely to be in the region of $20,000 or $25,000 and, in some remote areas, in excess of $30,000. A person running a big commercially operated cattle station in the Northern Territory can get a phone connected for that figure.

What has to be exposed as a charade is that we talk constantly about universal service as though it is something that is desperately in need of protection. But we never define what is meant by `universal service'. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) is now talking about universal service on the basic network having been achieved. Indeed, if we make comparisons we find that Australia is better off than most OECD countries. It has nothing to do with the fact that we have fairly sparse population distribution in a number of areas. The fact is that 93 per cent of households are already connected to the basic network. There are 44,000 rural and remote subscribers and, of those, all but 7,000 have been connected to the network. Those 7,000 would probably each need to pay in the order of $10,000 if they were to be responsible for their own connections, and no-one would suggest that. But at the moment it is possible that the connection costs could be of the order of $30,000. That has a lot to do with the fact that, at the moment, we have a very cosseted and over-staffed service.

If people were allowed to make their own arrangements to install their own connections, up to a point; if they were able to engage their own outside labour-and there are plenty of technicians who would be more than willing to accommodate them-it is my view that the cost could be substantially reduced. To the extent that government is justified in providing subsidies-I willingly accept that there are very many areas where people are genuinely in need of government assistance-that assistance can be provided at a much reduced cost. That is what this exercise is all about. It is sheer disinformation and distortion to pretend that somehow this debate is about removing cross-subsidies and subsidies. It might be about removing cross-subsidies; it is certainly not about removing subsidies.

I contend strongly that if we want to have a more efficient delivery mechanism we should identify the extent of community service obligations, we should identify those who are in need of assistance and we should then determine the most efficient way of providing that assistance. We can do that in a variety of ways. For example, in the United Kingdom British Telecom has a licence which requires it to provide services to rural and remote areas. They might not be as extensive as they are in Australia, but, undoubtedly, there are a number of areas where services are provided below cost. British Telecom does not ask for any government assistance to do that; it is unfamiliar with the notion of community service obligations requiring cross-subsidies or requiring any direct government subvention. It wears it quite willingly as a means of achieving universal coverage and it does that because, at the moment, it has a very tiny competitor in Mercury which has been prohibited for some five years from getting into the market in a decent way. But the reality is that, in due course, Mercury will acquire a greater degree of involvement in the market. It will not be the dominant player any more than Telecom will cease to be the dominant player in a competitive market.

I was interested to hear Senator Powell say that Mel Ward, the Managing Director of Telecom, had said that telecommunications is constantly in a state of transition. I thoroughly agree with those remarks, but I find them slightly inconsistent with the suggestion of the Australian Democrats that somehow we are all about change and what is needed is to maintain the status quo.

If we are about transition and if we are about acknowledging what is going on in the rest of the world, then we have to understand that the reason why the United States, the United Kingdom and Japan have moved to open up their networks to extensive competition is that otherwise, inevitably, there is going to be major bypass of the existing network. It is already happening in this country. Four of the States have already established private networks under various names. Some of us would remember Q-NET in Queensland. Senator Jones no doubt remembers Q-NET. That now I think has been sold off to the private sector. But the reality is that each of those State government instrumentalities and public service areas has been anxious to avoid using the public network because of the unnecessary cost that is involved, and because they are required to be unwilling subsidisers, that practice will increasingly expand.

It will be found that Telecom's major corporate customers, which it now regards as a discrete group of 200 to 300, will increasingly want to bypass the basic network and they will be then opting out of the system. To the extent that they do, Telecom's capacity to cross-subsidise will be markedly reduced. It has been reduced by some hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years as a result of the activities of State governments, many of them Labor governments. Visitel in Victoria is a State Labor government creation. That is going to go on happening. It will happen in Western Australia. It will happen in South Australia and in New South Wales. It will happen, not because people have ideological hang-ups or because they think it is about time they did something different: it will happen because there are irresistible economic imperatives that drive people to look for the lowest cost service. As that happens, Telecom's ability to maintain the cross-subsidy will be substantially reduced and the squeeze will be well and truly on; those people who are in need of subsidy services will be squeezed by Telecom's inability to maintain them, unless it puts up the prices more and more, and to the extent that it does there will be much greater consumer dissatisfaction.

While Senator Powell is here I would like to deal with an inquiry that is currently being undertaken by the Commission for the Future. I think there is an acceptance in this chamber that it would be very helpful to understand the true cost of Telecom's cross-subsidies because it is basic to the whole notion of whether one needs to protect Telecom from competition. I take the view that if Telecom is exposed to competition a number of efficiencies will very rapidly manifest themselves. There will be a considerable reduction of costs, probably because a number of people will cross over to the private sector and not be encumbered by present restrictive public sector arrangements. That, in itself, would contribute to a marked reduction of costs. It would not necessarily put people out of work but it would put them into more productive areas where they would probably be self-employed rather than being part of the almost 90,000 employees of Telecom at the present time.

What the Commission for the Future is proposing at the moment is a fundamentally flawed inquiry. The Commission for the Future is presently suggesting that it should look at the notion of community service obligations. It told a Senate Estimates Committee that it was only looking at them in the non-voice transmission area, but that is not what its project outline says. What I found even more extraordinary was that it is not particularly concerned with costs; in other words, it is looking to see whether one can extend the notion of community service obligations without having regard to the cost of delivering them. Community service obligations are all tagged. What are we on about? Are we on about providing services and maintaining good quality services to all those people who need them? If we are, then I think everyone is in heated agreement. That must always continue to be the case. To the extent that people might be jeopardised by any cost increases, then they have to be assisted in that area.

We are not about pretending that somehow we have not got a 93 per cent penetration rate; that there are remarkably few people who do not have phones who want them. The fact is that last year some 618,000 new connections were achieved and Telecom is basically meeting the demand. Telecom is taking it upon itself to extend connections and no doubt what it wants to achieve by this Commission for the Future exercise, for which it is offering funds at the present time, is a respectable basis for discovering a whole new area of community service obligations which it can then proceed to willingly undertake and argue that it needs the monopoly protection to maintain the cross-subsidy arrangement. It is a highly inefficient way of doing business. It is out of touch with the rest of the world. It is not happening in any other Western nations. We are going backwards.

What I argue is that we should be exposing Telecom to competition. Let us not worry about privatisation; privatisation is an option that has been exercised in other Western countries and certainly in terms of price and quality the results are there to see. All I can say is that that is one of the most effective ways of opening up the system. But let us not follow the British path. One does not transform a public sector monopoly into a private sector monopoly or a dominant carrier as happened with British Telecom. I do not think that was a desirable approach. I am not arguing privatisation. I am arguing exposure to competition and that is what the exercise is all about. If one looks at whether there are certain areas that still need to be the special concern of government, and I am sure that there are, there are ways in which one can achieve the maintenance of those community service obligations other than by cross-subsidisation.

One does it, firstly, by either a direct subvention from the Budget, so that it is transparent, so that people understand what the true cost is and one knows precisely what is involved, or by an internal levy on all telecommunications users. One can in fact provide the subsidies not just to the service provider; one can provide them, for example, to local municipalities which might also be prepared to expend some of their own funds on providing additional public phone boxes or local connections. One could provide it by way of a rebate to individual users. One could provide a lifeline service, as they do in the United States, where they have a specific fund that involves taking money from the long distance carrier and reallocating it to the local exchange. They do that in order to maintain community service obligations, although they do not use that term. But they do it to keep rates down, to ensure that people can afford to remain connected to the basic network.

We would never want a situation in which people were denied the opportunity to have ready and affordable access to public telephones. I am always reminded of Marilyn Monroe's poignant cri de coeur when she described the telephone as her only real friend. I think there are many people in the community who do find the telephone a source of great solace, as those who have teenage children understand. They include the aged and a whole range of people and even politicians, I suppose. There is, no doubt, no shortage of Tiberiuses on both sides of the House. We all know that a telephone is not just a business instrument. A telephone is a basic socialisation tool and it is a fundamentally necessary means of communication at all levels. The last thing anyone would want to do is to jeopardise that. But what I think we must be on about and what I think these regulations manifestly fail to address is that as long as we continue to protect Telecom and to give it this carte blanche to continue to be a monopoly provider under the guise of meeting all of these very vaguely expressed community service obligations, the Government will ensure that it has an inefficient system, with no price competition and that people will be compelled to look for ways and means of bypassing the network and making use of a whole range of other creative systems as they are doing at the moment. The end result will be a bigger and less sustainable dinosaur that will eventually fragment and collapse under its own weight. That is not the way to go.

These regulations do nothing to impose any disciplines on Telecom. Quite the opposite. They do not allow for any measure of competition or efficiency. They do not subject Telecom to any real pressure. They do nothing but protect and expand a monopoly which is basically going in the opposite direction to the rest of the world. I regard it as regrettable. I also regard it as regrettable that there are those who either do not understand or who do not want to understand that exposing Telecom to competition has nothing to do necessarily with privatisation. If one is interested in delivery of services at the lowest possible cost then there are very many ways and means of achieving that, the least of which is to maintain the monopoly in its present form.

I hope that there will be enough people in the community who will understand that those of my colleagues in the National Party of Australia and those in rural and remote areas are not under threat at all. They will be the beneficiaries, as will all of us, who find that a telephone is an essential means of allowing daily activity. As long as that remains the case-it always will be-we all will have a vested interest in the provision of those services at the cheapest possible cost. Those who pretend that somehow this debate is simply about privatisation and who use that as an excuse to perpetuate the monopoly do Australians a great disservice, make us much less competitive internationally and reduce Telecom's opportunities of becoming a more thrusting and vigorous enterprise. I note in passing that it was unsuccessful in achieving a contract in Thailand yesterday. It has a very poor track record when it comes to exports. Telecom will not be the beneficiary of this outmoded arrangement and certainly the Australian consumer will be the loser.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of Estimates Committee A on proposed expenditure for the year ending 30 June 1989, together with the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement relating to information received since the Committee approved its report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Chaney had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) the Government has misled exporters;
(b) the amendments in this Bill constitute fundamental changes to the Export Market Development Grants Scheme; and

(c) as such, they are a breach of the undertakings given by the Prime Minister and the then Minister for Trade during the 1987 election campaign, that the scheme would be allowed to run its full course''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the adjournment of the debate last night I was discussing the development of the export market development grants (EMDG) scheme, the changes in its use, the two inquiries conducted in 1988-one by the Bureau of Industry Economics and one by Price Waterhouse-the basis of satisfactory encouragement of schemes of this nature, the shortcomings of the present scheme and, of course, the famous undertakings of both the then Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that were made the week before the last election. Taking those factors into account, we must remember that Australia has export sales for 1987-88 amounting to $40.8 billion. A scheme of this nature must clearly provide inducements and initiation to new exporters rather than rewards for those that are already in. While rewards are appreciated, it is much more valuable to provide inducements to new people to encourage them to start.

SPEECH.PARA: It is up to the Government to create confidence in an export culture. For instance, we have noted the increase in the value of the Australian currency since yesterday and we have to consider again what this will do to the exporters of today. It is very difficult for them to face this fluctuating and fiddled currency. There have been several changes in the policy, and the Bill before us now shows that Government undertakings are absolutely meaningless. I remind the Senate of the 1990 guarantee that has been referred to. The then Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, made this statement on page 179 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 23 August 1988:
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill
Export Market Development Bill

I have written to all recipients of EMDGS assuring them that the Hawke Government regards the scheme as an integral part of Australia's export effort . . . I have also assured them that we will not undermine that effort by chipping away at the spearhead of Australia's export drive, Austrade.

We find that the Prime Minister has done exactly the same thing, saying that export assistance programs are particularly valuable to small and medium sized businesses attempting to enter foreign markets. We are getting these sorts of undertakings but we are not getting the actions to go with them. The undertakings industry has received are absolutely meaningless.

The elimination of New Zealand as an area from which refunds may he obtained is significant, and I accept that this is one of the areas of closer economic relations that we have to follow through. However, it was not one of the things that the people who were involved in the EMDG scheme were told, and that makes it difficult. Senator Chaney raised this issue last evening and several people have raised it with me. They have done the right thing. They have set up export programs. They have tried to work through the scheme in every way, but suddenly they find that the system has been changed.

The raising of the minimum expenditure threshold is one of the issues. Clearly, from the instructions that were given to Price Waterhouse and the Bureau of Industry Economics, the whole point was to see how much they could reduce expenditure. If there had to be changes of this magnitude, 1990 is not so far away and it would have been time enough then to make the changes or abolish the scheme, as seems much more likely. The performance test is quite anomalous, and it fails to take account of the differences between resource sales and service contracts. Some sales can be made immediately; some may take two or three years to build up. It is very difficult to know how far down the track some of these contracts may be.

Turning to the grant ceiling reduction, if export is our aim the ceiling should have been restored to real value, but it was reduced. Submitting export marketing plans is clearly a very good idea. I have no objection to including it in the legislation, as I have no objection to the cost of language training being deductible. The corporations grouping question will be hard to arrange but I believe it is desirable. It is unreasonable that one entity should have multiple bites at the grants scheme. Similarly, I believe that the new ownership clause is not unreasonable in any way. However, I regret that prior to 1990 the Government has deleted the very small potential exporter with a budget of less than $10,000. It takes time for a small business to grow into a big business. Anything that could encourage exports should be provided. There is a famous case in my own area of a very small operator who makes fruit cakes and exports them to about 26 countries. However, it is very difficult for small businesses to get started because there is very little help for them. I regret that the only thing this legislation does not say is that the Government's real intention is to save $52m and to do that at the expense of losing faith with the employers of 700,000 people generating sales of $5.2 billion.

I have considerable interest in exports; I always have had. It is not because I represent Tasmania but because relatively Tasmania is a most efficient exporter and earner of export income. Tasmania exports many products-agricultural and manufactured products, many different minerals such as gold, zinc, copper, silver, iron, lead, and so on, a range of wood and wood products, wool, dairy products, fruit and vegetables, essential oils, live animals, and meat. Of course, its per capita export figure is considerably higher than the national average.

The present Act provides for the claiming of costs such as advertising, overseas representations, participation in exhibitions, overseas travel, and bringing agents or buyers to Australia, and covers goods with at least a 50 per cent Australia content, plus various service activities and industrial property rights. The present termination date is 30 June 1990. What will happen then? When will exporters know what will happen in the future? Most exporters are making plans for well past 1990, anyway. I think it is time that the Government let them know whether there will be a scheme in the future and, if so, what sort of scheme it has in mind. When will the Government tell exporters what its future plans are? I implore the Government to announce its plans this year.

I noticed recently that Senator Button, in one of the great throwaway lines that he makes at various times, commented that export markets estimated to be worth over $2 billion annually by the year 2000 have been identified for value added production of wool, sheepskins, hides and cotton. It is all very well to make those sorts of statements but, if we are to export $2 billion worth of value added products, what will happen to the markets that we already have? Are the markets for the manufactured products expected to be the same as the markets for the raw products? Will we change the whole basis of our trade with some of these countries? It is all very well to make such statements when one has no intention of backing them up by assisting the people that one expects suddenly to enter such a large trading area.

During Estimates committee hearings I asked various questions about the scheme and how it was working. I was told that 22 per cent of the grantees in the last financial year were first year applicants. What I would like to know, and what I could not find out then, was: with the changes that are proposed, what is the figure expected to be this year? I was not given any answer to that question. It surprises me that apparently there has been no research into trying to find out what the changes are likely to do to our export industries.
