When I questioned officers on how many of these applicants would have been exporters without the EMDG scheme I received no response. I also asked what issues new exporters were raising, in order of importance. Again, there did not seem to be very much information available. I raised whether the cost of servicing representation with regard to 4,150 recipients of the grant was approximately $500 per advance. I was told that the costs were a worry.

One area where real help is needed, and needed urgently, is in product liability insurance. I received some helpful advice only today from Austrade, but nothing that would facilitate a few billion dollars worth of exports of new products to new markets. What will the Government do to assist in this area? In the meantime, plenty of potential new exporters are staying out of the trade, and staying out in hundreds.

Clearly, it would be best if, as far as possible, the expenses of the scheme were applied to grants rather than administration costs. The $500 per grantee servicing cost is a very high figure. However, the services of Austrade are necessary and they must be good. Its officers must be capable and experienced in trade and industry. I am very pleased with the progress that has been made by Austrade. Earlier this year I visited several Austrade stations and am happy to give them high commendation. I have spoken with many exporters and export groups around Australia. They are very keen, enterprising and anxious to proceed. However, they must be told what to expect in the future. Clearly, we need maximum contact with them to learn from their practical experience. I want the exporters themselves to determine the issues that induce the development of export trade. With limited funding we need advice on how and where that funding is best spent.

I return to the question I raised last night: will the Government's Bill encourage industry to export? I cannot see that it will. I think it is quite deplorable that this should be so when the balance of trade is against us. I noticed in today's daily commercial news that there has been a further slide in the value of our export products. The slide is not very big but it represents a trend. It is down quite a lot since the peak in April. Our imports continue to rise in price; our exports are decreasing in price. What is the Government doing except cutting off assistance to exporters? The Government must stand by the fact that it has broken the undertaking it gave to exporters. It has offered nothing to exporters by way of replacement or substitution of the scheme from 30 June 1990 and it has produced no policy which exporters can work from.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -Today we are debating the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1988. Despite the fact that the Opposition is not opposing this Bill, I cannot miss the opportunity to express my concern about the Government's handling of the administration of the scheme. Uncertainty in small businesses trying to develop export markets is rife. The Hawke Government seems not to have heard of the concept of lead time. Only last month we saw flower growers, who have planted particular varieties for export, facing a 38 per cent freight charge imposed by Qantas Airways Ltd. This increase has made it almost impossible for flower growers to compete on European markets. The freight charges increased the cost of sending one flower from 7.2c to 11c. Freight charges amounted to 30 per cent of the total costs. This is just another example which would deter other enterprising flower growers taking the risk of planting varieties of flowers for export.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already mentioned before the problems faced by the creative speciality cheesemakers in my State. Small businessmen are beavering away at producing products which have the potential both to replace imports and to be exported. The export of these cheeses is nigh impossible because of the costs involved in meeting the government regulations-regulations which are far more stringent for the export market than the domestic market and far more stringent than those to which cheeses imported into Australia are subjected. In the amendment to the export market development grants (EMDG) scheme we have another example of the carpet being pulled from under small businesses which are attempting to assist, in their own small but important way, to improve this country's disastrous balance of payments figures. In the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) he noted that the scheme is to be terminated on 30 June 1990. This is less than two years away. Significant changes are being implemented so close to termination, and there are no details of what the Government will put in place if it remains in power. I guess that it will not have the opportunity to do so.

The changes announced in the May statement and implemented five weeks later showed the typical ill-conceived, roughshod approach we have come to expect from this Government. The very real problems of these changes were brought home to me on a recent trip to rural Victoria where I visited a businesswoman and her husband and saw their small enterprise, developed out of their garage, and which now, as a result of her creativity and their joint energy, employs 11 full time and 24 part time workers. They have already made one promotional trip to New Zealand in May-June this year. As a result of the first trip they were reasonably confident of picking up one of the major duty free chains in New Zealand. The committed themselves to a further trip in July-August 1988 only to find the Government's game plan changed almost overnight and they were no longer eligible, just as they were cutting their export teeth in New Zealand. Having had their fingers burnt once, they might be less inclined to make plans to move into other export markets.

I was interested to hear Senator Archer refer to Senator Button's comments about value added wool exports. The small business to which I have referred tried to create the very thing that Senator Button is asking for-value added exports. These creative people, creating jobs in rural Victoria, have had the carpet ripped from underneath their feet. The indecent haste with which these changes have been introduced has had a disruptive effect on people trying to plan their business affairs and it has acted as a disincentive for exporters to invest to improve their access to export markets. This comment applies to other incentive programs as well. If a subsidy can change overnight, and there is no guarantee that it will continue after 1990, exporters can hardly be motivated to spend money to develop their products and their markets.

There is a parallel here with research and development expenditure. The kinds of exports and import replacing industries that the Government wants Australian business to develop will not succeed unless the products are right and the markets are right. The two go hand in hand. The importance of research and development is being stressed again and again by the Government and its Ministers Button, Jones and Dawkins. Senator Button laments the unwillingness of private companies to invest in research and development, while the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, argue about the relative contribution of the public and private sectors and the areas to which these funds should be attracted. The current debate between Jones and Dawkins should be cold comfort for universities now subjected to increasing control over the allocation of their research funds. This Government's philosophy is that it knows best how and on what research money should be spent even if the Ministers cannot agree.

The export development scheme has been subjected to four significant reviews in the last three years. There was the Ferris report-the report of the national export marketing strategy panel in 1985. The amendments suggested by it were only accepted in part. In 1987, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts called for submissions from Austrade on the improvements in administration of the scheme following an audit report. In January this year, we had a reference given by the Government to the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) to review the scheme. It was requested to report to Senator Button, the Minister, by 31 March 1988. In fact the report was finally presented in May-the same month as the economic statement-which foreshadowed the legislation under discussion. Indeed the legislation was presented to the other place the same night as the May economic statement. The BIE report was not released until September 1988, four months after the legislation was introduced. Also, in 1988, Austrade commissioned the Price Waterhouse organisation to assist in assessing the scheme's progress. This report has not been released. The Minister told an Estimates committee only last month that it was his decision as to whether and when it would be released.

A lot of tinkering-let me say quite expensive tinkering-in terms of both the cost of reviews and the cost to the exporters caught in the changes, has gone on and yet this is a scheme which is operating under a sunset provision in the relevant legislation. The claim is that these changes will make the scheme cost effective. What costs and disincentives are being imposed on exporters resulting from the constant changes and constant uncertainty? The point of all these reviews essentially has been to save money. The BIE report claims that there is an economically justifiable case for export support but we cannot afford the scheme as it is. It has suffered from chronic budget overruns, and this is not the fault of the exporters. It is the fault of the Government which has repeatedly failed to frame its Budgets properly.

The scheme has open access. This means that any exporter who meets the qualifying requirements is eligible to apply for a grant. The cost overruns have varied between 14.3 per cent and 46 per cent of the aggregate grants paid. for 1988-89, the Government has appropriated $109m, the same as in the Budget for 1987-88. In fact, in 1987-88, the Government had to seek an additional appropriation of $64m to meet the legitimate claims of exporters. This year, the explanatory notes provided to the Senate Estimates Committee once again showed a shortfall of an expected $64m. As the claims paid in the current financial year relate to the exports generated in the previous financial year, there is every probability that, early next year, the Parliament will be asked to appropriate another $64m at least. So, the Hawke Government cannot even get the numbers right for past exports.
The Government has also tried to obscure the truth about this current legislation. In the May economic statement this year, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said:
The way forward for Australia is not to be closetted and sheltered, but to be open and dynamic, trading aggressively in the world.
This sounds like a call to spend more money on helping exporters-not less. In the papers attached to the May economic statement we read:
The Government has decided to amend the export market development grants scheme to improve its cost effectiveness.

Again, a reasonable person might read this as meaning that the same amount of money is to be spent but in better ways. The Public Service has finally blown the whistle on the Government. The explanatory notes to Estimates Committee A state freely:
As part of the May Economic Statement the Government amended the EMDG scheme from 1/7/88 to reduce its cost.

So there we have it. There is nothing about improving Australia's export performance and nothing about spending money in better ways. These amendments are presented for one simple purpose-to reduce its cost.

Obviously the Opposition does not object to containing or reducing costs and at the same time making the scheme more effective, but not on five weeks notice and not at the expense of small businesses often working from scratch to build up export earnings. The current scheme has been continually patched up and there have been cost overruns in every budget. If a new EMDG or similar post-1990 scheme is planned, the lesson that has been learnt from the current scheme is that adequate checks and balances should be in place from the start and not introduced willy-nilly throughout the course of the program. If that were to be done, the uncertainty created by the adhockery of the present scheme would be avoided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sound management of Government finances requires cuts in unnecessary and wasteful spending and especially in non-productive expenditure. The Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1988 that we are now debating fails to meet those criteria. This Bill is an unjustified cost cutting exercise. At a time when the Australian dollar has appreciated in value by around 20 per cent over a three- to four-month period against our major trading partners, the Government is pulling the plug on assistance to exporters to finance, among other things, its vote getting cuts on beer excise.

SPEECH.PARA: Containment of our massive trade deficit is, as we all know, contingent upon a continuing increase in our level of exports. The Australian dollar is currently over 82c of the United States dollar-the highest it has been for some time. This makes our exports more expensive, less competitive and therefore harder to sell. The value of imports is increasing at more than double the annual rate of increase in the value of exports. Our economy simply cannot continue to sustain this deficit increase for much longer. Yet we have before us a piece of legislation which, although masquerading as an improvement to the export market development grants scheme, is a gross act of sabotage.

This Bill introduces changes which will allow fewer people to be eligible for the scheme which virtually eliminates small business, totally cuts out one trading area and will cause many exporting companies considerable financial hardship. The need for assistance in establishing overseas markets has been recognised by a succession of Federal governments and all the major business organisations.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the former Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, have made categoric statements on the need for maintaining export assistance. Mr Hawke has given his personal guarantee that the pre-election promises that he made regarding the continuity of the export market development grants scheme would be met. In a letter to the exporting companies in June 1987, the then Minister, Mr Dawkins, said:

. . . the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, gave me his personal assurance that a returned Hawke Government would continue the EMDG Scheme and sustain the efforts of Austrade. The Hawke Government is determined to give its full support to help Australian businesses selling overseas.

Despite all this, the Hawke Labor Government is introducing changes that will drastically alter the effectiveness of the export market development grants scheme and which will undermine the export potential of Australian industry. With the present Prime Minister undermining his credibility in this way, no wonder Minister Dawkins has become the Keating-for-Prime Minister-now campaign manager. By changing the rules in the middle of the game, the Government could seriously damage Australia's international trading credibility.

The increasing success of the export market development grants scheme is clearly demonstrated by the fact that, in the 1986-87 financial year, each cash grant dollar yielded $41 of export income, an increase of $3 from the $38 yielded in the previous financial year for each dollar of cash grant. In addition to the hard export dollars earned there are many intangible benefits, such as knowledge of overseas markets, increases in economies of scale which can benefit domestic market production and prices, and wider international demand for Australian products. Yet this Government seems bent on killing the goose that laid the golden egg. This proves that the Government believes that success should be penalised rather than rewarded. Our current account deficit is increasing by $1,000m every month because we are importing more than we are exporting. Our foreign debt has increased by $10 billion from last year, to reach $115 billion by June this year. This is likely to increase if our dollar continues to appreciate, making imports more attractive and exports less competitive.

In 1986-87 exports of manufactures and services grew by 26 per cent over the previous year but at the same time the cost of exporting increased. These higher costs mean that the increase of 9.5 per cent in export prices represents a real increase of only 4.5 per cent, and export growth in 1988-89 could well be adversely affected by a downturn in worldwide commodity prices.

Various representatives of Australian business have expressed grave concern about the changes to the export market development grants scheme, as well they might. A group consisting of State chambers of manufacture and commerce as well as other smaller bodies made a submission last March to the Bureau of Industry Economics and to Austrade regarding the export market development grants scheme. This submission made a great many points on the current scheme, regarding its necessity and effectiveness, and it made some recommendations for its future. Most of these points and recommendations have been totally ignored by this Government. Nevertheless, I shall mention some of them because they are a reflection of what the exporters themselves feel export assistance should be about. They present some relevant and valid criticisms. The submission to the Bureau of Industry Economics and to Austrade begins with a list of reasons why Australian manufacturers need the export market development grants scheme. These can be summed up by the opening statement:
. . . the EMDG scheme is seen as an incentive to manufacturers to enter and develop offshore markets for their companies and products.

The submission stresses that the export market development grants scheme is a financial and psychological motivation for firms to enter the high cost, high risk and low marginal return business environment of the international market place. It then reiterates that these disincentives are balanced by the benefits of growth and expansion of business, leading to higher employment, greater turnover and cash flow, and most importantly a reduction in our current account deficit. The second part of the submission highlights the effectiveness of the export market development grants scheme and includes some confidential case histories as illustrations. As the submission emphasises, apart from providing a counter to the more generous schemes provided to exporters by other countries, the export market development grants scheme provides a positive and crucial financial incentive to the long term export plans of Australian companies. Cutting back on the scheme now will badly damage our long range markets and international trading credibility, and could result in a drastic reduction in export returns. The submission emphasises the adverse effects of what were then only proposed changes-adverse effects which the Government has irresponsibly ignored despite this dire warning. This Government has also totally ignored the recommendation of this industry submission to maintain the export market development grants scheme in its present form until its expiry in 1990 and it has ignored the recommendation that a review board be convened as soon as possible.

In June, in my own State of South Australia, the South Australian Exporters Association, in conjunction with the Australian Manufacturers Council, made a last ditch stand to prevent the changes to the scheme and to make the parliamentary representatives of the people aware of the threat these changes pose to small businesses attempting to enter export markets. Yet the Government has also chosen to ignore these warnings. That is not all this Government has disdainfully ignored. It has also ignored its own protestations and promises. Since before the 1987 election the Prime Minister and his cohorts have been touting the necessity of maintaining the scheme intact. I have already quoted the former Minister in this regard, and on 16 June 1987 the Prime Minister said in a speech he presented:

Stability and certainty in the formulation and implementation of industry policies are crucial. Industry assistance policies must therefore be allowed to run their course. Export assistance programs are particularly valuable to small and medium sized businesses attempting to enter foreign markets.
Positive assistance measures such as export incentives . . . are investments in the long-term competitiveness of this nation.

Time and time again the Hawke Government and Austrade have reiterated that export assistance is vital to small and medium sized businesses entering export markets. The Chairman of Austrade, Mr Bill Ferris, said in a media release in May this year:

. . . both the Board of Austrade and the export community regarded the Grants scheme as very successful in that it provides cost effective incentives for Australian exporters, particularly the smaller and medium-sized manufacturing and service companies.

An Austrade survey conducted in February 1987 showed that smaller companies are the most successful exporters, as 95 per cent of the best performing exporters had an annual turnover of less than $5m. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, which is responsible for Austrade, stated, as announced in the May economic statement, that the export market development grants scheme aims to encourage small to medium sized Australian exporters to seek out and develop overseas markets, and that its objectives are to assist committed, newly emerging small to medium sized exporters in developing markets. But the changes announced in that economic statement will do exactly the opposite. Firstly, the total removal of New Zealand as an eligible market for expenditure will eliminate many of the new smaller exporters who often begin their move into the international marketplace in New Zealand. Also, the sudden announcement to remove this market as of 1 July 1988 will obviously cause financial hardship and disruption to market development plans and funding which has already been committed to the market for some time. Secondly, the proposal to raise the eligible expenditure threshold from $5,000 to $10,000 will prove to be an insurmountable barrier to many small businesses and will cause financial havoc with those firms which have based their costings on a certain level of export assistance returns. The scheme was due to run until 1990, and it should have been left untouched until that date.

The export earnings test is already severe enough and the proposal to tighten it up will only make things more difficult for exporters, especially in the early years. Austrade acknowledges that it takes three to four years to get an export market established, yet under the new rules only 20 per cent of export earnings will be eligible for grant payments. By the seventh year this will be down to 5 per cent. This will especially affect export sectors which already have difficulty meeting export earnings tests. I refer particularly to manufactures, construction services, computer software, high technology products, industrial property rights, and licensing and servicing companies in general. Many of these companies take many more years to generate export earnings than do commodity exporters, who can often generate large values of exports very quickly.

This proposal will provide only minor cost savings but will create a major disruption to the scheme. It is not only the small exporters who will be adversely affected; larger and long established businesses will also be severely disadvantaged by the Government's decision to reduce maximum grant levels from $200,000 to $100,000 for those exporters who have received grants over nine years. It is taking away 50 per cent of the support and export promotional budget which frequently means the difference between Australian products being internationally competitive or non-competitive.

In addition, the changes in this legislation completely ignore inflation. The grant ceiling would need to be raised to $300,000 to restore it to its 1983 level. By cutting it to $100,000 the Government is cutting it by two-thirds in real terms. Similarly, the cut-off figure of $20m should be indexed. In June 1988 the Australian Manufacturers Export Council (AMEC) sent a letter to the Prime Minister in which all these points, and others, were raised. The Council expressed its members' disappointment at the significant alterations the Government was making to the export market development grants scheme. It is particularly concerned about the speed with which the decisions were taken after what it termed very hasty examinations and the very limited opportunity for public participation. AMEC made a very serious charge against the Prime Minister. In its letter it said:

The Australian Manufacturers' Export Council considers the amendments proposed in the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill constitute fundamental changes to the scheme and as such are considered by the exporting community as a breach of the undertaking by both yourself and the Minister for Trade during the 1987 election campaign, that you would allow the scheme to run its full course.

This is indeed a very serious accusation and a very valid one in the light of the statements made by this Labor Government in the past 18 months. Even the Chairman of Austrade, Mr Bill Ferris, is on record as having said, on 26 May this year, that the Board of Austrade regretted that the Government had found it necessary to alter the eligibility criteria for the export market development grants scheme. AMEC concludes its letter by urging the Government to reconsider its decision for the benefit of Australian exporters and therefore, of course, for the benefit of the Australian economy and the Australian people as a whole. This Bill clearly indicates the Government's refusal to give that due reconsideration.

So there we have it: a complete contradiction in terms, with the Hawke Labor Government yet again flying in the face of informed and concerned opinion. It is yet another of many examples of this Government saying one thing and doing another, just as it has done with the Industrial Relations Bill, which we recently debated in this chamber, and as it is now doing with its Budget forecasts. Last year this Government said that it would not alter the export market development grants scheme, yet less than 12 months later it has done just that, to the great detriment of the long term plans of Australia's exporters.

The Government claims that this country needs exports and that it wants to assist exporters in their efforts to build overseas markets. Yet in reality it does nothing to further this aim. It is all rhetoric. The Government is doing nothing to remedy the chronic situation of industrial relations on the waterfront, where labour rorts and outrageous work practices mean that high costs make Australian exports uncompetitive and frequent work stoppages make deliveries unreliable. Now the Government is trying to put one more nail in the coffin by cutting away at the funding designed to help Australian business sell its wares overseas in the first place.

The Government claims that it is trying to cut costs, yet the figures show that despite a dramatic increase in assistance the export return on every dollar paid out has increased by $3 in one year from $38 to $41. Of course, this will have increased the profits of exporters and hence tax revenue. Cutting back expenditure at a cost of a diminishing export dollar return will reduce tax revenue, largely offsetting any expenditure saving. It would take only a small decline in the $6.9 billion in export earnings generated by these grants last year for the Government to lose revenue of $60m-roughly equivalent to the savings from these changes to the grants scheme. The changes will most likely ensure that decline, so the net effect on revenue will be nil. In other words, the savings the Government claims it will generate through the changes to this scheme will, in all likelihood, be more than offset by the fall in tax revenue as a result of the fall in export earnings from people who would otherwise have received the grant.
I quote Lindsay MacAlister, Managing Director of Austrade, who said:
It is essential for the balance of payments challenge and our economic prosperity that financial assistance for exporters is maintained.

Mr MacAlister reiterated that Austrade had to ensure the effectiveness of the export market development grants scheme as a support to exporters in the long term. How can it do this when the Government has continually undermined the scheme, first by abolishing the sustenance allowance and introducing the threshold and now by further cutting incentives, lowering the amount claimable by raising the threshold again, and wrecking the next few years budgets for exporters?

The Opposition welcomes the changes to the scheme which prevent abuses of it, but we deplore those changes which impose unrealistic financial constraints, especially for smaller exporters starting out, who are faced with the high costs of penetrating foreign markets for the first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable senator for his support. As the Australian Manufacturers Export Council said, the benefits do not outweigh the massive reduction in export market development grants assistance. The current environment in which the Australian dollar is becoming stronger while shipping and air freight rates are increasing is not conducive to a healthy export market in the face of diminishing government support for export effort. Therefore, this Bill is to be regretted. It is also to be regretted that the Government has put forward this legislation and that it has been totally unprepared to reconsider its initial decision on the export market development grants scheme in the light of all the evidence that has been presented to it by the business community in general and exporters in particular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support completely the remarks of my colleague Senator Chapman. I also support what the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) said when he was leading the debate from this side of the House. I totally oppose the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1988, which comes at a time when our balance of trade deficit is at record levels, our dependence on overseas sales is absolutely vital, and when the Senate has just received a report from the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, of which I am a member, which highlights the disastrous state of manufacturing industry in this country. I am absolutely at a loss to understand why this Government is now trying to hurt the small businesses that are attempting to earn some export income for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Although this Bill may have a couple of good points, its intention will not help those who want to get into export industries. In the words of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), this Bill proposes to revise the export market development grants scheme. He used soft words such as `adjustments', `scope to improve' and similar words which hide the fact that this Government has decided that export promotion is not so vital. While the Government has made some improvements to the scheme, essentially this Bill results in many adverse aspects for industry, and that is what I am worried about. If ever there were an inappropriate time to cut back on export incentives, it would have to be now. Yet we have a government that did much for the export drive in the last Budget by knocking some 25 per cent off our export aid. This is a government that obviously has a closet mentality; it does not seem to realise that what we earn out of our own household is important. The Government is putting exports on the back burner and saying, `We will live within ourselves, we will not try to expand our exports'.

The balance of payments figure for August showed a deficit of almost $1.4 billion. The month before the deficit was about $1.6 billion. We have just had another balance of payments deficit that was just under $1 billion, and in June this year our foreign debt was $115 billion-an increase of $10 billion on the year before. I cannot understand why we are not giving incentives to people who want to get out and sell more produce abroad. Our debt represents about $7,000 for every man, woman and child in this country. Our children and our grandchildren will be repaying this debt to other countries. We must have an export industry and we must have an incentive for that industry, yet that is being taken away by this Bill. We need those overseas markets; we need to increase our exports and reduce our imports. Yet here we have a government which discourages new and additional exports. That is not atypical of this Government; in fact it is quite typical because it has not always given a lot of help to Australia's industries.
I refer the Senate to a press statement by the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, on 22 June 1987, when he was Minister for Trade. In Sydney he said:
I have written to all recipients of EMDGS assuring them that the Hawke Government regards this scheme as an integral part of Australia's export effort . . .
He went on to say:
I have also assured them-
that is, the people in the export industries-
that we will not undermine that effort by chipping away at the spearhead of Australia's export drive . . .
Those are really shallow words when we realise that, just over a year later, the Government is chipping away at the export market development grants scheme.

I would just like to give a couple of examples of how the scheme might have helped in the past and how it will now be in a lot of trouble. A colleague of mine in the other House, the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), talked about the dried fruit industry. He said that the industry is not particularly large in Australia but its earnings of $100m last year added significantly to the Australian economy. Because of this Government's actions and its withdrawals of assistance this industry stands to lose over $200,000 in export assistance which will seriously hamper its export effort. This is only a small horticultural industry. It spends some $800,000 annually on promotion but it has to compete on world markets with countries such as the United States of America. Of course the United States Government gives some $10m annually to assist the United States raisin industry alone.

Recently, I had another example drawn to my attention of a veterinary products company established in Sydney that is adversely affected. It will be more adversely affected now. This company produces feed supplements and medications for the horse industry. Since its inception it has grown quite well and it now employs 12 people in Australia. Because of its success locally it decided four years ago to find markets elsewhere and it established trade contacts in the United Kingdom and Japan. It believes that, by 1992, given the progress and success of its products, 60 per cent of its turnover will come from offshore sales. This company is not a Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and it is never likely to be. It is basically a small group of people who found a niche in the market and who set about expanding that niche. With the previous export incentive grants available to it, it was able to make the move overseas. while the income it generates is only small, nevertheless it is a step in the right direction.

We recently had another great success story-the McGuigan family from the Wyndham Estate in the Hunter Valley. Everyone knows that the family won an export award, having used the export market development grants scheme to get off the ground and into a market. Fancy getting into a market such as France and selling wine to France! What a wonderful achievement. I would like to put on record in this place the wonderful achievement of that family in selling, not coal to Newcastle, but wine to France. The Wyndham Estate's wine is a wonderful wine anyway, but we all know that.

Let us look at the other things that this legislation will do and see why it will knock some people out of the industry. The eligibility threshold will be raised from $5,000 to $10,000. The other day I was doing one of my numerous tours around country New South Wales and I visited a manufacturing industry. The principals in that manufacturing industry asked me how they would go about getting some assistance to try to sell their product in other parts of the world. They have already had orders from other parts of the world but they will now have to expend in excess of $10,000 to get going. They might not want to spend that $10,000 to get going; they might not even have it. Let us not forget that this has to be money up front. Some of the small companies now will not be able to afford to put $10,000 up front.

Another measure in the Bill is the reduction in the maximum grants payable in successive years so that by year 10, the maximum grant will be $100,000. That will also affect other companies. In this country interest rates are rising, wages are increasing much too rapidly, our inflation rate is double that of our trading partners, and the Government talks a lot about the wonderful things that it will do for business. I say, `ha, ha, ha!'. What exactly has it achieved?

TALK.START.PARA: —Heaps.
—I see that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is back. Obviously he has been allowed back into the country.
—And Trade.

—I will get to the Trade part in a minute. The Minister obviously believes that he is a member of a foreign country and that is why I asked whether he had been allowed back into this country. Obviously, his own Government is taking a fair bit away from helping people in the trade area. In his travels around the world he will find that people really want to buy Australian products but because incentives are being taken away from Australian manufacturers and producers they will not be selling to the rest of the world the wonderful things we have here. I do not think they will be thanking him for that, but obviously they have let him back into the country this time.

SPEECH.PARA: What about a few of the other things that this Government should be doing, such as cleaning up the waterfront? That would give exporters a bit of a go too but obviously that is not in this Minister's portfolio. After years of inquiries we have just had a report about the waterfront which tells us exactly what problems we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many reports?

—Look at the labour market. Why do we not start getting a little productivity in the market? Senator McKiernan, who is one of our top trade union representatives from the west, was part of a committee that actually looked into the revitalisation of Australia's manufacturing industries. He has a lot to answer for in this place for what he has inflicted on the community in the western part of Australia. I hope that he will speak in this debate and say that. He did enough damage in his former capacity in making sure that we do not get exports. We cannot compete on world markets because we do not have a productive system in this country that allows us to do so. Something has to be done about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I finish-I know that Senator Macklin wants to get going before the suspension of the sitting for lunch-I would like to mention the amendment moved in this place by Senator Chaney. He said in paragraph (a) of that amendment:
. . . the Government has misled exporters.

I do not think anyone would disagree with that after the statement of Minister Dawkins only one year ago. The Government has misled Australian exporters-there is no doubt about it. Paragraph (b) of our amendment states:
. . . the amendments in this Bill constitute fundamental changes to the Export Market Development Grants Scheme.
How they do! They have already been itemised so I will not go through them again. Paragraph (c) of our amendment states:

. . . as such, they are a breach of the undertakings given by the Prime Minister and the then Minister for Trade during the 1987 election campaign, that the scheme would be allowed to run its full course.

The Australian people, the exporters of Australia, the people who want a decent income and standard of living in Australia, can ask this Government at the next election what it has done to make sure that this country is going along the right track so that it will be able to export and get into new markets. The people will show this Government at the ballot box that it has not done the right things by industry and by the people of Australia. They will decide at the ballot box in favour of the Opposition which has just highlighted and put on the record this Government's underhanded approach to the export market development grants scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill seeks to amend a scheme which has been operating since 1974. A series of changes has been made since that time. For some 14 or 15 years prior to 1974 an export market allowance scheme was operating. So this has been a long-standing method that Australian governments have used to assist our producers to export their products. Following the remarks that Senator Brownhill and other Opposition speakers have made, I hope that in the committee stage we will receive their support for the amendments that I shall move. Those amendments have been prompted by the exporters themselves. I shall expand on this in the committee stage, but I have attempted to meet at least two of the prime objections to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a rationale behind assisting our producers to sell on overseas markets, it has to be based on the notion that they are confronted with an enormous range of problems which arise from the fact that this country is geographically isolated from most of its major markets. The problems include up-front costs, trading facilities, an understanding of local conditions and laws and logistic and commercial requirements. All these things combine to make it a fairly daunting task to get into the export business.

Honourable senators will recall the debate a couple of years ago on the setting up of Austrade, when I think there was general agreement that the activities of government in this area are vital and crucial to the success of the private sector's thrust into exports. The introduction of this Bill at this particular time is, I think, unfortunate. It was announced in the May mini statement that the scheme would operate from 1 July this year, when many of the exercises contained in the Bill are such that the longer term agreements that people have been making, the longer run of positions that people need to take and the planning that people need to put into these types of exercises are massively disturbed by the short time frame that has been suggested-in particular, the New Zealand one which I wish to address in the committee stage by way of my amendments.

The second major difficulty that we see is the way in which the support scheme is handled. I shall move amendments which seek to recast the exercise so that there will be a phase-in operation. I suppose it is very difficult for people outside to say that if a company has $20m-one of the figures used in the Bill-it needs that type of support. I have long been a supporter of the notion that if we are going to give any incentives it ought to be done on the basis of the results we get. I would have thought that a company that gets up to $20m exporting ought to be given incentives to go to $40m and $60m, rather than being told, `You have reached that level so we will cut out the support'. The obvious thing that will occur is that people will stay under the $20m. In other words, the scheme becomes a disincentive rather than an incentive to export.

At this stage I want to say only that I think it is most unfortunate that we are dealing with this matter in the context of the entire Bill when $400m has been provided by this Government for the promotion of alcoholism-basically that is what the deductions with regard to the sales tax on beer amount to-while in the same Budget all that we have about trade is a disincentive. I believe it is unfortunate that we have had this Bill and I look forward to Opposition support in the committee stage when I move the two amendments that have been suggested by exporters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its consideration of this measure and urge that it be given a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order the Senate will now turn to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity today to draw the attention of the Senate to the excellent work undertaken by Greening Australia. This association has worked tirelessly to make Australians more aware of the importance of vegetation and tree planting. I believe its tremendous efforts deserve acknowledgment and commendation. Recently it was my privilege to attend a function in Brisbane when Greening Australia and Men of the Trees arranged for a tree planting in Anzac Park at Toowong especially for our bicentenary year. Representatives from countries involved in World Expo 88 all came to plant a tree, and, of course, I believe that this will be a permanent reminder now that Expo is being dismantled in Brisbane.

SPEECH.PARA: Greening Australia was established six years ago as the community arm of the national tree program and since then has been associated with the planting of millions of trees throughout Australia. It has established organisations in each State and has succeeded in coordinating financial resources with the efforts of community groups, individuals and government to establish a wide range of projects associated with the national tree program.

Greening Australia subscribes to the aims of the national conservation strategy for Australia. It believes that conservation and development are not incompatible-and that is a very important point indeed. Development is necessary to satisfy the demands of our increasing population, but unless it is guided by ecological, economic, social and cultural considerations it could have unde- sirable long term effects. Over the years, much of our native landscape has been cleared to make way for mining, industrial and urban development and for the agricultural and pastoral industries on which the economic strength of Australia depends. This loss of tree cover has accelerated soil erosion, increased salination, degraded water quality and reduced soil productivity. Essentially soil is a non-renewable resource. Topsoil lost to erosion will not be replaced naturally for thousands of years. Trees can help control erosion and are a renewable national resource.

Practical reafforestation and farm plans using trees and other vegetation can help promote improved land use management. The Fraser Government recognised the importance of tree decline and associated land degradation in 1982. It established the national tree program to encourage Australians to conserve, plant and regenerate vegetation for both community and private benefit. Fortunately, Australians have taken to the idea and the trend continues to grow.

I believe that conservationists not only need to talk about saving our rainforest and our trees; I believe they want to take action to plant trees, and this is what we have done around my home at Kingaroy. I look back to the time when my husband was quite young and we had an area of scrub behind our home at Kingaroy and he was all for cutting it down to grow some more corn. Fortunately, his father decided that the trees were more important than the money from the corn-one did not get too much money in those days anyway from selling corn-and so we kept the scrub, and that scrub, of course, has been added to by trees very regularly indeed. Our Kingaroy state school has a regular club day every year. One of its clubs is a tree planting club, and it is encouraging children to love trees and to grow trees. I think that, if all schools around Australia were to develop club days and have a tree planting club, this would be of very great benefit to Australia as a whole.

As a non-government organisation, Greening Australia enjoys a good measure of community support. It has benefited from support by large public corporations and by many small businesses at local level. This support supplements funding, advice and assistance provided by the Federal and State governments, but it is simply not enough. Greening Australia urgently needs further assistance if it is to succeed in carrying on its work in the twenty-first century. As a means of furthering public awareness of the problem of tree decline, Greening Australia established an annual award for outstanding achievement by an organisation, individual, authority or firm in furthering the greening of Australia.

In 1986, this award was made to the Lions Club of Bardon, in Brisbane, for its work with the Ithaca Creek project, which had its genesis in the establishment of a small children's playground but developed into the rehabilitation and regeneration of some 10 kilometres of creek line through Brisbane suburbs. It was an outstanding achievement and has attracted national and international attention.

In 1987, the award was made to Alcoa Australia Ltd. In support of greening during the International Year of the Tree in 1982, Alcoa undertook the development of an extensive community planting support scheme to encourage tree planting, particularly in rural areas where the need for trees is greatest. The scheme has been outstandingly successful and resulted in over 100 community tree groups being formed in Western Australia-and I am sure that Senator Knowles would be very interested indeed in that project there.

This year the award went to the Yass River Valley revegetation project in New South Wales, and it was my pleasure a couple of weeks ago to present this Australian award. The project has been operating since 1984. It has adopted a total catchment approach to ameliorating soil erosion and salinity problems in the Yass district. The project leader, Mr John Ive of Yass, attributed the success of the project so far to cooperation between the Government and an enthusiastic community willing to participate. The project has assisted in the production of comprehensive farm plans, the construction of a nursery capable of producing 25,000 tree seedlings per year, and has involved local schools in tree planting. It is good to know that the schools in the Yass district are being involved in tree growing. That is something, as I said earlier, that is very important indeed.

Annual field days have been hosted and a direct seeding machine purchased, the first of its kind used in the eastern part of Australia. The project has also been directly responsible for the propagation of 45,000 tree seedlings. It would not have been possible without the cooperation of a number of dedicated individuals and groups who care about our countryside.

The project provides an excellent model for others to follow as it demonstrates so clearly the benefits of cooperative community action. At the Queensland level I was very pleased to see the three groups were commended by the judging panel: the `Save the Trees' campaign research nursery at Zillmere, the Kern Corporation of Brisbane, and the Turner family of Milmerran. Mr and Mrs Turner were Queensland award winners last year for the extensive planting they have undertaken to protect their property and for their contribution to various field days. There is no doubt that right throughout Australia, if more farmers in rural areas were to plant areas of trees, that would help to alleviate the soil erosion problem immensely. I also begin to wonder whether perhaps if we planted more trees and really greened Australia, it would help us in our rural areas to get a little more rain more regularly. I do not know whether that has a proper connection, but I sometimes wonder whether the fact that we have cut down too many trees has caused the scarcity of rain, particularly in Queensland, or the fact that it does not rain as often as we would like.

Long before tree planting became popular, the `Save the Trees' campaign research nursery, based at Zillmere in Brisbane, was encouraging the conservation and use of trees. In the last 40 years it has sold and donated tens of thousands of trees and has provided advice and research into the conservation and horticultural usage of trees.

In undertaking an extensive streetscape project in Margaret Street, Brisbane, the Kern Corporation encouraged 19 other business premises to improve Brisbane's landscape through their `Brisbane Brush-up Campaign'. I guess that this could be an example, too, to other corporations and firms in other cities throughout Australia. Such projects do much to beautify a city, and I commend Greening Australia for its work in promoting public awareness of the importance of vegetation and tree-planting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was present at the handover by the Country Women's Association (CWA) of a sundial to the Parliament. I was there as a representative of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), but a number of members and senators were there, including my colleagues Senator Margaret Reid and Senator Bjelke-Petersen. Those who have not seen it should take a step out of their way to have a look at this most attractive piece of sculpture, which is a great credit to the artist and also to the organisation which has chosen that piece of sculpture to be presented to the national Parliament. It is very appropriate that an organisation like the CWA would present a sundial. The people in the country have their lives so ruled by the sun. Their crops and their livelihood are dependent upon it. They work by the sun, as we often hear when daylight saving matters are discussed. Their total lives, I think it is fair to say, are dominated by the sun.

SPEECH.PARA: The CWA has often suffered from a `lamingtons' image and it is one that its members strongly resent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with lamingtons?

—They are a lot more than lamingtons, Senator. They have made a major contribution to the lives of country communities, but they have done a lot more than that. They have certainly contributed as thinking individuals to the way this country is run.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly interested recently to be given a booklet in which the CWA listed some of the major recommendations which it had made to State and Federal governments over the years and it was an extraordinarily wide range of matters which its members had studied and in which they had decided to take a continuing interest. I commend them for the amount of work that goes into preparing material so that motions, such as those they have passed in the past, are able to be intelligently debated.

However, there is one matter that intrigued me, and I find it curious that in all the many activities and areas of concern in the community that the CWA has studied, it appeared that it had given little or no attention to probably one of the most important matters that this country faces, and that is the defence of its citizens and its territory. I hope that the CWA will move to look at this direction. It seems to me that if anybody should be concerned to see that a country is properly defended, it should be the women of the country. Our history is littered with the lives of men and women ruined by war. After all, it is the women who send away their men, their lovers and their sons, to fight for our country, and all of us, hopefully, would expect and wish that this country will never again be required to do that. But it is my strong personal belief that there is no way that we will continue to achieve peace if we are not prepared to spend money in peace-time to see that war never comes. By that I mean that we need to have a credible deterrent in this country. We need to maintain good relationships with our neighbours-of course, it goes without saying-but we also need to be seen to be too strong to mess about with. I hope, therefore, that the CWA will look at this subject more seriously and in more depth in the future and take a very strong and continuing interest in something that is so vital to this country.

I want to draw to the Senate's attention four motions which were passed by the CWA in Tasmania at its recent State conference. They are on four widely varying matters which affect the Federal Government. I would like to read them to the Senate so that they can be drawn more effectively to the attention of the Government. The first motion that affects the Federal scene was:

That the Country Women's Association in Tasmania (Inc) request the Federal Government to promote the National Greening of Australia to halt soil degradation by encouraging all citizens to plant a tree each year.
That was moved by the Riverside Branch. The second motion was:
That the Country Women's Association in Tasmania (Inc) urge the Federal Government to review all laws concerning property settlements after divorce.
That was moved by the Selbourne Branch. The third motion was:

That the Country Women's Association in Tasmania (Inc) urges the Federal Government to promote the culling of our Kangaroo herds by licensed shooters and the resultant meat and hides utilized for production of uniquely Australian produced goods.
That was moved by the Riverside Branch. The final motion which affects the Federal Government was directed to both State and Federal governments, and that was:
That the Country Women's Association in Tasmania (Inc) urges the State and Federal Government to consider the recycling of all used tyres for fuel production as part of an anti-litter campaign.
Once more, that was a motion from the Riverside Branch.

That gives an indication of the wide range of matters in which the Country Women's Association takes a very practical and detailed interest. I urge the Federal Government to look seriously at these resolutions, which come from citizens who are prepared to give a lot of their time to improve the lot of their communities, but who are also prepared intelligently to study issues which face the nation. I commend the members of the CWA for their long record of being concerned citizens working for the good of their country.
Sitting suspended from 1.03 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Does the Minister agree that there is a national interest in the stability of the financial system? Is the Minister aware that as of Tuesday Rothwells Ltd is reported as having stopped taking deposits or, more importantly, paying withdrawals? Is the Minister further aware that at this point there is no assurance that the claims of depositors upon it will be met? Is the Minister aware of any action being taken by the Reserve Bank of Australia to monitor these developments? Will the Minister request the Attorney-General to consider directing the National Companies and Securities Commission to carry out an investigation into the affairs of Rothwells under section 291 (2) of the Companies Code, or is the extensive involvement of the Labor Government of Western Australia such as to preclude effective action by the Hawke Government?

—In general I am aware of the matters referred to in Senator Chaney's question concerning the difficulties which are besetting Rothwells at the moment. I am not aware of any Reserve Bank investigation into any matters. That would be a matter perhaps for the Treasurer rather than for me, but I am not sure even of that. As to whether I will request the Attorney-General to direct some sort of investigation under section 291 (2) into the matters relating to Rothwells, no, I will not do that. I believe that the Attorney-General indicated yesterday in the other place in answer to a question from Mr Moore along the same lines that he did not intend to undertake such an exercise of the power conferred under section 291 (2).

—If I may put a supplementary question, Mr President, is the Minister saying that he will not even pass on a request to the Attorney-General for action under the Companies Code on a matter which is apparently likely to involve hundreds of millions of dollars and doubt about the position of depositors? On a matter that is of major concern to many people around Australia, is he not even prepared to make that request of the Attorney-General?

—There is no need for me to make a request. The Attorney is well aware of the request made of him to exercise this power and answered that very request in the House of Representatives yesterday. If Senator Chaney reads the Hansard record in relation to Mr Moore's request, he will see that the answer is there.

—Has the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories been drawn to media reports that the Queensland State Government intends to introduce the Queensland recreation Act? What are the implications of this legislation for the State's management of national parks and the Queensland Government's claim to the World Heritage Committee that the Queensland Government is capable of managing Queensland rainforests without Federal Government intervention?
—They have done it for the last 200 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in Senator Boswell's interjection. I shall list a few things he says may have gone on for the last 200 years. I shall be fascinated then to see whether Senator Boswell repeats his interjection.
—Have you a new suit?
—It is not a suit, as a matter of fact. It is a sports coat. I continually wonder, Senator Brownhill, why my apparel so fascinates the Opposition.
—This is like some sort of edition of Happy Days.

—It was when I bought it. To continue, my information is restricted to what I have seen in newspapers, given that so far the Queensland Government has, as usual, been less than forthcoming in handing out details of legislation which it proposes, but I have had a number of queries in the office as to how it will affect our World Heritage areas in Queensland. Although I have some worries about that, I am sure that the Commonwealth can prevail.

ANSWER.PARA: To answer the question, one major effect apparently will be the creation of a two-man board, Senator Boswell-just two. That will be the Conservator of Forests and the Under-Secretary of the Environment Department. Those two will have the power `to grant any person the right or privilege to do any specified thing in a recreation area . . .' I do not know whether that has been going on for 200 years, Senator Boswell, but I believe that most people in Australia would be appalled at the prospect of anything from logging to giant waterslides being permitted in our national parks. But in Queensland, under the regime that currently prevails, that is now apparently not only possible but almost certain. Obviously there has to be some concern when the National Parks and Wildlife Service is not even represented on the proposed board which is to decide what to do in Queensland national parks. The legislation is so bad that even the Queensland Liberal Party has decided to oppose it, and to get action from that party on anything is indeed wonderful.

I would remind honourable senators that there have already been instances where Cape Tribulation National Park was logged by a couple of Queensland Government cronies only a year ago, and it is only two or three years ago that the Queensland Government tried to sell Lindeman Island. I would have thought that somewhere along the line the Queensland Government might have learned something, but it raises serious doubts about Queensland's management of national parks. Importantly, though, after the first week of December when the World Heritage convention has accepted the inscription of the wet tropics area in north Queensland for the World Heritage List, it will be possible for the Commonwealth to ensure that the practice of giving away to cronies whatever the Queensland Government likes will not prevail in the wet tropics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I remind Senator Tate of Mr Hand's statement on the 7.30 Report last night that he had sacked eight Aboriginal Development Commissioners to ensure a tightening of ADC decision- making. Is it not a fact that the sacked ADC commissioners had moved to sell two ADC white elephants, namely the Oasis Hotel at Walgett and Nardoola, a property near Moree? Was evidence given to the Estimates Committee, at which Senator Tate was present, that amounts approaching $750,000 had been spent by the ADC on the Oasis Hotel which had been acquired by that body during the chairmanship of Mr Charles Perkins, that a decision had been taken in November 1987 by the ADC to sell the hotel, and that the new ADC decided in about June this year not to proceed with the disposal? Similarly, was evidence given to the Estimates Committee that Nardoola had been put up for sale by the old commissioners but withdrawn from sale by the new commissioners? In view of all this and Minister Hand's assertion that the new ADC was there to tighten up ADC decision-making, will the Minister explain to the Senate how these decisions represent any administrative tightening up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two properties concerned, the Nardoola farm at Moree and the Oasis Hotel at Walgett, were the subject of consideration for disposal by the Aboriginal Development Commission. I forget the exact dates. As I recall the evidence on the Oasis Hotel, the ADC commissioners had put the disposal of the property in the hands of landbrokers and the evidence was that such offers as were made did not come in at the reserve price, so consideration needed to be given whether to pursue the question of disposal of the hotel. Obviously that was a factor to be taken into account by commissioners in relation to the disposal of the property.

ANSWER.PARA: There are other factors which they are properly required to take into account to do with the social conditions of those who might be involved either as employees or as customers of that establishment. Indeed, the question of the involvement of the local Aboriginal community in management of that type of operation is very important. No doubt all these factors were taken into account by the new Aboriginal Development Commission board, and it would have taken such decisions as it did in order to fulfil its general statutory objectives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I actually asked the Minister for Justice how these decisions represented any tightening up of the Aboriginal Development Commission decision-making. In view of the fact that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs wrote to the chairman of the ADC asking for a reconsideration of the decision of the old commissioners to sell the properties in a letter which I now seek leave to table, how does the Minister explain the direct advocacy of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in this matter for a course which represents the opposite of any financial tightening up? I seek leave to table the letter.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite proper for a Minister to make representations after he has held discussions with members of the general public. There is nothing very smart in tabling that particular document. I have it here. It is quite a straightforward letter from the Minister to the Aboriginal Development Commission.
—You simply overlooked it in your previous answer; that is all.

—I did not need to have reference to it. The fact is that a letter was sent by Gerry Hand to the Chairperson of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Mrs Shirley McPherson, dated 14 June 1988. I believe that that actually occurred after a meeting of the commissioners on 23 May 1988 when they resolved that no action would be taken on the disposal of the Oasis Hotel until after the matter was discussed in full at the next Commission meeting. As I say, that must have followed the disappointment in the failure to obtain a purchaser of the hotel as it had been put in the hands of the land brokers I spoke of.
—But they didn't get the reserve price, so they gave it away; is that what you are saying?
—I will read to honourable senators the whole letter:

ANSWER.PARA: I have received a number of representations concerning the proposed disposal of the Nardoola property at Moree and the Oasis Hotel at Walgett. I understand that Commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission have proposed the sale based on the economics of the two ventures.

These representations were made to me after my consultations with the Community regarding the ATSIC proposal. On my return to Canberra I met with you and I outlined the concerns of the Community and I asked you if Commissioners would review their decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the meeting with them before the meeting of the twenty-third?
—I will check on that particular date. The letter continues:

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst appreciating the need for the Commission to carefully assess its holdings and to critically examine the performance of enterprises, I am sure that you would agree that any possible alternatives involving continued Aboriginal participation are worthy of further investigation.

Although the representations made to me do not include specific proposals for the future use or arrangement of the two properties, I have nevertheless been impressed with the deep concern held by many Aboriginal assets-
I think that should be people-

If this concern can be redirected into a commitment to manage and develop these properties, I am satisfied that a worthwhile result may be achieved. I would appreciate any reconsideration the Commissioners might give to the disposal action including perhaps a deferral until the interests of other Aboriginal groups in these areas can be fully explored.

It may be that the letter formalises the conversations that were held with Mrs McPherson on the Minister's return to Canberra. But the fact is that the Minister makes representations on behalf of the local Aboriginal communities, which representations were made to him while he was holding consultations on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal. It seems quite proper for the Minister to pass on such representations to the Aboriginal Development Commission.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH WEST TASMANIA: WORLD HERITAGE LISTING

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of claims by the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) that the Federal Government is going to remove 300 hectares of land in the Snowy Range in South West Tasmania from the area to be protected under the World Heritage listing as a result of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests? Is this claim by the ACF true?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a report by a Mr Geoff Law of the Australian Conservation Foundation which has suggested that I will be agreeing to the excision of some area in the Snowy Range. It ought to be understood, as far as I am aware, that at the moment my Department is preparing a series of options as a result of representations that have been made to me by the industry and by trade unions which would take into account some short term industry needs, particularly with regard to the veneer industry. I asked the Department to examine those proposals and come back to me with some options as to how I might be of some assistance. I understand that there has been a leak of one of the options which it has prepared. However, none of the options has been shown to me yet so I am not in a position to tell the honourable senator what I have done or what the other options are. I understand there is an appointment being made for those concerned in the Department to see me on Tuesday. Hopefully next week I will go through those options and be able to make some announcement to the Senate as to what the future of the area will be.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In Volume IV of the Royal Commission report on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam, Justice Evatt concluded that `2,4-D is not carcinogenic'. Is the Minister aware of two recent American studies which have linked exposure of farmers to the herbicide 2,4-D with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and a court decision brought down in Texas in 1987 against the Dow Chemical Co. charging the company with causing death by malignant lymphoma due to exposure to 2,4-D? In the light of this evidence, will the Government rectify the erroneous findings of the Evatt Royal Commission and recognise the legitimate claims of Vietnam veterans suffering ill health due to exposure to agent orange? I refer the Minister to my question without notice on 22 February 1988 and Senator Button's answer and ask: Can the Minister advise the Senate of the Cabinet decision regarding the request by Professor Hardell and Professor Axelson for compensation for damaged reputations flowing from alleged misrepresentation of their evidence by the Evatt Royal Commission?

—No, I am not aware of the two recent American studies that Senator McLean has brought to our attention today. But, I am advised that the Department of Veterans' Affairs monitors material which may be relevant to the effects of chemical exposure on veterans. As previously announced, the Government through the Department of Veterans' Affairs will continue to monitor health trends among Vietnam veterans and take all appropriate action. In relation to the third part of the question, I would draw the honourable senator's attention to my answer on pages 763 and 764 of Senate Hansard of 27 September this year where I indicated that, following the Government's response to the Evatt Royal Commission, the Department of Veterans' Affairs had written to the two scientists. They had replied saying that they might provide further comments in due course. However, at this stage, I have nothing further to add.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not see a contradiction in her statement that the Department monitors constantly developments in relation to these matters and yet, on the other hand, she acknowledges that it has no knowledge of one of the most significant recent pieces of evidence to be acquired in the United States of America and, secondly, of a profoundly significant law case in 1987 affecting this matter?

—I believe that I said that I had no knowledge of the case the honourable senator mentioned. I then went on to respond in terms of the Department's advice. I will take the second part of the honourable senator's question on notice and see whether I can gain any further information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the devastating effects of Hurricane Joan on the Central American countries of Costa Rica and Nicaragua. What action, if any, is the Government taking to assist these countries to overcome the effects of the heavy storm damage?

—On 22 and 23 October, as honourable senators will well know from the news reports, Hurricane Joan did devastate very large areas of Nicaragua. The hurricane also caused damage to neighbouring countries, in particular, Costa Rica. In Nicaragua 350,000 people were left homeless while in Costa Rica it has been estimated up to 120,000 people were affected. The Government has decided, consistent with its normal reaction to these matters, to make a contribution to assist the victims of Hurricane Joan. As I have already separately announced today, $100,000 will be provided, the bulk of which will go to assist those affected in Nicaragua. These funds will be channelled through the Australian non-government organisation, Community Aid Abroad, and through its United Kingdom-based partner agency, Oxfam.

—I address my question to the Minister for Resources and refer him to the current industrial dispute at Mount Newman. Does the Minister support efforts by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) to end restrictive work practices at the Mount Newman iron ore site? Does he agree that the company, the employer, has followed the procedures that he personally encouraged in the tripartite arrangements for the iron ore industry in the Pilbara? Does he agree that the company has been meticulous in working through the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission and that it is the trade unions operating at Mount Newman which have caused the great difficulty the company now faces? Does he agree that developments of this kind have the capacity to place Australian markets for iron ore at risk? Finally, what action is being taken or can be taken to bring about a speedy resolution of the dispute, including the introduction of those efficient working practices which are essential to restoring the mine's competitiveness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question has a remarkable similarity to a question that I should imagine would properly go to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The relationship to my portfolio is at best tenuous. Let me answer those parts of the question that are directly related to my portfolio. The Australian Government has encouraged and participated with the Western Australian Government in establishing the Western Australian Iron Ore Consultative Council. That is a body referred to in Senator Stone's question that has worked to harmonise the interests of unions, employers and the two governments in the iron ore industry. Since its inception in 1984 it has played an important role-not the only role, because there have been other factors at play as well-in setting a scene in which the level of industrial disputation in the Pilbara has fallen remarkably and the amount of productivity per worker has increased dramatically. I have to say as well that that is leaving aside the exercise that I know Senator Stone has some admiration for but I have disdain for at Robe River about 18 months to two years ago as a way in which proper industrial relations should be conducted.
