ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone asked me about BHP's efforts on restrictive work practices. I am aware that BHP, in the context of Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decisions on the 4 per cent, the second tier and so on, has engaged in discussions with its work force on productivity exchange and reached agreements on those matters. I am aware as well that there has been a positive view taken by Mount Newman in removing restrictive work practices, as there has been a positive view taken by the unions in the industry about restrictive managerial practices. But the proper place for those matters to be sorted out-and this is an element of one of the questions-is in the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the body that has legal jurisdiction for handling industrial relations matters in that area. My understanding is that currently there is on foot in that Commission, before Commissioner Jack Gregor, proceedings to do exactly the things that the honourable senator asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another procedure and another procedure.

—Proper proceedings. The company concerned, as have the unions concerned, has absolute rights to bring those proceedings before the Commission. We say as a Federal Government that that is the right place to settle those types of disputes and we call upon the parties to use that facility to do exactly that.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to put this in perspective. The Australian iron ore industry is meeting the challenge of firming and firmer world prices in iron ore. We expect exports for the 1988-89 period to reach an all time record. Perhaps 100 million tonnes of iron ore is achievable in the period 1988-89. As I have said, productivity in the industry is improving. Productivity in 1987 in terms of tonnes mined per employee increased 45 per cent over the 1983 level. Likewise, there has been a marked improvement in industrial relations since the Iron Ore Council to which I have referred was established and started operating.

In terms of the markets at risk factor, a question the honourable senator raised, I have had extensive discussions with the marketing managers of Mount Newman, as I have with the marketing managers of all the iron ore producers in the Pilbara, in order that we understand better the sensitivities of the market for the coming price negotiations in Japan. I have had discussions also with the general manager of Mount Newman, Mr Gordon Freeman, about the industrial relations situation and other problems. There is a recognition by Mount Newman that part of the reason it cannot meet the production quotas it set for itself as production goals is mine design and other engineering factors. They are not exclusively industrial relations factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his response and in particular for reminding honourable senators of the events of some two years ago at the Robe River iron ore site, which is also in the Pilbara. In view of the spectacular success achieved by the Peko-Wallsend company in raising productivity at its Robe River iron ore mine to some 40 per cent above the present productivity level at Mount Newman, has the Minister had any second thoughts about the much vaunted tripartite arrangements for the iron ore industry in the Pilbara, in which he himself was so centrally involved? Would he welcome some assistance from the H. R. Nicholls Society in the resolution of these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not even go as far as Senator Walsh did and ask Senator Stone for a tie from the H. R. Nicholls Society.
—You would be very welcome to it.
—I do not want one, thanks.
—I would send it to you in a plain brown envelope.

—I am sure that may be the way many exchanges occur on the honourable senator's side of politics. As I said, productivity per worker in the iron ore industry, measured from 1983 to 1987, improved 45 per cent.
—That compares to 100 per cent at Robe River.

—As Senator Stone would know, Robe River is one of the smaller operators. The two major operators, who account for an overwhelming proportion of the exports out of that region, are Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd and Mount Newman. Robe River would account for, I think about--
—About 20 million tonnes a year.
—That is out of 96 million tonnes a year. So it is a very small proportion. The productivity achievements have been made most significantly in--
—I would not mind 20 per cent of the market.

—Senator Boswell does not understand, because he comes from Queensland, that the other two companies, Hamersley Iron and Mount Newman, account for at least 70 per cent of production out of the area. In order to get that productivity increase there had to be significant productivity increases in those companies too. Senator Stone contrasts the confrontationist mentality-typical of the Fraser years of industrial relations, which caused this country to be racked by industrial disputation-to the tripartite approach of the Hawke Government, which in the major operators in the Pilbara has achieved significant productivity gains per worker. It has been done on a voluntary basis, without the intimidation and authoritarianism typical of the Robe River example.

ANSWER.PARA: Do I have any second thoughts? No, I always believe it is vastly better to work out problems by agreement than to confront, stand over and intimidate. Do I want a tie from the H. R. Nicholls Society? I thank the honourable senator for his offer, but no thanks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and refer to the numerous articles in the media about the tertiary education White Paper. In many of these reports doubt is cast upon the main elements of this paper. Can the Minister assure the Senate that the mooted changes to tertiary education will ensure greater access and more relevant tertiary courses for Australia in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been reports of the type referred to by Senator Foreman about the Federal Government's policy objectives for higher education, as outlined in the White Paper. They have been mostly inaccurate because all eligible institutions have applied to join the unified national system, although some which are subject to merger discussions have not applied as separate institutions. In doing so, the institutions have given reasonable commitments in important areas, such as management plans, staffing reforms, credit transfer policies, equity objectives and a common academic year. These objectives were all endorsed as important areas requiring reform during consultations on the Government's policy discussion paper which was released almost a year ago. The Government did not seek to tell institutions what they should do in these areas; rather, it asked the institutions to address the issues themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: Institutions in the new system will now be able to share the substantial growth in student places-40,000 over the triennium commencing next year-and the substantial capital works program involving almost 100 new building projects over the triennium, as well as a major program of renovation of older buildings. There has been a problem in some areas because some academics want the additional resources without changing their work practices, as the rest of the work force is doing, in areas such as award restructuring. In particular, some want to preserve the system of lifetime academic tenure, regardless of whether the job exists. That question will be resolved by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission rather than by the Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FORMER MINISTER FOR ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS: ELECTORAL FUNDING RETURN

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the annual report of the Australian Electoral Commission which was tabled yesterday in which the Electoral Commissioner detailed his decision that propaganda material issued at taxpayers' expense by the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs before the last election was clearly an electoral matter requiring the furnishing of an electoral funding return to the Commission-a requirement that was not met by the Minister until after his refusal to provide a return had been referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions. I ask the Minister to give details of the composition of the $11,222 revealed in that return as having been spent on the production and mailing of two booklets, Achievements in Aboriginal Affairs and A Renewed Commitment. How many copies of each booklet were printed and how many were posted? What were the staff and other internal costs involved in their preparation that were not included in the electoral return? Could the Minister provide a similar breakdown for the $24,421 of taxpayers' money spent by the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on the video A Solid Foundation that the Electoral Commissioner also determined to be election material?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PARLIAMENT HOUSE CAFETERIAS: USE OF DISPOSABLE GOODS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to you, Mr President. Following the receipt of a somewhat inadequate reply from the Joint House Department to queries from my staff about the ridiculous amount of disposable cups, trays and packaging used in Parliament House cafeterias, I ask: Could you clarify the role of Parliament House, and those privileged to work here before they too are discarded, in setting an example for the Australian community in moving away from a disposable consumer society towards a conserver society by reducing the volume of disposable items thrown away on a daily basis in this place? Could you tell the Senate what volume of disposable plastic cups and packaging and what volume of chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) producing items are dispensed from Parliament House cafeterias and drinking fountains per week? Could not the ban on polystyrene packaging containing CFCs, which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has promised by 31 December 1989, be imposed immediately in Parliament House, as commercial alternatives are available? Finally, are the buzz words, `centralised production', `economy of scale' and `inadequate design'-meaning lack of storage space in the case of cafeteria glassware-going to be used in this Parliament House to defy what the international scientific community and the United Nations warn is a global crisis of resource wastage?

—Senator Vallentine has mentioned correspondence between the Joint House Department and her staff. For the information of honourable senators I table a copy of a letter from the Joint House Department dated 14 October 1988 to Senator Vallentine's staff on the question of CFCs in disposable containers. Details of usage made by the Joint House Department of disposable wrappings and containers are being prepared and will be provided. I understand that, of all the products, only two-polystyrene cups and hamburger trays-were manufactured using a process involving CFC gases. Stocks of both of those items, when exhausted, will be replaced with products which do not contain CFCs. Due to a lack of storage space behind servery counters in the staff cafeteria, it has been necessary to use disposable plastic cups for soft drinks in lieu of glasses. A number of changes and modifications are required to Parliamentary Catering Service areas. These are being addressed progressively. As problems are resolved a greater use of reusable containers will be possible. I have asked the Joint House Department to further investigate the issues raised by Senator Vallentine and report back to me on whether additional measures to address her concerns are feasible.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to a speech made on 9 October 1988 by Mr Garvin Rutherford, the President of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, to that organisation's annual convention, in which he criticised the competence of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Is it a fact that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) now intends to initiate a contempt of the Tribunal proceeding against Mr Rutherford under section 25ab of the Broadcasting Act? Has the Tribunal sought the Minister's advice or approval or has it simply advised him of this action? Does the Government not consider it reasonable that the President of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters should be allowed to criticise the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, or is the Tribunal to be totally immune from criticism? Will the Tribunal also be bringing an action for contempt with regard to an article published in today's Australian entitled, `Why the ABT must go'?
—I am not aware of the speech made by Mr Rutherford or the response, justified or otherwise, of the Tribunal. I will refer the question to the Minister and seek an early reply.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of a newspaper report in today's Melbourne Herald with the headline, `A million people at risk: government'? The report quotes the Minister as saying that the greenhouse effect could lead to the deaths of more than one million people and is the greatest problem facing mankind this century. Is this an accurate presentation of the Minister's views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article in the Melbourne Herald which is based on an interview in which I took part on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Quantum program. Most of the interview was not broadcast-mercifully so, some might say. While the text of the article is accurate, in some respects, obviously the headline is alarmist to say the least. It might be helpful if I attempt to relate what actually happened.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, the Government intends to seek solutions to what I consider to be the greatest problem facing mankind. I certainly believe that that is the case, so that part of the article is accurate. In one sense it is ridiculous to suggest that a million people are at risk, especially when one is given the impression that they are all in Australia. That is certainly not an impression that I attempted to convey. Obviously the impact of higher temperatures and rising sea levels will be felt by many millions of people around the world. I did not estimate in the interview how many people would be at risk. I merely observed that this development had the potential to cause the death of who knows how many million people. That of course was on the assumption that nothing was done.

Anyone who watched on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation last night the program Inundation of a Nation, which showed countries like Bangladesh where the sea quite regularly washes over the land and causes the death of thousands of people, can appreciate that, if nothing is done, the possibility of millions of people being at risk is real indeed. Nonetheless, I did not ever suggest that that example was applicable to Australia. I suggested only that that would be possible in Australia, if nothing was done to ameliorate the effects of the problem.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Minister for Resources to an article in today's Canberra Times about the formation of an Australian Labor Party committee to review the Labor Party's uranium policy which, and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . all sides say is irrational.
The article goes on to say that the policy:
. . . had to be changed because it was illogical . . .

Will the Minister elaborate what all sides of the Labor Party find `irrational and illogical' with its uranium policy? Will the Minister explain why the Labor Party has failed to develop a `rational and logical' uranium policy in the five years it has been in government? Can the Minister explain to Australians why they are being deprived of an estimated one billion dollars in revenue each year in export income from uranium enrichment for peaceful purposes, because of the Labor Party's `irrational and illogical' uranium policy? Can the Minister advise when we can expect to see a rational and logical uranium policy from the Australian Labor Party? Finally, can the Minister tell the Senate what he believes should be included in a rational and logical uranium policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked a series of questions based on a central premise that some people in the Australian Labor Party regard the policy on uranium as `irrational and illogical'. I have not seen the Canberra Times; I have seen the report or words to that effect in the Bulletin this week. None of the reporters whom I have seen who have reported that matter has named any of the people who allegedly hold this view.
—Oh, come on; you know it is.

—None of them has named any of the people. If that view were true, one would expect to see names being accredited with that view. Since the central premise of this question depends on that and, as I say, I do not believe that anyone has ever been named, I think all the other questions just fall to the ground as a consequence.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the non-answer. He made the remark `if the view were true'. Firstly, if the view were not true, why has a committee been formed to talk about this `illogical and irrational' policy and, secondly, does this mean that the Government is going to continue to fiddle after five years in office when there is an increasing demand for uranium because of the Japanese power companies' decision to stop purchasing from South Africa and Namibia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I took Senator Parer's words down. If the view were true, it might be one person's view, anonymous and unidentified in the Australian Labor Party, that the policy is irrational. It might be more than one person's view. I do not intend to get into a hypothetical discussion with the honourable senator across this chamber about the views of various people in the Labor Party who remain anonymous in terms of public accreditation for that viewpoint.

ANSWER.PARA: He asks me, `Why has a committee been formed?'. In my answer to that question, in dealing with his question forthrightly and honestly, I say that it has to be entirely separated from the premise of the first part of his question to have any logical debate about it. Having now separated it from the first part of the question, I add that the Labor Party is a party never afraid of going back and re-examining its policies and considering the premises on which they were based to see whether over time in the light of new or different information or experience those premises should be reviewed. The reason the National Conference of the Labor Party this year decided to set up a committee to examine that matter is that we believe it is important in this area of policy making to have a dynamic approach and to refine our attitude.

As far as the last point of his question is concerned about market opportunity being lost, I refer him to an article in the Australian Financial Review this morning in which the writer deals with the subject of the possibility of new uranium contracts going to Japan from the United States because of the closing off of contracts from South Africa and Namibia. If the honourable senator reads that article, he will see that one of the prime questions reported is that there is a high level of political motivation, given the trade balance between Japan and the United States, as to why that is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories seen an article by David O'Reilly in the current issue of the Bulletin magazine? Is it true that the `greenhouse effect' has become the honourable senator's `secret weapon' in a campaign to free up the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy, as is suggested in the article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of fact I have seen the article to which Senator Crowley has referred, written by David O'Reilly. He claimed that I was using the `greenhouse effect' as my `secret weapon' in my campaign to free up the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy.
—You wouldn't do that.

—That is right; I would not do that. The journalist David O'Reilly wrote the article without reference to me. I am not sure to whom he spoke; perhaps his informant was Senator Parer who apparently has some knowledge of what people in the Labor Party think on this question. However, I have always thought that David O'Reilly was a journalist who, normally, could get his facts right. Perhaps, if he had spoken to me, that reputation for always getting his facts right could have been maintained.

ANSWER.PARA: I have just said, in answer to another question, how seriously I regard the `greenhouse effect'. It is so serious that I hardly want to use it as a lever to free up anything, let alone our uranium policy. Having just referred to that Quantum interview which I said was not broadcast in full, I have one quote from part of the transcript which was not broadcast. I said:
I am not going to run around advocating that we begin using nuclear energy. That ought to be a last resort. Importantly, I think you cannot rule out nuclear energy as an option.

I think that ought to be the position that all of the parties represented in this chamber indeed take on as the `greenhouse effect' worsens in the next 50 years and we are looking for options. We cannot afford to rule out options. We have to see what technology and what human ingenuity can deliver for us.

In that same interview, I advocated that at first we ought to be looking at solar power and wind power and harnessing the oceans to see what technology can deliver in those areas as being more important. We ought to look at nuclear energy, as I said, only as a last resort. I hope that is a view that can be shared by more than simply people in the Labor Party.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: STAFFING

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business to a motion passed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's consultative council at its latest meeting expressing its concern at the `profound disillusionment of staff arising from the Government's continued underfunding of CSIRO'. I further refer to the reported comments of Miss Carole Popham, Deputy Chairman of the Council, alleging that CSIRO staff are extremely angry and will not remain with the organisation in its present state. Does he agree that there is a critical morale problem at CSIRO as a result of the Government's policies? Does he deny that scientists are quitting CSIRO in large numbers out of anger and frustration? Does he agree that Australia's scientific, research and development efforts are seriously endangered by this brain drain?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some of the allegations contained in the honourable senator's question. First of all, while I concede that CSIRO's funding this year has placed it in some difficulty, the position of CSIRO in so far as government funding is concerned is that for the first time in its history it will have the same funding in real terms, at least, for the next three years. Secondly, next year CSIRO will have the greatest sum available to it in its history. That is because CSIRO will be earning more money from outside sources in addition to the funding it gets from the Government.
—Maybe.

—There is no maybe about it at all. It has said it will deliver on that. It is unpalatable to some people in CSIRO, and perhaps elsewhere, that government funding will not be increased indefinitely for CSIRO and that it has to earn some proportion of its money from outside sources. I remind the honourable senator of the figures. Australia stands very high in the world pecking order in terms of government funded research and development. We stand up at the top of the ladder on that. But private sector research and development in Australia has been abysmal, and therefore our total research and development effort compares very badly with that of other countries. There is no secret that the Government has embarked on a quite deliberate strategy to encourage private sector investment in research and development and to encourage strong relationships between organisations like CSIRO and the private sector. Next year 30 per cent of CSIRO's funding will be coming from the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: I would have thought the honourable senator would have approved of that, being, as I understand it, a National Party senator, because he would know very well-perhaps he does not know; I am not sure that he has had any vast experience in the National Party-that the relationship between the Australian research community and the agricultural sector has been strong for very many years, in fact decades. The contribution of rural sector producers to research and development and the understanding of it has been most important. Agriculture, at least at times, has been using state-of-the-art technology in this country and is very appreciative of the importance of such technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you keep on funding it instead of cutting it to death?

—I am not interested in Senator MacGibbon's mindless rhetoric on this subject. I am trying to answer this other fellow's question. The second part of the question-culled, if I might say so, with great skill from the pages of this morning's Australian Financial Review-relates to the so-called brain drain from CSIRO. The brain drain from CSIRO identified in the article in question is a brain drain of one-a person who was the topic of questions in the Senate two or three weeks ago. Senator McGauran might not have been listening at the time. There is very grave doubt as to whether the brain drain of one illustrated in this article occurred because of government policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator refers me to the remarks of Miss Popham, who talks about the brain drain and the morale problem it has caused. I have agreed this morning to meet with Miss Popham and her organisation and have a chat about some of these matters. I look forward to that. But it is important to note that when she talks about the CSIRO budget being slashed by 30 per cent she is not taking into account the fact that the total CSIRO budget next year will be the biggest it has ever been in the history of the organisation. It is just that some people do not like the source of some of the money when they have been relying for donkey's years on the everlasting arms of government to sustain them and keep them in good stead.

People talk about the brain drain from CSIRO but, if there is a brain drain concerning this country in terms of scientists and engineers, it involves people coming here rather than going away. There is a net gain of scientists and engineers in Australia every year of about 2,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the number of degrees they have, alone, not by the quality.

—Of course, I concede that. That is what it is all about in terms of developing a critical mass of research and development personnel in the community. If there has been a brain drain, it is also in the direction of top quality Australian scientists coming back to this country. I could name a dozen who have come back to work in the private sector because of specific government initiatives such as the management and investment company program which have led to the establishment of a whole range of new and innovative companies in this country. There are plenty of those.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of press reports that the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) is to be given an increase in funding to compensate for the decline in funding it has suffered through the 1980s? Has he also seen comments by the head of the Trade Practices Commission, who claims that the Commission is unable to undertake its role effectively because of the chronic shortage of funds? Are the statements about the increase in funding correct? If the reports are correct, can the Minister indicate what level of increase has been contemplated? If the reports are not correct, does this indicate an extension of the Government's deregulationist push into the area of commercial practice and consumer protection?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen several reports concerning the financial status of the Trade Practices Commission in so far as it relies on funding from the Commonwealth Government. The underlying assumption of the question, that there has been some sort of dramatic decline in funding, is one that has been put forward in the press over recent weeks but I think it needs to be clarified both for Senator Powell, in particular, and for the Senate generally. In fact the Trade Practices Commission's funding has not been treated any differently from other areas of the portfolio, and it has faced no particular subjection of very stringent reductions in its expenditure when we look across the whole portfolio. In money terms there was a small increase, though admittedly a small decrease in real terms, between 1987-88 and 1988-89, from $7.888m to $7.942m. I think that puts the matter in perspective.

ANSWER.PARA: The major reduction in funds appears under the restricted trade practices compliance program, but that is due to an abnormality in that it includes $1.019m which was the final part of the special funding provided to the TPC in the last two financial years to cover an order for legal costs against the TPC when it lost the long running Tradestock case. These costs have all been paid, so no special funding is needed this year. Thus, although sometimes the impression is given that there has been a reduction of something like $1m between the funding available to the TPC this year compared with last year, it really depends on that abnormal payment made in relation to the Tradestock case. In fact there has not been that severe pruning of funds available to the Commission that might otherwise be assumed and indicated. As to any future increase or decrease in funding, the Commission's funding is subject to normal budgetary discussions, and they will be undertaken at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has his attention been drawn to various media reports indicating that doctors are shunning the new system for charging patients that the Australian Medical Association (AMA) sought to have introduced yesterday? Has there been any indication to the Federal Government from the vast majority of hard working, honest and caring doctors in Australia that they have full confidence in the present Medicare arrangement and perfect satisfaction with their present fee arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally I welcome the very positive indications that most general practitioners (GPs) have decided to reject the AMA's proposed new fee structure and continue to charge according to the Medicare benefits schedule. Even the Federal President of the Australian Medical Association acknowledged in Monday's Age newspaper:

ANSWER.PARA: Only a minority of doctors were expected to charge their patients according to the new schedule.

This should be seen not as a victory for the Government, as some people have suggested-indeed it is a victory for everyone and, more importantly, for the patients-but rather as a rejection by the general practitioners of the confrontationist and unilateral approach adopted by the AMA in attempting, without consultation, to impose a new charging system on patients and doctors. I am not at all surprised that at least 80 per cent of doctors have chosen to ignore the AMA's edict to implement substantially higher fees from today. General practitioners have consistently shown themselves to be fair, caring and responsible people and to be enthusiastic participants in Medicare. According to most recent statistics, only 3 per cent of GPs' standard consultations have been charged according to the AMA's recommended fee levels. GPs are showing that they are not prepared to inflict financial hardship on their patients in order to increase their own incomes.

For its part, the Government is prepared to respond to the responsible attitude of GPs by showing our willingness to work with any medical organisation that is prepared to adopt a cooperative rather than a confrontationist approach to resolving the concerns of GPs. The Government is happy to discuss constructively changes to the Medicare benefits schedule, the overriding purpose of which is to improve the standard of patient care. I am hopeful that such genuine consultation might be the outcome of meetings between doctors groups and the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, later this week.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave a preliminary response to Senator Lewis on a question about sponsorship or, more accurately, the sponsorship `crawl' which is broadcast in association with the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) test pattern. I am now in a position to give some further information. I am advised that the SBS has received money for at least two of the sponsorship `crawl' exercises in February and April of this year. Section 79za of the Broadcasting Act provides that the SBS may receive money from program sponsorship of a kind approved by the Minister. I can now confirm what I indicated was my recollection yesterday. I did not give any such approval for this particular exercise and the present Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, advises me that neither has he since he took up the portfolio.

ANSWER.PARA: The SBS has advised the Minister that it received advice from its corporate solicitor that ministerial approval was not required as the announcements were shown only as part of its test pattern rather than in the context of its programs. However, the recent publicity-not just the question yesterday but other publicity before that-prompted the SBS to ask that this advice be reviewed. As a result the SBS wrote to Mr Willis on 26 October seeking his approval for the announcements. Mr Willis tells me that he will respond to the SBS as soon as he is satisfied that the `crawl' messages are in accordance with the provisions of the Broadcasting Act. In the meantime, the sponsorship messages have been discontinued.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received an explanation by Mr Cedric Wyatt, the General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), in response to a question by Senator Peter Baume in the Senate yesterday. That response says:

ANSWER.PARA: On Monday 10 October at about 12.30 p.m. Western Australian time, I received a telephone call from Acting Commissioner, Peter Yu who asked me would I be interested in the position of Acting General Manager of the ADC. Not having any knowledge of what had happened I said that I would be very interested and was asked would I proceed to Adelaide to meet the Commissioners.
