SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald in an article on page 3. That article, which is headed `Perkins may face Senate inquiry', says:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's final decision to recommend the matter be referred to the privileges committee was taken against the wishes of the Government members of the committee, including the chairman, Senator McMullan.

As I made clear yesterday and as the written document makes clear, the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs was unanimous. Having spoken to my Government colleagues on the Committee, Senator Collins and Senator Devlin, I was asked by them to make it clear that that statement is not true. The next paragraph of the article says:

As Senator McMullan tersely noted in his report to the Senate: `Some members of the committee conclude that these circumstances (regarding Mr O'Brien and Mrs McPherson) are sufficient to warrant the matter being referred to the privileges committee . . .

That is also incorrect in two ways. First, it is not my report; the document from which the newspaper is quoting is a report from all six members of the Committee. Secondly, that addition in the brackets regarding Mr O'Brien and Mrs McPherson is wrong; it is a quote from a section of the report relating only to Mr O'Brien. For those reasons I appreciate the leave of the Senate to clarify the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The introduction to the Independent Air Fares Committee report states that one of its main tasks was to monitor the developments in domestic air fare market and ensure that the current economy air fare determinations continued to be appropriate for the period from 1 July 1987 to 30 June 1988. The introduction to the report continues:

In particular, the Committee will continue to approve economy fares which reflect costs efficiently and economically incurred in the operation of passenger services, and to give active support to discount fare initiatives aimed at stimulating the demand for domestic air travel.

The two major airlines in Australia, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines, have a combined market share of 87.6 per cent of the domestic traffic. This is significant because the fares that they charge have a considerable effect on influencing other airlines. These two airlines have the greatest capacity and range of aircraft in the domestic airline industry. One aspect of this is that there appears to be a case of feather- bedding occurring in this industry in relation to manning levels on the larger aircraft operated by both airlines. Australia is the only place in the world where this overmanning-a crew of three pilots-occurs in the larger aircraft. There appears to be a blatant overmanning level compared with that applying in other countries where stringent air safety rules also have to be satisfied. In those other countries these planes are operated with lower crew levels.

I see no indication in the report of how the fares are determined on the routes that use these particular aircraft. I wonder whether the high staffing costs are taken into account. I would recommend that where these adverse work practices apply, the extra manning costs should be excised in determining the level of fares, thus benefiting the air travelling public. Given the previously mentioned task of the Committee, it is important that these costs should be excised when determining flight costs in order to ensure the lowest possible cost to consumers in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Reynolds) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is intended to give legislative effect to the Government's decisions on the issues arising out of the Australian Law Reform Commission report on lands acquisition.

The present law governing Commonwealth acquisition, the Lands Acquisition Act, was enacted in 1955. However, many of the provisions it contains are a carryover from the original legislation passed in 1906. In turn that was based on an 1845 United Kingdom statute.

In July 1977 the then Federal Attorney-General requested that the Law Reform Commission examine the Commonwealth legislation. The terms of reference for the Commission specifically concentrated on the rights afforded to persons whose land was acquired by compulsory process by the Commonwealth.

The report of the Commission was tabled in the parliament in April 1980. The Commission was critical of a number of aspects of the Lands Acquisition Act. During recent years the Commonwealth Parliament has enacted legislation to enable the independent review of administrative decisions which adversely affect individuals. The decision to acquire property, particularly by the use of the compulsory process, is a decision which affects, sometimes profoundly, the owner of the property. There is no mechanism within the current Act whereby an owner may require the acquiring authority to justify publicly the need for and choice of his property. When persons' homes are acquired it can cause significant disruption to the individuals involved. There is no legislative provision to ensure that displaced owners can provide for themselves out of their compensation money a suitable alternative home. It seems reasonable that people in those circumstances should be provided practical assistance and recompense for the intangible effects of removal from their home. This is not provided in a legislative sense in the current Act. Another problem not covered by the Act is that of blight. It is not uncommon for a government's acquisition decisions to be generally known some years before an acquisition may take place. Someone whose property is involved can find themselves in the situation where there is no market for their property because of the Government's intentions and the Government might not be ready to acquire the land for some years. Under the current Act there is no facility for the owner to compel the Government proposing the acquisition to purchase from him. Inflation can also cause difficulties for owners, particularly if there is a significant lapse of time between acquisition of the property and payment of compensation following final agreement on the amount to be paid.

These and other deficiencies with the Lands Acquisition Act were identified by the Law Reform Commission in its report which contained a series of recommendations with three main objectives: more open procedures in the acquisition process; greater public accountability for decisions to acquire property; and more generous statutory provisions for compensation for persons deprived of their land by the Commonwealth.

Following the Law Reform Commission report an inter-departmental working party comprising representatives of the major policy departments concerned was set up to review the report and develop recommendations for government consideration. In 1983 the Government agreed to the implementation of most of the Commission's recommendations to be incorporated into new legislation.

This Bill represents the fulfilment of the Government's decision. It is obvious that it has taken some years to get to the stage of being able to present this Bill to parliament. Whilst that is regretted it is this Government's intention that priority should be given now to seeing this Bill enacted and implemented.

When the Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives at the end of the autumn session, the Government indicated that debate on the Bill would not occur for some months to allow sufficient time for interested parties to examine it in detail and provide comment on it. The Government is pleased that a number of organisations took up the invitation and literally dozens of comments on different parts of the Bill have been submitted.

Submissions were made by a number of groups, including the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Administrators, the National Farmers Federation, Northern Territory and Western Australian chambers of mining, the Australian Mining Industry Council and the Land Acquisition Reform Committee. The latter group convened a two-day symposium in Sydney to discuss the Bill which was attended by the Opposition, the judiciary and the Government.

At that forum the Government emphasised the promise that it would consider all comments made and incorporate any suggestions for amendment which were considered would contribute to the general intentions of the Bill.

The Government has considered all the comments and during the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives 34 amendments which reflect the suggestions and comments generated by the consultation process were incorporated into the Bill. Some of those amendments were of a technical nature but others were made because they contributed to the objectives of this major legislative change which clearly has the interests of individuals as its primary focus.

I now turn to specific provisions of the Bill. There are numerous provisions which are being written into this Bill which are not contained in the current legislation. Time does not permit me to highlight all of those issues. However there are a number of matters which should be brought particularly to honourable senators' attention.

I would first like to make clear that this legislation relates to the acquisition by the Commonwealth of any interest in land. In clause 6 the definition of an interest in land for the purposes of this Bill is as wide and all embracing as it can be. In comments to the Government there has been some concern expressed that the definition might not include mining tenements. The concern is that the Commonwealth might through its actions extinguish some right to the use of land conferred by a mining tenement and not compensate the owner of the tenement.
That is not the case. Tenements are interests in land and if they are acquired by the Commonwealth then the Constitution requires that the owner be justly compensated.

The Bill specifies an entirely new and comprehensive process that must be followed when the Commonwealth wishes to acquire property. At the start of the process the Bill at clause 22 requires the Government to make a pre-acquisition declaration. This declaration is a statement of intention which is provided to the owner identifying the land the Commonwealth wishes to acquire and giving the Government's reason for the acquisition. Clause 23 says that at the same time the Government's intention to acquire is to be made public by publication in the Gazette and a local newspaper. Furthermore the Bill requires that the market place be alerted to the Commonwealth's intentions by providing at clause 38 that the declaration be lodged with the registrar of titles and by clause 39 the owner will be required to tell intended purchasers of the Commonwealth's intention.

The Bill places numerous requirements on the Government to complete acquisitions expeditiously. Throughout the Bill time limits are identified in which the Commonwealth must act or make decisions. One example of this is at clause 44 which says that where an owner has been served a pre-acquisition declaration he can in writing agree to the acquisition and require the Commonwealth to acquire his property within three months.

One of the particularly significant provisions of the Bill is that an owner can seek a review of the Government's decision to acquire their property. Clause 26 of the Bill stipulates that the owner can formally seek that the Minister reconsider his decision to acquire. Following that, if the Minister reaffirms the decision to acquire, clauses 28 and 29 provide that the owner is able to seek review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the Minister's decision. The Bill provides at clause 29 and 30 that the Tribunal will hear the appeal and recommend to the Minister a course of action. Clause 31 lists the range of issues that are to be relevant to any review by the Tribunal. However the review should not include environmental matters where an inquiry has been held under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. It is intended by clause 31 that any such review would encompass: the nature of the public purpose; the extent to which the public purpose is in the public interest; the suitability of the land for the public purpose; the effect of the acquisition on the land owners; the environmental effect of the use and development of the land; and any other means of achieving the public purpose.
However clause 22 says that the policy decision of government which has led to the acquisition should not be subject to review.

This Government is concerned by the need to strike a balance between the rights of private property on the one hand and the legitimate needs of society for land for public purposes on the other. It is also concerned at the effects on efficient administration of legislation relating to acquisitions of land and the speedy resolution of claims for compensation. For these reasons the Bill specifies instances where a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is considered inappropriate and should not be allowed. However, such circumstances are clearly defined and constrained and include for instance at clause 24 where the Minister is prepared to certify that the review should not be held due to urgency or where the issue of a pre acquisition declaration could be prejudicial to the national interest.

This is one part of the Bill that the Government amended in response to comments made during the consultative process that was adopted. Initially the Bill at clause 24 contained a third situation where there would be no pre acquisition declaration and no right of appeal to either the Minister or the AAT for review of the decision to acquire and that was where the Minister certified that it was essential that particular land be acquired. That provision was initially suggested to government by the Administrative Review Council. The notion was that since the Minister was not to be bound by a recommendation of the AAT on the decision to acquire, if the Minister initially certified a definite intention to acquire due to the essential nature of the acquisition, then review of the decision by the AAT would be redundant.

The Government has acknowledged the concern that has been expressed at this provision by deleting it from clause 24. However the Government has retained a similar provision in clause 22 but in that instance a pre acquisition declaration would be issued and made public and the owners could seek that the Minister reconsider his decision. So although appeal to the AAT would not be available use of the provision would be quite public.

Furthermore if an owner of land being acquired using this provision believed that the provision was being misused he would be able to appeal to the Federal Court under the Provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

It is also not intended that review processes would apply in situations described in clause 40 where the acquisition is of the nature of a normal commercial transaction between parties dealing with one another on an equal basis and by inference from which any party is able to withdraw.

This Government is concerned at the effect on owners of some of the Government's activities which might be undertaken leading up to a decision to acquire a property. Consequently whilst the Bill retains the present powers of temporary entry to enable the Commonwealth to enter onto land to investigate its suitability, there are at clauses 9, 13 and 95 added requirements over the present legislation for the Commonwealth to: give 7 days notice of the proposed entry; minimise damage to the land; compensate for any expenses incurred by the land owner; as a consequence of the temporary occupation in addition to any damage or loss suffered.

Furthermore, where a pre-acquisition declaration has been issued to an owner and the acquisition does not eventually proceed, clause 96 of the Bill provides for the owner to claim and be paid compensation for any loss suffered as a result of the Commonwealth's activities. Where an owner claims compensation as a result of the Commonwealth's temporary entry, occupation and/or abandonment of an acquisition, initiative rests with the claimant. There is to be a new requirement at clause 96 limiting the claim period to three years. The Bill requires at clause 103 that once the claim is lodged the Commonwealth is to decide within 2 months on whether the claim will be accepted and what compensation will be paid.

Many of the new provisions which have been written into this legislation relate to the process involved where a compulsory acquisition takes place and compensation is to be paid. Under clause 41 of the Bill compulsory acquisitions are to be authorised by the Minister rather than by the Governor-General as is the current requirement.

The present Act provides only limited guidance for the determination of the question of compensation although practices in use have been developed in line with case law over the years. This Bill adopts in clauses 54 to 63 a detailed statutory list to provide guidance to all parties and the Federal Court as to the basis of compensation. The Bill retains the existing provision that compensation should be based on a market value of the land which includes by judicial interpretation any special value to the owner. However, the Bill provides that the compensation entitlements will be expanded to provide for: disturbance including loss or damage incurred as a reasonable consequence of the acquisition. Clause 55 says that such costs should at all times be reasonable having regard to market rates and should also be directly related to the acquisition; clause 59 says that compensation is to be assessed on the basis that any zoning restrictions for a public use are to be ignored provided that a claimant who bought the property in the knowledge of any restriction would not be entitled to compensation on a `without restriction' basis; where a person's principal place of residence is acquired clause 61 stipulates that there will be provision for a householder's solatium to compensate for the intangible and unquantifiable losses suffered by the owner. A fixed statutory payment of $10,000 is to be provided and that amount will be increased annually in line with the consumer price index; where a person's principal place of residence is acquired and the compensation payable (including compensation for disturbance but excluding any solatium payment) is insufficient to acquire replacement housing clause 61 says that compensation is to be increased to enable the acquisition of a reasonable equivalent; clause 58 says that optional compensation shall be paid on the basis of cost of the equivalent reinstatement where land is used for a purpose for which there is no general demand or market and use will continue on other land, e.g. schools and churches; clause 55 provides that the reasonable expectation of an owner of any renewal of leases or licences etc. if the acquisition had not occurred will also be included in the assessment.

The Bill also provides at clause 60 that any increase or decrease in the value of a property due to the proposed work by the Commonwealth is to be disregarded in assessing compensation. Additionally new provisions will clarify in clause 60 that: where a site can only be developed by a government body the special suitability of that site is to be disregarded in compensation; any increase in the value of the property due to unlawful use is to be disregarded, and any increase in value due to improvements carried out without the Minister's approval after service of a declaration is to be disregarded.

The Bill provides that the present system should be retained whereby properties acquired using the compulsory process are acquired by publication of a notice in the Gazette of the acquisition. However, in order to facilitate claims by interested persons the Bill requires at clause 41 that a notice should also be published in a local newspaper indicating that the acquisition has occurred.

The Bill clearly indicates the procedure that must apply whereby the owner can claim compensation. Once the property has been acquired the Bill requires in clause 48 that the Commonwealth will notify the former owner of the acquisition and advise him that he appears to be entitled to compensation. In clause 67 the owner is requested to prepare a claim on an approved form for submission to the Commonwealth. After the Commonwealth receives the claim from the former owner the Commonwealth then has a limited period of 42 days in which to make an offer to the former owner and disclose the basis of the calculation of the offer. Clause 75 says that the claimant may then respond either accepting the Commonwealth's offer or submitting full details of the basis on which his claim is calculated. Once the owner has made his revised claim clause 76 says that the Minister must make a final offer within 2 months.

Where the owner and the Commonwealth cannot reach agreement on the amount of compensation that needs to be paid the Bill provides for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review the Minister's decision on the amount of compensation. These provisions apply not only in clause 81 to compensation following compulsory acquisition but also in clause 107 in relation to compensation for temporary entry and occupation of land and abandonment of acquisition proposals. The Bill provides in clauses 81 and 107 that both parties would be bound by the Tribunal's decision on how much compensation should be paid.

It should be noted that in this Bill in clause 131 in cases where an owner applies to the Tribunal for review of a decision to acquire or a reasonable application to review the quantum of compensation, the Tribunal is able to recommend to the Attorney-General that the costs of the appeal should be met by the Commonwealth.

It is possible that negotiations on the amount of compensation to be paid and ultimate review of the quantum of compensation by the Tribunal may take some time. The Bill contains provisions which are aimed at minimising the difficulties faced by an owner. For example the Bill contains at clause 47 a provision whereby the owner is allowed to remain in occupation for 6 months where the Commonwealth has no immediate need of the property either on agreed terms or on terms decided by the Minister. Furthermore clauses 85 and 110 of the Bill provide that where the Minister has accepted a claim and made an offer of compensation but the offer is not accepted by the claimant the Commonwealth shall make an immediate payment of 90% of the Commonwealth's offer. When agreement is reached on the amount of compensation to be paid, clauses 91, 92 and 115 provide that interest will be paid on the balance of the amount compounded at 3 monthly rests from the time of the acquisition or in relation to clause 115 from the time the claimant lodged the claim.
There are many other matters covered and provided for within this Bill. One which is of particular significance relates to the acquisition of land in public parks.

The current legislation does not allow the Commonwealth to acquire land which is in a public park. The Australian Law Reform Commission accepted that this was an unreasonable constraint particularly in instances where an intended acquisition may not be controversial but may nevertheless be necessary for the Government's purposes.

It is not uncommon for the Government to need a facility such as a navigation beacon or a communications tower in a location within a park. At the present to acquire such a property, no matter how small, the State government has to excise the land in question from the park to enable the Commonwealth to acquire the land. However, whilst recognising that the Commonwealth should be able to acquire land in public parks it is also essential that safeguards be provided within the legislation to ensure that this power is used properly.

For this reason in clause 42 the Bill requires that where the Commonwealth wishes to acquire land in a public park the following conditions must be met. Firstly, the relevant State must agree to the acquisition. Secondly, there must be a full inquiry under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 except that both Houses of Parliament may veto the need for a full inquiry. Where that happens the requirements of the Environment Protection Act must still be met with a further stipulation that where the property to be acquired is part of a world heritage property or a property on the national estate then a full environmental impact statement must be prepared. Finally, once the acquisition has occurred clause 46 provides that either House of parliament will have a veto power whereby the acquisition can be made null and void.

This process will enable non-controversial acquisitions by the Commonwealth of land in public parks to be achieved expeditiously whilst at the same time sufficient safeguards are provided to ensure that those acquisition powers are not abused. The process provides protection of the States' rights and ensures that environmental and heritage issues are adequately addressed.

Clause 124 of the Bill provides for regulations to be made to prescribe the conditions for exploration and mining on Commonwealth land. The Government's policy for access to Commonwealth land for exploration and mining does not apply to national parks or Antarctica.

The existing Lands Acquisition Act allows for mining and exploration on Commonwealth land to be controlled by the State using State legislation but subject to any conditions the Commonwealth may wish to apply. However, access to Commonwealth land for mineral exploration and development has been constrained by the lack of a co-ordinated policy and the lack of clearly defined administrative procedures. It is not clear to mining companies what the Commonwealth requirements might be and it is considered that this lack of communication discourages mining companies from pursuing mining activities on Commonwealth land.

The Government considers there is scope to implement a multiple land use policy through developing procedures which could allow exploration and mining on Commonwealth land, subject to conditions which protect the Commonwealth's interests in the land such as environmental, heritage and socio-economic factors as well as its specific use of the land.
The Government has accepted a set of policy principles which it believes should apply in order that a multiple land use policy may be facilitated.

Mineral exploration and development on Commonwealth land will be allowed to proceed where these activities do not preclude the purpose for which the land is designated, and where they comply with all relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory laws and policies.

When the Commonwealth proposes to acquire land or change the use of an existing area of land, the resource potential of the area will be taken into account as part of the Commonwealth's general assessment of the area's suitability for the proposed use.
The Commonwealth will acquire mineral rights only where the principal purpose for acquisition precludes mineral development.
Where the Commonwealth disposes of land on which it holds the mineral rights, the Commonwealth will normally dispose of the mineral rights to the States and Territories.

This Bill provides for the making of regulations prescribing the conditions for exploration and mining on Commonwealth land. The regulations may also make provision for the making of arrangements between the Commonwealth and a State or Territory for the officers of a State or Territory to administer the granting of mineral exploration and mining licences over Commonwealth land. It is envisaged that the regulations made under the Bill will contain provisions similar to those of relevant State or Territory mining laws. However for the first time mining companies will know what the Commonwealth's requirements are regarding access to Commonwealth land for mining purposes.

All proposals to explore or mine on Commonwealth land administered under the Lands Acquisition Act will be examined for the effect they will have on the environment in accordance with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, where applicable. Also, all proposals must be approved by the Federal Minister responsible for the Lands Acquisition Act.

This changed approach by the Commonwealth to mining and exploration on Commonwealth land has caused some concern amongst the mining industry. However the Government is convinced that the mining industry will find the new approach to be a great improvement over the present ad hoc approach. That will become apparent when the mining regulations are provided for parliamentary scrutiny.

Furthermore, this new legislation is not going to be held back from commencement by a need for those mining regulations to be drafted. It is the Government's intention that the new Act should commence as soon as possible. The Bill provides in subclause 124 (8) that until such time as the mining regulations are available and take effect the arrangements under the current Act will continue to apply.

I have identified here what the Government believes to be the main provisions in the new legislation which depart from the requirements of the current legislation. The Government believes that the Commonwealth needs to update its approach to the acquisition of land and in particular to protect the concerns and interests of the property owners whose property is acquired by the Commonwealth.

This Bill achieves all this. It provides a balance between the protection of the rights of individuals and the ability for the Government to meet its property needs. It offers to property owners the ability to question the Government's decision to acquire their property. It clearly specifies the wide range of factors to be taken into account in assessing compensation. At the same time it also provides an efficient process that the Government can use when it is dealing in a normal commercial market situation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present a report on a reference not disposed of by the Standing Committee during the Thirty-Fourth Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When the Senate passed the motion establishing the legislative and general purpose standing committees on 22 September last year, several matters which had been referred to the former Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, and which had not been disposed of before the dissolution of the Thirty-Fourth Parliament, were referred to the new Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I presented a report on three of those references on 19 November last year. One remaining reference was the Australian Army's rapid deployment capability, given to the Committee on 26 March 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Our predecessor Committee held an in-camera hearing on the reference, and undertook several inspections in connection with it during 1985. Since that time, the Government has received the report of the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, by Mr Paul Dibb in March 1986, and the Government in turn presented a White Paper, entitled The Defence of Australia, in March 1987. Both reports deal with the Australian Army's rapid deployment capability.

The Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has taken note of these reports and in view of the other commitments that are currently before it, in particular, finalising an inquiry into contingency planning, for nuclear-armed and/or powered warship visits, and a new inquiry which it has just begun into Australia-India relations, it has decided to take no further action on the matter referred to its predecessor Committee in March 1985.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Chapman:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Knowles:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish very briefly to make a couple of comments about this paper. Although it has been on the Notice Paper for some time, it was a very long time in coming to the Senate. The figures that are given in this report are current only to 30 June last year which makes it a very old document indeed before that information is available to the Parliament. I think that is quite unacceptable. Certainly, it is not new for us to find that the reporting of VIP flights has taken so long to come before the Parliament. In studies that I have made of the subject, members of the current Government were complaining about something similar years ago. It may simply be a case of a lot of paper work to be got ready with not a great deal of priority in the Department of Defence. Nevertheless, the Parliament should not be given material which is so old that it is almost useless, especially when we consider that we are talking about the expenditure of at least $6m in any one year.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that the Government has plans to change the VIP fleet this year into a leasing arrangement. I find that an acceptable option. However, I am concerned at a couple of matters which came to my notice when looking at this paper. One is what I believe to be the excessive use by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of the VIP fleet. It would appear to anybody reading this report that the Treasurer uses this fleet virtually as his private taxi, particularly between Sydney and Canberra. But I question whether the guidelines which have been laid down now for many years are being observed as strictly by this Government as they have been by previous governments. There have been questions and answers on the subject of the guidelines in this Parliament for a number of years. I draw to the attention of the Senate a question that Senator Walsh asked on notice of the then Minister for Defence on 5 May 1981. He got a detailed answer from Senator Durack about the guidelines laid down for the use of these aircraft. I would very much like to know whether there has been a change of those guidelines since 1981. If there has not, I suspect, from any fair reading of the paper, that they are being observed in the breach rather than to the contrary.

I also wish to draw attention to the fact that, during the last election campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) saw fit to use the National President of the Returned Services League (RSL), Sir William Keys, on an election tour to far north Queensland during which he gave interviews on the respective merits of the Government's policies and the Opposition's policies. I find that a most unacceptable use of the VIP fleet. I conveyed my feelings on this matter to Sir William Keys at the time but I now question publicly the Government's use of the aircraft in facilitating heads of lobby groups-which, of course, the RSL is, and a very effective one too-to take part in an election campaign for the Government's benefit. I am quite sure that that cannot be within the terms of the guidelines and the Government stands condemned for using the aircraft in that manner.

I certainly would like to see these records coming before the Parliament much more speedily and I would like details of the costs of each flight. I know that they have been asked for before, but they still have not been provided. The excuse has always been that it is a difficult matter. I do not accept that as being a satisfactory answer because these days, with computerisation throughout the Defence Force, and the fact that those costs have to be calculated for budgetary purposes, I do not believe that it is beyond the ability of the Government to provide that information to the Parliament when it is providing the details of the flights. I hope that that will be improved upon in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Hill:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Jenkins:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications (COPQ) was established in June 1984 following the Government's acceptance of the recommendations of the report of the Fry Committee of Inquiry into the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications in Australia. The aim of this Council, which replaced the previous Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications, was to develop and improve procedures for assessing overseas professional, technical and general academic qualifications. The council was also given the responsibility to follow up the Fry report recommendations, other than the findings of Fry relating to recognition procedures in the trades area. As this report also is late appearing. It is sad that it has taken a while for us to read that during the year 1986-87 the council made a review of progress as far as the Fry report recommendations are concerned and concluded that there was a need to reassess priorities and directions for further development of the Council's operations. The Council decided to embody its findings in a four-year plan, 1987 to 1991, to maintain the thrust of the Fry report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that the Senate appreciate the goals of the Council. The Council set its priority tasks as the amendment of the Migration Act to define the Minister's powers in relation to overseas qualifications, and of course one of the findings of the recently published report of the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies is that the Migration Act itself should be amended. Another priority is the further development of non-discriminatory recognition and assessment procedures and the provision of improved information and advice on qualifications for prospective immigrants overseas. One of the functions of the Council is to conduct examinations for people holding qualifications that are not immediately acceptable to registration and recognition authorities. In fact, during this year the assessment by examinations was carried out in the areas of dentistry, dietetics, engineering, medicine, nursing, occupational therapy, pharmacy, physiotherapy, podiatry and veterinary science.

One of the achievements of the Council that I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate is its establishment of pilot bridging courses for overseas qualified professionals. It was recognised some time ago that a bridging program was very necessary if people were to have their qualifications recognised in this country. Some interesting figures are included in the report, but I only have time to draw the attention of the Senate to a few of them. In 1986-87 the largest number of non-approved qualifications in computing came from countries listed on page 20 of the report. Of that number the highest proportion was 83.3 per cent of applicants from Sri Lanka and the lowest proportion cited in this group was 34.6 per cent from Hong Kong. It is interesting that of those who applied to have their computing qualifications registered, 37.8 per cent of those from the United Kingdom were not recognised and 50 per cent of those from the United States of America were not recognised. Those figures are revealing and I suggest that there should be further investigation into that particular area.

It is interesting also to note who are the clients of COPQ. Of the 113,000 people who received visas to enter Australia during the 1986-87 year, about 20,000 were identified as having professional, sub-professional, technical or trade skills, but half of COPQ's clients are already resident in Australia. Those people are migrants who were not selected on the basis of their skills or qualifications, but have arrived as family members, refugees or under special humanitarian provisions. The rest of COPQ's clients are prospective migrants and those requests are referred to COPQ through overseas posts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council Report

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Coulter:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be advisable and appropriate to deal with this particular paper today, concerning medical research. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is meeting today and tomorrow and reports have come out that a great deal of concern is being expressed about the amount of funds available for medical research in Australia. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), according to the news media, was confronted with some anger at cuts in money for the Commonwealth funded NHMRC. I think it is appropriate that we look at the situation and set down some facts. In 1988 there were 952 applications for project grant support, of which 304 were funded. A further 289 received the scientific rating, which placed them in a `highly recommended funding' category, but they could not be provided with support from the available funds. In other words, there were almost 300 applications which passed all the tests and presumably all the assessors' reports but which could not be funded. The reason given was that funds were not available, but that is only one of the reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The NHMRC should have a look at where it is sending its funds. I have raised this matter in this chamber before. Over a period of six years an amount of $450,000 in NHMRC grants was applied to a project which dealt with the dioethical issues in the use of foetal tissue and human gametes and embryos. I have mentioned before in this chamber the concern that is fairly broadly expressed that these amounts largely have gone to Professor Singer and Dr Cusa. Professor Singer, of course, has often published his view that the human embryo, the human foetus and indeed the newborn child have no inherent right to exist and specifically that a human embryo is of no more inherent worth than a lettuce. I think it is also of concern to those scientists who have not been able to receive funding although their projects have been regarded as being worth while. It is also interesting to note that very substantial amounts of funding have been given in this area, in what essentially is not an area of medical research. It is being applied in a polemical debate to prevent legislation being introduced and supported to cover these most important issues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Boswell:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an annual report for the year 1986-87 and is therefore already somewhat out of date. The report notes that the future for Christmas Island and Christmas Islanders is uncertain. There was an unexpected and rapid winding down of the phosphate mining company, but after that many unemployed people stayed on the island in expectation of tourism development. To date there has been virtually no such development. In fact, all that we have had introduced into this place is an ordinance for a casino to be built on Christmas Island. There are varied views on this, and no doubt the matter will be debated fully at a later time. I am sure that everyone is in agreement that the fragility of the environment of Christmas Island must be taken into consideration, whatever its future is to be.

SPEECH.PARA: What is to be regretted, and it is mentioned in the report on page 54, is that the democratically elected Christmas Island Assembly was dissolved on 28 October 1987. Although the island and its population are small, it had a very successful form of self-government. It had an Assembly of nine members, elected by proportional representation under a Senate-style electoral system. If honourable senators care to look at page 32 of the report, they will see that the names of the nine Assembly members reflect the multicultural aspect of that community. When it existed, the Assembly was very responsible, and this was reflected in its actions. It was certainly concerned with the long term good of the island and its environment. For example, I cite the recommendation of the Assembly to preserve the forest habitat of the Christmas Island frigatebird.

The Assembly took a strong stand against the phosphate mining corporation in relation to mining of the lower western shores of Smithson Bight and considered in the land use survey of 1985 that the conservation habitats there were of international concern, with their outstanding coastal scenery and the high landscape and wildlife. In fact, as a result of the recommendations passed by the Assembly, mining of those terraces did not proceed.

I would like it to be noted by the Senate that, rather than an ordinance being introduced in this place at this time for the establishment of a casino on Christmas Island, it would be of far more use to the Christmas Islanders if they were to have their Assembly reinstated. They could then be responsible for their own affairs and continue debate, in the responsible way that they did in the past, on the issues which concern them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a previous occasion I indicated that my intention was to try to make some positive remarks about the report of the Council of the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE). Events has proceeded somewhat since the report was first presented and subsequent information has come to hand with regard to the amalgamation. Nevertheless, substantially I want to pursue those same themes and some of the points raised with me by students from the various bodies associated with the proposed amalgamation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do that, I take the opportunity to congratulate those involved with the continuing development of the CCAE. As the report indicates, it continues to be an outstandingly successful tertiary institution. I hope, and at this stage expect, that the virtues of this institution will be preserved in the development of the forthcoming amalgamated institutions. There are two particular aspects of activities I want to refer to before raising some of the students' concerns. One relates to the development of a faculty of engineering. I note with great pleasure from the report of the Council that some engineering courses are commencing and that bachelor of engineering courses have received accreditation. I look forward to the Council, with the Council of the Australian National University (ANU), taking advantage of the amalgamation to enhance the prospects of development of coherent and coordinated engineering courses at the amalgamated institution.

I also put on record my appreciation of the excellent work done by the Australian Centre for Local Government Studies at the CCAE and hope that, in the amalgamation with the ANU, that program will continue to develop and flourish. It makes a substantial contribution to the academic understanding of local government and also to the training of councillors and council staff.

The students at the CCAE, the ANU and the Canberra Institute of the Arts have raised a series of issues arising from the proposed amalgamation and it seems to me that three of those are worth referring to in the context of this Council report. The first is their continuing and reasonable concern that it should be a genuine amalgamation and not a takeover by the ANU of the other two institutions. There is continuing apprehension that that may be the case. My belief is that there is certainly no necessity for it to be the case. The indications that I have seen at the moment are that a reasonable amalgamation can still be achieved, and I expect that to be the case. I want to put on record that, although I support the retention of the name of the Australian National University for the amalgamated institution, I would be opposed to there being a takeover by the ANU of either the CCAE or the Institute of the Arts.

The students raised very reasonably-and very gratifyingly, for a group of students; it may not have been the case when I was a student at university-the desire that teaching should be explicitly mentioned as one of the functions of the new university. I regard that as an entirely positive proposal from them. As I have said, it may not have been a proposal the students of my era would have welcomed-we thought teaching was something that belonged in schools-but I think it is a very important part of a tertiary education institution.

The other point the students raised which I want to take the opportunity to reinforce and support is their need for assurances that students will be able to complete courses substantially similar to those to which they were admitted before the amalgamation and that students who change from one course to another will be given full recognition for previous studies, subject to the rules of the new courses. I think those questions of pursuit of preferences and continuity are important. The students have taken an essentially positive attitude, for which I congratulate them, and I look forward to the successful amalgamation of the three institutions.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome this year the early release of the report prior to the Estimates Committee hearings. I believe in giving credit where it is due, and Estimates Committee D is giving credit this year to the fact that the report was released prior to the Estimates Committee hearing. It has been of great use to the Committee in providing a wealth of information in a very well set out document. By contrast, the Estimates Committee documents, the explanatory memoranda, are causing great difficulties because the Department of Defence has not been able at this stage to provide criteria for performance indicators which will be of use in determining how the Defence Department is meeting its challenges.

It is a matter of some concern to me that the Department of Defence traditionally has been able to operate behind a veil of relative secrecy and that so much information is deemed to be classified. Quite often it is obvious that material which could be made available to the public and to Parliament has not been made available. I look forward to the Department reviewing, perhaps thanks to the pressure of program budgeting on the Department, the amount of material which will be available to the public in future. In the past there has even been secrecy relating to wastage. There was a hard fought battle to try to ensure that information was continually supplied on wastage rates. We now need information on training levels in the total force, on the mothballing of equipment, on the likelihood that we are producing ships that we shall not be able to crew, and the likelihood that we are buying aircraft that we shall not be able to find pilots to fly. This information has to be known to Australians if they are to make a proper assessment as to whether the Government of the day is spending the defence dollar wisely and as to how well defended we are.

I wish to refer briefly to some matters that are referred to in the report. One relates to the pilot retention bonus. It became obvious to the Estimates Committee that this was an ad hoc decision taken as a result of pressure from the Government on the Department. There was very little consultation within the Department on the matter and an old air force proposal emanating from some years back was pulled out of mothballs. The figures were not updated and no new studies were undertaken. Many millions of dollars were spent without proper thought and attention. It was a clear indication of the panic that was setting in in view of the loss of pilots. It has caused resentment among other categories of Defence Force personnel, who are also in short supply and who feel neglected and not appreciated.

I am glad, however, to see that the Royal Australian Air Force acknowledges in the report that it is undertaking studies to try to maintain personnel numbers. The writing has been on the wall for a long time, and by now I would have expected studies to have been completed and action taken. I hope that the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into wastage rates, which will be tabled in the Parliament shortly, will give the Government and the Services the information they need on which to base considered action. I have great confidence in Mr Cross and his subcommittee and trust that he will be able to provide useful recommendations which, this time, the Government should accept, compared with his last report into the management of the Defence Department which was rejected by the Government-rejected at its peril because so many of the report's recommendations have a major impact not just on the efficiency of the Department but also on the morale of its employees. I trust that the Joint Committee report will bear out the speeches and submissions I have been making. I also would have liked to have dealt with Mr Cooksey's recommendations in respect of rationalisation of the defence facilities. His recommendations will require to be dealt with by the Government shortly.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In relation to the annual report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) I wish to concentrate on the area of privacy. The annual report contains several statements which certainly have not been carried out religiously by the interviewers of the Bureau during the present household expenditure survey. On page 15 of the ABS annual report we see the following statement:
Except by prior arrangement, they-
that is, the interviewers-
do not make calls before 9.00 a.m. or after 8.00 p.m. or on Sundays.

That is not true. Indeed, interviewers have been calling on people after 8 p.m., and many of the households called on have reported to me that interviewers have called quite late. It is essential that the Bureau should choose interviewers who are willing to abide by its rules and regulations. Elderly people are being called on at 8.30 at night. I believe that 8 o'clock is too late for elderly people to be expected to open the door to strangers. I think that the Bureau should look into this area and ensure that its interviewers abide by the rules. On page 16 of the report one sees the following statement:
A person should take such steps as are, in the circumstances, reasonable to ensure that information in his possession or under his control is securely stored and is not misused.

A member of the other place, Mr Cameron, visited a friend at a party held at an interviewer's house and found, to his distress, personal responses scattered in piles all over the lounge room floor. Also recorded in the columns of Hansard is a matter raised by Mr Hawker detailing a case where a farmer had been sent information destined for another farmer because of a mistake by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I am well aware that mistakes occur, but it is ridiculous for the Bureau to claim that it is able to avoid any privacy abuse. On page 21 we come to the crux of the problem we face on the household expenditure survey:
The second question of the relationship of legal obligation to respond to statistical surveys with considerations of personal privacy is a large one.

It is certainly not a question to be resolved by statisticians, yet that is just what the Bureau has done. It has said that the survey is legal. The Bureau did not table the survey and we have several legal opinions to the effect that it should have been tabled. The statisticians wrote to the Attorney-General's Department giving information on grounds that were very selective--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on the annual report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) for 1987-88. I found it interesting to compare the present report with the Bureau's report of 1986-87. The Australian Bureau of Statistics was telling us in parts of that report about its plans for the future and about work in progress. Nowhere have I been able to locate in that report any reference to the current household expenditure survey except maybe a veiled suggestion on page 46 where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Significant development work was undertaken during 1986-87 on two major national surveys . . .

The Parliament would not have been alerted to the fact that a new household expenditure survey-I stress this-a new household expenditure survey, with a new name and a new title and new questions, was in the process of being prepared.

I turn to the Australian Bureau of Statistics annual report 1987-88 which is the one under discussion. I was also interested to find that 13 pages, in fact the whole of chapter 3, were devoted entirely to statistics and privacy. Going through the annual report of 1986-87 there is almost no comment and no interest taken by the Bureau in privacy as an issue. I would suggest that the interest that the Bureau has taken in putting 13 pages of this vital area of privacy and data collection by the Bureau into the report is as a result of the pressure that the Opposition has placed on the Government to make more public the way in which the current household expenditure survey was introduced and commenced. We see in the 1987-88 report on page 13 a comment:

In addition, subsection 6 (3) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 provides that each new proposal for the collection of information for statistical purposes by the ABS must be laid before both Houses of Parliament before its implementation, unless the collection of information is to be made on a voluntary basis.

I had a constituent ring me up who said that she was asked to fill out a questionnaire of something like 129 pages. It included questions like, `Have you been to the doctor in the last three months and if so how much did it cost you? How much did you get back on Medicare? How much did you get back from your private medical fund?'. She was also asked to list the number of that treatment. Anybody looking at it could know what sort of treatment she had. Some of those treatments are very personal. Those numbers clearly identify what has happened. She was also asked to fill out a diary of her expenditure for a two-week period. The example that she was given included a bunch of parsley worth 69c. The example also included tickets to a hockey match. These are examples of the sorts of things she would have to put down. She would have to put down all of her income during that two weeks and all of her expenditure.

I am sure there would be a lot of people in the Senate who would not want to put everything that they bought at a supermarket-one can buy lots of things at a supermarket nowadays-onto a form. In fact, if one lives in a rural area one may be interviewed by someone one might know. I know that the ABS tries desperately not to have someone that person knows interview them but it may happen. The ABS goes to extreme lengths to provide privacy with the census. A person can ask for an envelope, somebody can collect that envelope and they do not know what that person has written. Yet, we now have a very intrusive survey where people have to disclose details about themselves.

My complaint about the Bureau in relation to this household expenditure survey was not tabled. It was then tabled when pressure was brought to bear. I believe that one of the things that have happened as a result of that pressure is that the Bureau has had to pay more attention to the privacy aspects of its data collection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This is a privilege because I have been allowed to continue after Senator Patterson. Previously, I had made some remarks about the privacy area in the annual report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) where it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The second question of the relationship of legal obligation to respond to statistical surveys . . . is certainly not a question to be resolved by statisticians.

I pointed out that I believed that on this occasion it was the statisticians who had made this survey legal. They have done this by appealing to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for a legal opinion. The information they supplied to the Attorney-General for that opinion was selective and inaccurate. During the Senate Estimates Committee hearing Mr Skinner of the Australian Bureau of Statistics admitted that he had sent a letter to the Attorney-General's Department regarding information requiring this legal opinion, which information was inaccurate. He admitted that the information about the methodology in the two surveys that required the opinion of the Attorney-General was indeed not accurate. He also told me that he had not sent the Attorney-General the questions from the 1974 survey and the 1988 survey so that the Attorney-General could make a decision on whether the contents of the two surveys were indeed similar or, as he cared to put it, virtually the same. He did not send the new form in the 1988 survey to the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General was left to give a legal opinion not only on false information but also on insufficient information.

When questioning officers from the Attorney-General's Department they readily admitted that they had not sought any additional information. They relied solely on the information that the Bureau of Statistics had sent them. The mind boggles that the Attorney-General's Department should make a legal opinion available, one that the Australian people are meant to find credible and are meant to understand should be an opinion of some substance. Yet, the Attorney-General did not at any stage seek the correct information. The Department was told by the ABS that the content was virtually the same. It accepted those words. It did not seek to compare the content. It was told that the form was unchanged. It did not seek to view the two different forms. It accepted those words. Those words were not true on either account. It accepted the word of the ABS that there was only one significant change in the methodology. As I say, during questioning Mr Skinner admitted that that was inaccurate. Indeed, there were two very significant changes in the methodology and he had not reported that change to the Attorney-General's Department. How the Australian people can place any reliance at all on an Attorney-General's opinion when the Department does not seek the correct information that would enable it to make such an opinion is quite beyond my imagination. As such, I will continue to press on the people of Australia that I believe that the household expenditure survey is quite voluntary. It is only if they choose to fill it in, that they should do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) annual report is an excellent report on an industry that is booming in Australia, one that brings in something like $6 billion in overseas earnings. Ninety-seven per cent of our wool is exported. I draw the Senate's attention to one aspect of the report. On page 32 the Corporation states:

A change in the tariff status of imported lightweight fabrics in early 1988 will also adversely affect consumption of some wool fabrics. Wool fabrics up to a weight of 130 grams a square metre, which had previously been subject to a 2% duty, now attract the full 40% duty.
That rate has now been reduced to 35 per cent. The report goes on to say:
Cotton and synthetic lightweight fabrics were retained within the 2% by-law. The AWC is making representation to the Federal Government seeking to remove this discrimination against wool.

I believe Senator Button has asked the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to convene a meeting of the major interested parties to discuss this matter. I would like to make the Senate aware of some investigations I have made on behalf of quite a few of the manufacturing companies which have approached me about this matter. They were concerned that after spending so much money on promotion, both here and overseas-out of a total budget of $300m, $179m was spent on wool promotion and it took five years to convince small manufacturers in Australia to use lightweight woollen cloth-the Government, in the harmonising of tariffs, should increase the duty from 2 per cent to 40 per cent, while leaving the tariff on cotton and synthetics at 2 per cent. There are quite a few small manufacturing companies in Australia which are using lightweight wool. They have to import it because of the quality of cloth they require. There are one or two local producers but, obviously, in the select area of garment manufacture there needs to be a wide selection of fabrics for those companies to compete in the reasonably small market.

I took the trouble to put out a questionnaire. Of the 100-odd companies which replied about half were not affected. Of the 40 or so businesses that were affected 90 per cent indicated that the tariff increases had affected them in a very serious way. The concern I had, as a former woolgrower, was that 75 per cent of them were contemplating using synthetic fibres to a greater degree and 22 per cent were totally replacing woollen cloth with synthetics. No wonder the Wool Corporation noted this in its report. Australia produces the best wool in the world. We are encouraging local manufacturers to use it so that people here can have the benefit of this wonderful fabric. The Government is putting a duty on the cloth which will put small manufacturers out of business. Twenty per cent of the people I canvassed said that up to 80 per cent of their business had been affected. Another 50 per cent said they had suffered significant reductions in sales. Fifty per cent of the respondents said they would not be using woollen cloth next year because of the new tariff.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I consider the Australian Wool Corporation's annual report to be a good report. I congratulate the Corporation on it. It shows how much the wool industry has turned around in Australia in the last two years. There was a revival in prices in early 1986, but they have really taken off in the last 12 months. If honourable senators look at the table on page 28 of the report they will see that on 30 June 1987 the Australian Wool Corporation had on hand 381,520 bales, or 65.7 million kilograms. Exactly 12 months later it had only 1.5 million kilograms, or 9,203 bales. We are now dangerously low on stocks in Australia. Income to Australia has risen from about $3 billion last year to, as Senator Calvert pointed out, $6 billion at this stage. From what I can see it is still rising. As a result, the Australian Wool Corporation has collected more money in wool tax. In that period it has collected $17.805m. With a Government grant of $16.903m and interest of $8.4m the Corporation had a disposable income for promotion of $43m in the last financial year. So much for the good things about this report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Wool Corporation was invited to put on a fashion parade in the new Parliament House during the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in September. The Corporation accepted the invitation. Honourable senators should bear in mind that the Corporation puts on woollen garment promotions right around the country, at all the royal shows, in shearing sheds, and in other places. It had agreed to put a show on here-probably the best showplace in Australia. It would have been shown on television to the rest of the world-at least to the Commonwealth countries and, no doubt, to other countries interested in that Conference. All of a sudden the Corporation withdrew its acceptance. On inquiry to the Corporation I was given the answer that it was short of funds and that the acoustics in Parliament House were not good enough. I replied that if the acoustics were good enough in an outback shearing shed they should be good enough in this grandiose Parliament House. I also said that if the acoustics were not right there were good sound experts around the place who could have made them right. I know the acoustics were no good here when we moved to this building but they are all right now. I consider that, in negating at the last minute its undertaking to the Parliament, the Corporation let down a very important industry to Australia as well as the fashion industry, which is recognised worldwide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak to the 1987-88 annual report of the Australian Wool Corporation. It is interesting to note that in Australia's bicentennial year our wool industry has reached a new peak of importance to the nation's economy. Wool regained its position as the leading export commodity, with an export value of nearly $6 billion. That is a lot of money in anybody's language, and it draws attention to the need for income equalisation deposits. It would be good if that scheme were reintroduced as it would give people a chance to improve their financial position.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1987-88 Australia produced its largest ever wool clip of 841 million kilograms-an increase of 3.4 per cent on the clip produced in 1986-87. It is no wonder that that is so because the sheep population increased by three million to 161,800,000 as at March 1988. Not many years ago, of course, the sheep and wool industry was suffering very badly. The Government should realise how much this industry helps it with overseas credits. Japan is still Australia's largest single buyer, purchasing 20 per cent of our wool exports.

Very important matters have been brought to our attention in this annual report. The year began with the implementation of Government legislation which gave increased responsibility to the wool growing industry for the management of its affairs. The wool industry is to be complimented on the tremendous amount of advertising it has done over the past 12 months or so. Its latest promotion campaign, a copy of which I cut out of one of the newspapers recently, is headed, `Mr Cool in Wool'. Having regard to the weather we are experiencing at present, there must be many people who are glad that the Wool Board is introducing new types of woollen material. This will mean that businessmen do not always have to wear very heavy woollen clothing. I compliment the Wool Board for the action it has taken in this regard. I also compliment the firms who feature in the advertisement `Mr Cool in Wool'.

I have mentioned some of the matters in the report. It provides very worthwhile reading. The members of the Board are to be commended for the tremendous amount of work they have done in preparing the report. The directors of the Corporation--

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Coulter:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a private member's Bill, introduced by Senator Coulter, entitled the Ozone Depleting Substances Regulation Bill 1988 (No. 2). The Bill replaces an earlier Bill introduced in April this year by Senator Coulter, which he subsequently withdrew. He substituted this new piece of legislation, which is based primarily upon that April draft but it contains a number of amendments and changes to which I will refer in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time the original legislation was introduced in April 1988, I expressed on behalf of the Opposition our opposition to Senator Coulter's Bill for a number of reasons. I gave those reasons as follows: firstly, we had problems with the proclamation clauses of the April legislation, which we believed could unnecessarily delay the introduction of legislation related to the protection of the ozone layer. Secondly, I expressed concern about the setting of an 85 per cent recycling requirement without what I regard as adequate calculation of the costs or the degree to which the Swiss technology from Unifoam AG, Glarus, would be available to manufacturers in Australia and elsewhere, and the extent to which a target figure in a piece of legislation may have been dependent upon a piece of overseas technology which may not have been generally available for patent reasons and for a number of other economic considerations.

Thirdly, I believe that the way in which the Bill was presented failed to recognise the progress already being made by aerosol manufacturers under various voluntary arrangements which have been entered into in this country and elsewhere. Fourthly, I had some problems with the proposed system of inspectors, including the level of penalties, particularly those to be imposed on persons. Fifthly, I had some concerns with the question of the absolute export prohibitions which were contained in the April legislation. Finally, I had some concerns about the application of locus standi to virtually anybody defined as an interested person.

The Bill currently before us, which was reintroduced and read a first time on 12 October, made a number of changes to the April Bill. The first of those changes was that the proclamation date was given a fixed establishment-that is, the Bill was to come into effect on a specified day, namely, the first day of January 1989, rather than on a date to be fixed by proclamation. The second major change to the Bill was that it extended the category of examinable documents to include books and documents related to `the manufacture' of ozone depleting substances. Thirdly, the definition of the word `sell' was extended to cover leasing or rent arrangements. That was a suggestion which I think Senator Coulter picked up following representations which were made to him by the environmental law section of the Law Institute of Victoria.

Next, the prohibition of ozone depleting substance-containing products has been extended to importation. This would have the effect of preventing the importation, for personal use or as promotional giveaways-for example, aerosol cosmetics-of products which might otherwise still have been able to be imported into Australia under the terms of the April legislation. Former clause 11 (2) was deleted so as to prevent the export or import of non-conforming equipment, the manufacture of which was complete before the expiration of the period of grace, it being felt by Senator Coulter that the Bill should prevent what he called `offloading', perhaps to Third World countries, of equipment which did not conform with the requirements of the Bill, on the basis that those items ought to be safely scrapped in Australia under what he believed would be the stringent provisions in place here.

Finally, a new clause was inserted which absolutely prohibited the export of ozone depleting substances after the period of grace had expired. Senator Coulter claimed that that provision is necessary as manufacturers of ozone depleting substances in Australia, who are faced with substantially decreased demand as a consequence of recycling, may seek to maintain production by selling ozone depleting substances offshore. I think that those are the primary changes which have taken place in the legislation between the April draft and the October draft which is now before us. I, nevertheless, still maintain a number of specific objections to this piece of legislation. For that reason, the Opposition parties will not be supporting the legislation if the question is put to a vote.

I will detail some of those specific objections. As I said, the first is the question of the establishment in the legislation of a target figure, that is, an 85 per cent figure by volume which is specified in clause 7 (1) of the Bill. That clause reads as follows:

After the expiration of the period of grace, a corporation shall not use an ozone depleting substance in, or in connection with, the manufacture of any product or material, or for any other purpose, unless such of the processes of the manufacture of the product or material, or such of the processes in which the ozone depleting substance is used in or in connection with that purpose, are carried out in such a manner that, upon the completion of those processes, not less than 85 percentum, by volume, of the ozone depleting substance is collected and stored so as not to be released into the atmosphere.

I believe that the insertion of that clause in this legislation is unreasonable because, as I said in my earlier remarks, I do not have any evidence before me that that technology is widely and cheaply available in a way which would not interfere with the patents held by the Swiss originators of the particular process to which Senator Coulter has referred in his own speeches on this matter.

Secondly, I refer to the absolute prohibitions which are contained in clause 11 of this Bill which provides that, after the expiration of a certain period the exportation from or the importation into Australia is absolutely prohibited where we may be dealing with what clause 11 (1) (b) of the Bill describes as:
. . . an aerosol product in respect of which the dispersion medium is, either alone or in conjunction with another substance or other substances, an ozone depleting substance.
