I shall come back to that in a moment because the primary test upon which this Bill fails to attract the Opposition's support is the question of the use of ozone depleting substances in pharmaceutical products.

I also make clear that we do not believe in the mechanism provided for the issuing of injunctions under this Bill. The Bill provides in clause 13 that the Federal Court may, on the application of the Attorney-General:
or an interested person, grant an injunction restraining a corporation from doing an act . . .
It is then described in the Bill. Subclause 3 of clause 13 defines `interested person' in these terms:

``interested person'' means an organisation or association of persons, whether incorporated or not, the objects or purposes of which include, and the activities of which relate to, the protection or conservation of the atmosphere or of the Australian environment.

Frankly, that means any person in Australia. So, any person in Australia who is part of what is described as an organisation or association of persons which claims that it is in the business of protecting the Australian environment may take action under this legislation in the Federal Court of Australia to seek injunctions to restrain corporations from doing certain things. I believe that that is simply an unreasonable test. I believe that, if it had been limited to the sort of fiat of the Attorney-General which is more normal in these matters, that would have been a supportable proposition. To say simply that anybody who is a member of any organisation which makes a claim, no matter how spurious or not, that it is involved in the protection or conservation of the atmosphere or of the environment, is a person capable of seeking an injunction under this Act is, I think, unwarranted.

Finally, we come to the whole raft of enforcement mechanisms which are provided in this Bill from clause 15 through to clause 18. This provides that warrants may be issued in certain circumstances and that people may go traipsing around other people's property. For example, clause 17 subclause (2) provides:

A warrant authorises the authorised person to enter the premises: (a) with such assistance, and by such force, as in necessary and reasonable; and (b) during such hours as the warrant specifies or, if the warrant so specifies, at any time.

Here we have a regime established in which there will be authorised inspectors who have identity cards, who will be able to get warrants which will allow them to enter premises with such assistance and by such force as is necessary and reasonable. What does this mean? What are we coming to when we get a situation in which, once again, we have a whole series of pieces of legislation which allow all sorts of entry with force, entry at any time and warrants being given to various people. For example, the Secretary to the department, under this legislation, may by an instrument in writing appoint a person to be an authorised person for the purpose of this Act. We have had this debate on a number of occasions before. Senator Richardson has rightly drawn attention to the fact that there are a large number of pieces of legislation such as egg marketing legislation, primary industry legislation and all sorts of enactments--

TALK.START.PARA: —Banana growers.

—Banana growers, whatever it happens to be-which allow all sorts of officials to get warrants or to get passes to go traipsing over property, to enter by force and do all those sorts of things. I think at some stage there really genuinely needs to be a line drawn across the bottom of the page on these sorts of things. I think it is continually unreasonable to have mechanisms put in place, for the purposes of protecting the environment or whatever it happens to be, by which all of these authorities are issued. All of these warrants are there to be issued. Whilst the rights of individual citizens certainly have to be weighed against other public policy consideration, I believe that those rights are treated by this piece of legislation in a fashion which, frankly, I find somewhat cavalier.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I focus specifically upon the primary issue by which I have judged this piece of legislation to be defective. I refer to the failure in the legislation to make a reasonable exception for the continued use and production of pharmaceutical and medicinal products which use ozone depleting substances.

I wish to refer to the pioneering piece of legislation already on the statute books in Australia, that is, the Tasmanian legislation entitled the Chlorofluorocarbons and other Ozone Depleting Substances Control Bill 1987. That was introduced in Tasmania by the Liberal Government and indeed is a pioneering piece of legislation as far as the protection of the ozone layer is concerned. Clause 4 subclause (1) (a) provides the following:

For the purposes of protecting the health and welfare of the community and protecting the environment, the Director shall (a) ensure that the use of controlled substances as propellants in aerosols be eliminated except where used in medical or emergency situations where alternative substances are not available;

If we look at the second reading speech of the Minister in Tasmania, Mr Hodgman, we will see that he quite clearly indicates that there are a number of products and a number of instances where for proper medicinal and pharmacological reasons that sort of an exemption ought to be available. I believe that that is necessary in any piece of legislation. I indicate to Senator Richardson, who I understand will be bringing forward a piece of legislation in the course of next week, that one of the tests which will be applied by the Opposition in determining its opinion on that legislation-which I can say we would generally be very anxious to support-is that it should contain within its framework proper provisions for exemptions in the case of pharmaceutical and medicinal products. I gather from the indications the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, is giving that in fact that will be the case. As I say, that will certainly help us to reach the position, which I hope we will be able to reach, of giving the legislation support and speedy passage.

Of course Senator Coulter addressed this matter in some detail when presenting his second reading speech at the time of the introduction of this new piece of legislation. He indicates, under the heading `Pharmaceutical uses of CFCs', that he is aware of the particular problem. He says:
Australians currently release about 170 tonnes of CFC12 into the atmosphere each year from this source-
he is talking about pharmaceutical products-
and Glaxo-
a pharmaceutical company-

state they expect this amount to rise and plateau at about 260 tonnes. The health costs of this release must be weighed against the health benefits. Increasing UV, consequent on ozone depletion, causes increases in skin cancer and other diseases. In 1982 there were approximately 3,000 cases of malignant melanoma diagnosed in Australia. About 15 per cent or 450 patients had survival times of less than 5 years. Malignant melanoma is the fifth most common cancer in men and the third most common cancer in women.

If one exempts this use in Australia then we must exempt this use throughout the world unless we are prepared to argue for our use and deny it to those in Third World countries. Extension of Australia's per capita pharmaceutical use to the whole world would result in a global release of 100,000 tonnes per year or one eighth of present release from all sources. I believe the health and other costs of this release would far outweigh the benefits.

That, with the greatest respect, is one of the silliest statements I have ever come across. One might as well say if every citizen of China drank as much beer as every citizen in Australia, the world would be so awash in alcohol that it would be reasonable grounds for banning its production in Australia. I have actually seen such an extrapolation in one of Senator Coulter's earlier statements: that if every person in China used as much deodorant as every person in Australia, we would be in real strife. That is probably quite true, but the actual prospect of every person in China, or India or wherever it happens to be, using as much deodorant spray as every person in Australia is so remote that to make it a point of argument, a point of substance, by saying it is likely to be a reasonable statement that as a result of this there would be a global release of 100,000 tonnes per year and that would be absolutely unacceptable, just seems to me to be stretching the credulity of this Parliament even further than is normal in a large number of these debates.

I do not in any sense conceal the fact that I have a personal interest in this matter. I keep here in the chamber in my desk drawer my own metered aerosol device for the control of my asthmatic condition. I have little devices like this all over the place-in my car, in the office in Canberra, in the office at home and in the office in Sydney, and I carry one around with me permanently. I do not resile for a moment from saying that I am certainly not going to be voting for a piece of legislation Senator Coulter brings forward saying that these products can be banned in Australia and presumably I am going to wheeze my way into an early grave in order to satisfy him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you trying to persuade me to support the Bill?

—Senator Collins is not the only one who is likely to be attracted to that prospect just at the moment. I have studied the submission from Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd, as undoubtedly Senator Coulter and a number of others have done, and I think it makes a reasonable case that there is an absence of appropriate alternatives at this point in time. I think that the evidence put forward in an information paper prepared by Glaxo, entitled Pharmaceutical Use of Chlorofluorocarbons in Metered Dose Aerosols, makes it clear that there is no reasonable alternative available just at the moment. It is certainly true that skin cancer is one of the major health problems in Australia but, may I say, so too is asthma. Asthma is one of the largest killers in this country. It is one condition the incidence and severity of which is actually increasing. That may be largely due to certain other environmental causes. It may be due to all sorts of food colourings and additives, and air-conditioning problems, or it may be primarily, as Senator Peter Baume has indicated from the chair, the result of the wicked and evil habit of smoking. It is certainly not a matter in which one wants to have to weigh up the problems of asthma against the problems of melanoma. I do not think that is a legitimate approach to the formulation of decisions on a major matter of public policy. I am persuaded by the evidence that Glaxo put forward, that at this stage there are simply not reasonable, safe and cost-effective alternatives to the use of chlorofluorocarbons in key pharmaceuticals.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply indicate the general approach which the Opposition takes to the protection of the ozone layer. It is one of the areas where I have no doubt there exists a fundamental bipartisan approach to dealing with questions of atmospheric protection, whether it happens to be the protection of the ozone layer or combating the problems of the greenhouse effect or whatever. In the Liberal and National parties' recently released formal environment policy, we state:

In Government, the Coalition Parties will pursue with industry and the State Governments, a timetable for accelerating the implementation of the Montreal Protocol for the protection of the earth's ozone layer. Australia will also take a leading position, in international fora, in the revision of the Montreal protocol seeking stricter controls. In addition, through the research work undertaken through Australian efforts in Antarctica, further scientific investigation on the effect of the CFCs will be pursued.
Particular attention will be paid to the steps which Australia can take to ameliorate the world-wide impact of the `greenhouse effect', i.e. the warming of the earth's atmosphere.

So there is no disagreement on the part of the Opposition that this matter needs to be addressed, that the threat to the earth's ozone layer and the impact of the greenhouse effect are of some importance and need to be tackled as a matter of urgency. We made that position clear when I spoke in the debate in the Senate about chlorofluorocarbons on 19 November 1987. I spoke about it also on 17 November 1987 when I moved to take note of certain treaty papers, one of which involved Australia's ratification of the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer. I made clear in a press statement on 21 March 1988 that the new figures coming from the Centre of Atmospheric Research in Washington suggesting higher figures for the depletion of the Earth's protective ozone layer were a matter for considerable concern.

The Liberal and National parties throughout Australia have taken this matter very seriously. The Tasmanian State Government has introduced pioneering legislation, to which I have already referred. The Minister for Environment in New South Wales, the Hon. Tim Moore, has written to Senator Richardson indicating to him that it is the intention of the New South Wales State Government to introduce legislation, although of course he made it quite clear that he hoped that it would be legislation complementary to all States and jurisdictions around Australia and that a unified national strategy could be pursued. The Western Australian Liberal Opposition has given notice of its intention to introduce legislation in that State along the same lines as the Tasmanian legislation. Also, we are to have some legislation introduced next week by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I believe that will be an important piece of legislation. It will be capable-one hopes-of passing both Houses of parliament, whereas I believe that Senator Coulter's legislation is no more acceptable to the Government in its current form than it is to the Opposition. Therefore, when the Government's legislation is introduced next week we will have the opportunity to take major steps at a national level in Australia to combat this significant problem.

I do not believe that anybody should seek to minimise the importance or significance of atmospheric problems which are being recognised at the moment as profound dangers to the earth's survival. I do not believe that all the scientific evidence is entirely in place. A number of questions need to be addressed-for example, I quote from an article which appeared in newspapers on 20 April this year. It said:

Dr Paul Fraser, principal research scientist for the CSIRO in Melbourne and a member of the NASA Ozone Panel, said there had been a 2.5 per cent loss of ozone since 1979-but only 0.7 per cent of this could be blamed on CFCs.

I can refer honourable senators to articles which appeared in the Chemical and Engineering News journal in November 1987 and a number of other articles such as that which appeared on 5 August 1988 in the journal of the Institution of Engineers of Australia which indicate that the precise nature of all the causes and the complex interrelationship between the various causes leading to the depletion of the earth's ozone layer are still not well understood.

It is certainly not a matter of waiting until it is too late to do something about this problem. However, it is a matter of taking steps which are practicable and that is the bottom line in this debate, not the fact that something needs to be done now. Something does need to be done now but the question is: what can be done now that is practicable? I put it to the Senate that the piece of legislation before us from Senator Coulter is not practicable. It is on that basis, and not on the basis that we do not take the matter seriously or we do not believe that action is required, that the Opposition parties will not support this Bill. We look forward to discussions with the Government over its legislation which will be introduced next week. We hope that the Government's Bill not only will be practical but also will go as far as possible in addressing this problem in Australia. On that basis the Opposition has made its determination about this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening not only to Senator Puplick's contribution, but also to the interjections of my esteemed colleague and friend Senator Sanders. I have to say that on this occasion Senator Sanders is wrong. I do not believe that Senator Puplick's approach has been irresponsible, weak or wimpish. In fact, as far as is possible on this occasion when we are dealing with one of the most critical issues of our time-the depletion of the ozone layer-I would hope that we could get a degree of bipartisan support. The nature of Senator Coulter's Ozone Depleting Substances Regulation Bill has some merit and I am not critical of everything in it. Obviously, it contains some innovative proposals. I know that Senator Coulter's view is that we should examine his proposed legislation and look upon it as being compatible with-or if not compatible, complementary to-the legislation which I have been developing. However, the difficulty is that it is just not reasonable or appropriate for me to say here and now that that legislation is either compatible or complementary. At this point I will not pre-empt the Bill which will be introduced into the Parliament next week. I do not think that is sensible; there are still some processes through which that Bill must go.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I undertake to look at Senator Coulter's proposed legislation and consider every aspect of it. There may be some aspects which can be incorporated at a later point, particularly in regulations. I hope that Senator Coulter has the good grace to consider the legislation which I will bring in because there are some important matters in it which are not covered in Senator Coulter's legislation. My legislation will be far wider in scope and, in many cases, tougher. I have felt all along that, if we were to have legislation on this matter, it had to be able to meet with some acceptance from industry and be implemented by industry-Senator Puplick used the word `practicable'. Of course, we should not forget the role of the States. By the way, Senator Puplick referred to the Tasmanian legislation introduced by the Tasmanian Environment Minister, the Hon. Peter Hodgman. I have some queries about his deep commitment to the environmental cause. In this respect I mention two comments which Mr Hodgman made at the Australian Environment Council meeting held earlier this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one you were at or the one you were not at?

—The one I was at. Mr Hodgman said that bushfires were okay as long as they only burned bush. His other comment which I thought was pretty touching was that kangaroos would prefer to be shot, not poisoned. I pointed out that they would probably prefer neither if given the option. I know that the Tasmanian Government is desperately trying to look greener but it will have to do a bit better than that.

SPEECH.PARA: Before turning to some of the specifics of things I hope the Government can achieve with its legislation, I wish to go into the background of this matter. The global decrease in stratospheric ozone that has occurred over the past decade or so is somewhere between 2 and 3 per cent. About half of this cannot be attributed to natural causes. The small amounts of ozone gases which can be found between 20 kilometres and 50 kilometres above the earth are known as the ozone layer. I realise that those gases are playing a vital role in screening some of the ultraviolet radiation which is present in the sunlight. Some of the synthetic chemicals, specifically chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons of which we use so much these days, have led to the depletion of that layer. That depletion has crucial implications for humankind. It is not just a matter of looking at the effect on the environment, it is also the effect on all of us that counts. The most common application of CFCs that we hear about-and unfortunately I saw this referred to out of context on the Quantum program last night as if it were the be all and end all-is their use in deodorants and sprays of all kinds. Later in my speech I will give the undertaking that Senator Puplick sought in regard to exemptions for some critical uses. Other wide applications for CFCs are in refrigeration, air-conditioning and solvents.

In September 1987, after several years of negotiation, a diplomatic conference in Montreal, Canada, was arranged by the United Nations environment program and it achieved an important international accord. The Montreal protocol, as it was called, provided for early action to limit consumption of CFCs in each participating country at the 1986 level, with a reduction of 20 per cent by 1993-94 and a further 30 per cent by 1998-99. The Australian Government will certainly be going further than that. Of course, it should always be remembered that, in any event, the protocol provided for a review of those levels I think in 1990, and obviously Australia will participate in that review. As I noted in a press release of 18 September 1987, Australia supported that international initiative. It took an active part in negotiations that led up to the agreement. On 5 June this year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I in a joint statement indicated that Australia would be signing the protocol, which is due to take effect from 1 January next year.

The decision to sign the protocol I hope demonstrates the Government's commitment. We want to place the protection of the ozone layer as high as we can on the environmental agenda not just of the Government but also, hopefully, of the nation. Recent scientific discoveries as a whole-although there have been some conflicting ones-have indicated that for part of this year there have been further dramatic losses in ozone over the Antarctic. I hedged my bet there because one report I read suggests that it is less. I think this points up what Senator Puplick was saying earlier-that there is a need for more data before we make too many irreversible decisions. Nonetheless, Australia will press to ensure that the provisions of the protocol are revised in the light of what up to date scientific information, technical and otherwise, we can find.

If the review that is to be completed at the end of 1990 is to be effective it will require all nations that are participating to monitor effectively what they have done in the interim, and certainly Australia will be doing that. We have to work closely with State governments, and I have been successful in persuading some State governments not to persevere with their own legislation but to wait until legislation I am bringing in next week is on the table. I might say that it is not just a matter of looking at State Labor governments; basically all governments have been willing, except for Tasmania, to wait. I am pleased that that is the case because we need the concurrence of the States.

We also have to look at industry. Negotiations with industry are vital. I will not go over all the details of negotiations we have had with industry; I think Senator Collins will cover those negotiations in his contribution. The problem is that Senator Coulter has not consulted industry in drawing up his Bill and, unfortunately, the Bill reflects that lack of consultation. His proposals may have-indeed I suppose they have-the support of some elements of the conservation movement, but this is one occasion when we cannot proceed with the conservation movement alone. Without the States and industry we will have all sorts of problems.

On 12 July this year I announced that the Government had approved the drafting of legislation to control these substances. Since that time my Department has been proceeding with the development of those drafting instructions. They will provide Australia with legislation which will include provisions to give effect to the Montreal protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer. The legislation will include provisions to ensure that all practicable steps are taken to reduce emissions of ozone depleting substances by a series of regulations which will control their use and it will provide mechanisms for the control of the manufacture, importation and exportation of ozone depleting substances.

One of the great strengths of the approach the Government has adopted in the development of this legislation is the extensive process of consultation conducted with the manufacturing sector. After all, it is critical that the manufacturers and the importers of CFCs and halons, the group most immediately affected by the legislation, are extensively consulted and involved in the task of placing Australia at the forefront of international action. Talking to officers of my Department the day before yesterday, the checks we have done so far on what nations around the world are planning to give effect to the protocol suggest that so far Australia will be going further than any other nation currently plans to go, and we will have been able to do that with the agreement of industry. So this is not a case where we can look at industry as the bad guy. I think industry accepts that there have been problems with what it has done in the past and it is prepared to change. I want to make sure that we take industry along every step rather than place it in a position where it will find it almost impossible to comply with government decree. Agreement has been reached with industry on the question of aerosol sprays, and again I have to say that for all but limited essential purposes the use of CFCs in aerosol sprays will be stopped by industry very quickly. That process is to be concluded by the end of 1989 and in one step will reduce the national consumption of CFCs by 30 per cent.

The legislation which I will introduce in parliament very shortly will regulate dealings with ozone depleting substances by restricting their production, import and export, and by controlling applications of CFCs and halons so as to limit, as far as is practicable, their emission into the air. So far as is practicable, no one will be able to start dealing in CFCs or halons unless they were doing so during 1986. Again, if we are stopping new players from entering the game, obviously we will make sure that there are more and more restrictions. So far as is fair and practicable, consumption and production over the next five years-I emphasise five years-will be limited to 1986 levels and will be progressively wound back. Within a very few years the supply of halon gases will also be frozen at the 1986 level.

I have announced several times in the past that the Government is determined to take all reasonable steps to exceed the minimum requirements that were laid down in the protocol. In consultation with the industry we are developing further restrictions. Many of these restrictions will go further than those that are mentioned in Senator Coulter's Bill. In some cases he has not even covered the areas the Government's new legislation will cover. There are real weaknesses in Senator Coulter's Bill in regard to restrictions, which is one of the reasons why the Government at this stage is unable to support it. Senator Coulter has failed to address some of the most important areas which the Government will be regulating.

I think I said earlier that this is neither the time nor the place for me to provide the details of the Government's Bill-certainly not before it has gone to Caucus and got its approval-but in a very short time Senator Coulter will see that the Government's Bill is far wider in its scope. Hopefully that will mean that he will think again. Just to give some examples of what I think is reasonable, Senator Coulter's Bill opts for 85 per cent recycling of polystyrene containers and packaging. The Government's regulations will go further than that, and I hope Senator Coulter will take that into account. Senator Coulter wants to ban aerosols outright. Senator Puplick pointed out that there was no allowance for emergency use, or exceptional uses such as international security or even personal security, let alone medicinal uses. Clearly, in some fire extinguishers, as an example, there is still a problem with developing alternatives and the Government has to be careful to make sure that we protect ourselves from fire.

As far as medical purposes go, I can say that I used to be an asthmatic. It is some years since I have had an attack. Nonetheless, because of 25 years experience I still keep some sprays around me. I would be loath to let that security blanket go. I know Senator Collins has difficulties from time to time. I know Senator Puplick does, and so do a lot of other people in this chamber and in the other place. Let us not forget the millions of Australians who are occasionally affected. If there is no allowance for that, the Bill is clearly deficient. It would mean we are going to lay down some unrealistic restrictions. But not only are they unrealistic; they are unsafe. We have a responsibility to protect those Australians who are affected by asthma and, unfortunately, for whatever reason there is a growing number in that category and so far medical science has not been able to find a better way of managing asthma than sprays, which do involve some use of the chemicals that we are seeking to restrict.

We are going to be realistic, I hope, in dealing with those aerosols. We recognise the need for exceptions and exemptions. Therefore, I think I have given Senator Puplick the undertaking that he required. We are going to consider very carefully what allowances we need to make. We are covering both CFCs and halons. Senator Coulter is covering CFCs only. I think that is another weakness in his Bill. The Government's Bill will go further than the Montreal Protocol in regard to exports. Here again, I am not going to give the details now but I am confident that Senator Coulter will be pleasantly surprised by the legislation that the Government will bring in on this question and it will be done with the concurrence of industry. That consultation which has been going on with industry, by the way, will be an ongoing process. We are not going to stop once the Bill has gone through the Parliament. Not only do we need to look at the Montreal Protocol revision in 1990; we need, I think, to look at the progress of implementation of the Government's legislation. We need to look at whether or not we can have our own review and go further ourselves again in a few years time.

Not only do I intend to continue the consultative process that I initiated some time ago; I am going to add to it by including an environmental representative. I think a representative from the environmental movement can have a role to play. I do not believe that, after the introduction of this legislation, whatever review we are conducting for its purposes or for the purposes of the 1990 review needs to be done in secret. I think it is clear that there is time now and room for the environment movement to be involved and I am going to make sure that we do that. A specialist committee will be set up to advise me on any special pleading that may arise from people who seek exemption from the strictures of the regime which we will introduce. That means that continued industry involvement will be there to make sure that whatever pressure is being placed on industry is going to be dealt with not just by whatever opinion I might come up with but, hopefully, by expert opinion.

In looking at a whole range of detail in Senator Coulter's Bill I note that there are many things that are not covered that need to be covered and there are many areas where Senator Coulter did not go far enough. I shall just go through a couple of those areas. In looking at refrigeration equipment, Senator Coulter is requiring valves for recovery and recycling; he wants to ban the release of CFCs to the atmosphere and he requires recovery and indefinite storage of the CFC. All of those are reasonable and indeed commendable goals. I do not dispute the direction in which Senator Coulter seeks to go, but to implement those provisions immediately would place on industry an unreal burden. It cannot do so tomorrow afternoon. The Government will, hopefully, show Senator Coulter a better approach, which is to go with industry in giving a reasonable timetable for all of these commendable goals to be achieved.

To look at the opposite of what happened to me in this chamber in the last couple of days, the fines that Senator Coulter seeks to put in the Bill for non-compliance are nowhere near as high as those that I will be seeking to bring in. We are going to be tougher on industry for breaking the rules that it has had an integral part in drawing up. I appeal to Senator Coulter to consider whether it is not better to wait for the legislation that I will be introducing within the next few days. He will have an opportunity to look at it. I would like him to wait until he has done that and then, over time, hopefully we can look at implementing some of the innovation which is undoubtedly in his Bill.

The Government is not prepared to go along with his Bill. He has not had any consultation with industry in drawing it up. We worked hard at the consultation process over the best part of 12 months. The consultation process has worked and I think the honourable senator will see the results that that consultation has brought very shortly. I am not against what he is trying to do, but he is going too fast and being unreasonable. We seek not to be too quick and we always seek, as Senator Boswell would know, to be reasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Ozone Depleting Substances Regulation Bill 1988, introduced by my colleague Senator John Coulter, which I point out has been available for scrutiny since April, I would make the comment at the outset that, as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, the depletion of the earth's ozone layer is one of the major ecological crises facing all life on this planet. Others include, as has already been mentioned in the debate, the greenhouse effect, land degradation in all its manifestations, and increasing pollution of the earth's oceans and waters. All of these are significant problems in themselves, but we must remind ourselves that nothing on this planet exists in isolation. Everything is interconnected. Perhaps that is the message of the bogongs. Importantly, human beings-each and everyone of us-are responsible for the welfare of all life on this planet. Regrettably, however, there are certain and numerous activities of human beings which are responsible for bringing all life on the planet to such a serious state of global, ecological disaster that it is the responsibility of all of us, including industry, particularly those of us around the world who hold public office and therefore have the ability and the power to act, to do just that-to take responsible action which will alleviate these dangers.

SPEECH.PARA: Passage of the Bill before us today would be a highly responsible action for the Senate to take as part of Australia's contribution to resolving the global challenges which face us. Briefly, to recapitulate, this Bill imposes strict controls on the release of CFCs 11 and 12 and would enable the recycling of well over 85 per cent of these substances. Senator Coulter said in his second reading speech, `The problem relates to CFC release to the atmosphere, not the use of CFCs'. Again to quote him, `Recycling must be an important component of any strategy designed to properly address the problem of stratospheric ozone depletion'. In refrigerators, for example, when they require regassing or reach the end of their life, rather than the CFCs being released to the atmosphere, they can and should be collected, cleaned and recycled.

The Bill also requires that all new refrigeration equipment, including air-conditioners, be constructed so that ozone depleting substances are contained, can be collected, safely stored and recycled. Recycling measures for other ozone depleting substances, including industrial cleaning and degreasing solvents, are also addressed in the Bill. In addition, the Bill imposes a ban on the use of ozone depleting substances in aerosols. As more information becomes available to us because of continuing research on stratospheric ozone depletion, we are seeing that the Montreal Protocol, which represents the major concerted action at an international level on this issue so far, falls far short of what is needed. I shall mention a couple of recent occurrences.

Last month the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) called for a total world ban on the use of the chemicals which are believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield. The EPA believes that the 50 per cent reduction required by the Montreal Protocol does not go far enough. That recommendation reflects a growing consensus that the threat to the ozone layer is even more serious than was previously recognised. The call of the EPA was backed by an important American industry group representing manufacturers and users of CFCs and halons, the Alliance for a Responsible CFC Policy, the chief industry trade group in the United States representing both makers and users.

Senator Coulter's Bill has been criticised on the ground that it does not reflect the interests of the industry, and I think that we should be looking to the United States and its example when considering this Bill. The significant feature of the ozone layer depletion is the predicted and certain increase in skin cancer because of increased ultra violet radiation. With this in mind I draw the Senate's attention to a report in the Canberra Times on 21 October this year in which more evidence of ozone depletion in the Southern Hemisphere is revealed. There is interesting evidence from New Zealand where scientists discovered hard evidence on how that country is being affected by extensions of the Antarctic `ozone hole', as is it known. According to research teams, last summer ozone levels over New Zealand dropped by some 20 per cent for two days as the ozone-poor air from the Antarctic moved over that country. That is an interesting experience when it is considered that we do not even know at what point we may be subject to increased danger in that area because of the movement of ozone-depleted air.

We are aware that the Government intends to introduce its own legislation and, although that is not quite ready yet, I understand that its main purpose is to curtail production of chlorofluorocarbons. That is fine and is to be commended and supported. However, Senator Coulter's Bill points out that without strict controls over emissions of ozone depleting substances we are not addressing the immediate problem. Dupont is currently working on substituting alternatives to CFCs but these will not be available until towards the end of this century. The cost of setting up new plants to manufacture the substitutes is estimated by Dupont itself at $10 billion globally. In addition-and it is also a matter of concern-the substitutes are very potent greenhouse gases and therefore would merely exacerbate the problem of greenhouse warming. Therefore, it is absolutely crucial that action is taken to ensure recycling and control of emissions. Senator Coulter's Bill would compliment the Government's legislation. In that area of halons, which are not specifically covered in Senator Coulter's Bill, and in the area of the need for exemptions for special purposes, the Bill provides for this to occur by regulation.

This is a practicable piece of legislation. The technology exists for the processes suggested in the Bill. The technology is available and what is suggested could be done within 12 months. Senator Richardson has said that, with the introduction of the Government's legislation, over time some of Senator Coulter's initiatives may be taken up, but in this, as in our other environmental global problems, time is something that we do not have. The Democrats put forward a motion on this matter last year, which was not supported by either Government or Opposition. Senator Puplick listed a lot of speeches he had made about his concerns in regard to ozone depletion. Lists are fine, but in terms of people who are in a position to act on such issues the way in which people vote is far more important. The Australian Democrats believe that this is complementary and practicable legislation. Any exemptions, which have concerned people somewhat emotively in this debate, are covered in the legislation. The Democrats implore both the Opposition and the Government to look seriously at the legislation and to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has canvassed most of the issues that are pertinent to this debate on the Ozone Depleting Substances Regulation Bill 1988 (No. 2). Therefore, I shall not detain the Senate for my usual 30 minutes. The difficulty I face with Senator Coulter's Bill was touched on by the Minister and he said that it applied particularly to me. I am disturbed that there does not seem to have been quite enough homework put into this piece of legislation in terms of what it does not cover-matters that I know the Government's legislation will cover. Unfortunately, I feel that what the Bill does cover, at least in the short term, needs to be left out. One of the myths I grew up with when I was a boy-perhaps it was just told to me to reassure me-was that at least asthma did not kill people. That was a widely held belief when I grew up. Unfortunately, it does kill; my mother died from it. The asthma cures that were around in those days pre-aerosols were horrendous. In those days a great many asthma sufferers died from heart attacks induced by the medication they had to take. I personally would find myself in extreme difficulties if I did not have available to me the same medication as Senator Puplick, as I have just discovered, has-and that applies to a great many Australians. Hundreds of people die from this disease every year. It is unfortunate that a subject that sticks out like a sore thumb has been overlooked in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In my contribution to this debate I intend to cover one of the great deficiencies in the legislation, and that is the lack of essential consultation in the preparation of the Bill. One of the strengths of the Government's stance on this very serious issue-and, as Senator Coulter knows, I have contributed my views on a number of occasions in Senate debates-has been the extensive process of consultation that has been established with State Governments and the Northern Territory Government, as well as with industry, the conservation movement and other interested parties prior to Australia becoming a party to the Vienna convention and a signatory to the Montreal protocol. Under the guidance of the United Nations environment program, an international treaty-known as the Vienna Convention for Protection of the Ozone Layer-was concluded in 1985 and Australia became a party to the convention in September 1987. The convention established the principle that countries party to the convention would take appropriate measures to protect the ozone layer, that they would cooperate in scientific studies and exchange relevant information, and would develop protocol's specifying control actions. However, the convention did not set down specific control strategies. A protocol to the Vienna convention specifying measures to control ozone depleting substances was finalised at a conference in Montreal in September 1988.

The Government has been actively pursuing its attempts to regulate ozone depleting substances from the very beginnings of these negotiations and the Minister's Department has been involved right from the start of the international negotiations. In turn, the Commonwealth Government has been engaged in extensive negotiations with the States and with the Northern Territory. As is well known, State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory have universally supported Australia signing the protocol. All States except Tasmania have agreed that the protocol should be given effect through Commonwealth legislation. Indeed, it would be nice, as I am sure Senator Coulter would agree, to do this via international legislation rather than national legislation. The Commonwealth has been negotiating with all the States and Territories over the framing of the legislation which Senator Richardson will introduce, as he said, very shortly. It has been common ground between all the States, the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth that the various governments should frame legislation which is complementary throughout the Commonwealth.

One of the significant characteristics of this Government's period in office has been its ability when making decisions to consult extensively with relevant and interested groups. This process has ensured that decisions taken by the Government have largely enjoyed the support of the public. The process of consultation is particularly vital, given the critical nature of this issue. Protection of the ozone layer is relevant to all Australians, and indeed all citizens of the world. In May this year the Minister met with the industry representative body, the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers (AFCAM). This is a government lobby group which was formed last year and represents virtually all the manufacturers, importers and consumers of CFCs and halons. For example, its members include Dupont, Monsanto and the largest importer, Lovelock Luke, and two of the biggest manufacturers, Chemplex and Pacific Chemical Industries. AFCAM's secretariat is based in Canberra to ensure that it maintains a constant and united front on behalf of the industry before the Government. The Minister's meeting with AFCAM was clearly fruitful. Very shortly after that meeting, the major vehicle of consultation between industry and Government was formed. This is the joint Government industry working group. The industry is, of course, represented by AFCAM. This is one of the major areas where Senator Coulter's Bill falls down. There has in fact been no consultation by Senator Coulter--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—Let me tell the honourable senator that if there has been consultation with industry it is not reflected in Senator Coulter's legislation. The Government is represented by an interdepartmental working group consisting of representatives from Senator Richardson's Department, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Bureau of Meteorology, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and a variety of others. This group has been cooperatively developing action plans relating to measures to be taken by the various industry sectors to reduce emissions of these gases.

SPEECH.PARA: Since then, the industry technical groups have been developing action plans for measures to reduce emissions of ozone depleting substances in the key user industry sectors. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has been closely involved in those discussions. The action plans formulated by those groups to reduce emissions have been the subject of extensive discussions between State, Territory and Commonwealth officials, key environment groups such as the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Total Environment Centre, and consumer interest groups such as the Australian Consumers Association and the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations.

A large part of that discussion took place in a forum held in Melbourne in August. It is obvious from what I have said that the Government has put a great deal of work into the draft legislation which should be brought down next week. Senator Coulter, of course, would be aware of the forum in August that I have just referred to. Some 60 people representing all State departments, the leaders of sub-working groups from the joint industry Government working group, and representatives of key conservation and consumer groups attended it. It became obvious through those discussions that measures proposed for the majority of industry sectors clearly required progressive development over varying periods and Senator Richardson's legislation will be tailored to meet that need.

Senator Richardson intends to further develop strategies for reduction of emissions through the same consultative process after the legislation is enacted The Minister intends, for example, to maintain the Government industry working group and to enhance its expertise by the appointment of a representative of the environment movement. I have no doubt that Senator Coulter's Bill, as the Minister said, has the support of some elements of the environment movement. But that, in this problem, is not sufficient.

To effectively comply with the Montreal protocol and indeed to make any attempts whatsoever to go further, the cooperation of industry and States is absolutely essential. This Government is not about heavy handed unilateral controls. As I have said, one of its great strengths is the ability and willingness to carry out consultation with interested parties to achieve the desired result. Every one of us recognises the serious problems caused by depletion of the ozone layer. The Government is treating the problem seriously, but at the same time it has to be done realistically. This is where Senator Coulter's Bill falls down.

We are not seeking to achieve the impossible. We are, in fact, going to do all that is possible. The actions of the Government will ensure that Australia goes far beyond the requirements of the Montreal protocol and it will be at the forefront of international action on this issue. Indeed, may I say, that I believe that the Bill which the Minister will introduce shortly will become a watershed in terms of law that exists around the world in the treatment of this serious problem. I know that Senator Richardson's Bill will in fact go much further in many areas than Senator Coulter's Bill does. One of the difficulties, if I can just address the position that Senator Coulter has adopted, is that his Bill could be treated as complementary to the Government's legislation. Unfortunately-and I have examined the Bill very carefully-it cannot.The two simply do not meld together very well at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not seen the Government's Bill yet.

—Can I just advise Senator Coulter that I qualified my remarks by saying that I am confident that Senator Richardson's legislation will do this. I am aware of the major provisions that the legislation will encompass. Indeed, Senator Richardson when he addressed this chamber only half an hour ago said precisely the same thing. Perhaps Senator Coulter was not listening. As I said before, I am confident that the Government's legislation will go further than Senator Coulter's legislation in certain areas, particularly in addressing the areas that were outlined in detail by the Minister half an hour ago in relation to those areas of emissions that Senator Coulter's Bill does not even deal with.
—Like halons.

—Perhaps when Senator Coulter is in reply he can address himself to the remarks made by the Minister and me. One of the areas on which I look forward to hearing some comments from him is with regard to how millions of people who suffer from the debilitating disease of asthma-as I do-would cope if the honourable senator's legislation, as he wants it, were brought into law this afternoon and the medications that asthmatics require to maintain their life were removed.
—When I reply I will do that.

—In response to that interjection I have to make the point again that one of the disturbing aspects of Senator Coulter's legislation that concerns me is that the problem of unilaterally banning all these aerosol packs would instantly remove-and it is Senator Coulter's legislation-the ability of asthmatics to have access to those kinds of medicaments.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made this point once before and I will make it again. It is such an obvious problem. It is not a small problem. Millions of Australians suffer from this disease. Millions of Australians use aerosols. The disturbing aspect of the absolute failure of Senator Coulter's Bill to provide exceptions is disturbing in the sense that it is clear that Senator Coulter has not done the work required to produce a piece of legislation that will realistically attack this problem. Senator Richardson, I might add, touched on a number of other areas of vital importance such as the propellants that are used in certain fire extinguishers which industry at the moment can find no alternative for replacing. That simply is not good enough. I might add that it is unreasonable to proceed with legislation at this stage when we know that in one week-not one year, not in five years, not in 10 years-the Government will be introducing a major piece of legislation dealing with the same problem. I think that is probably as unrealistic as the honourable senator's legislation is itself.

To conclude, I have no doubt at all that the Australian Democrats will give careful consideration, as they do to all legislation that comes into this chamber, to the major piece of legislation that Senator Richardson will be bringing down next week. I have no doubt-I am confident of this-that if it falls short of perhaps some of the Democrats' expectations it will at least receive the Democrats' support for those sections that they would like to see implemented in law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very worrying for us all that wrong assertions are being made as far as Senator Coulter's Ozone Depleting Substances Regulation Bill 1988 (No. 2) is concerned. It has been wrongly asserted that Senator Coulter has not made provision within that Bill for people who suffer from asthma and who, therefore, need ventolin sprays or for people who suffer from other diseases and who need similar sprays. It has been wrongly asserted that there is no provision for these people within Senator Coulter's Bill. This is simply not so. There is provision within the Bill for regulations to be brought in for any exceptions that are found necessary. I suggest that Senator Puplick and Senator Collins should look again at the legislation. There is provision precisely for exceptions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to bring to the attention of the Senate that it was some 14 years ago that scientists first asked the question, `What are we going to do about chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) which we are pouring into the atmosphere?'. We have had 14 years to think about it. We have known about the depletion of the ozone layer for at least the last decade, just as we have known about the greenhouse effect and other effects that have been mentioned. The ozone layer depletion and the greenhouse effect are related. Senator Coulter's Bill offers a very specific way in which Australians can help to save the world. There is a popular misconception that ozone depletion means nothing more than having to wear a hat and apply some suntan cream but I am afraid that it means far more than that. It is not so simple for us or for the plants and animals. We do share the world with animals and plants. We will all be damaged by an increase in ultraviolet rays. So the future of Australian agriculture, as well as the future of pastoralists and graziers, will be affected. In addition, the microscopic creatures at the base of the food chain and which live in lakes, rivers and the oceans, spend at least a part of their life cycle at the surface. They are also intensely sensitive to ultraviolet radiation. If the microbes and plankton are decimated the whole food chain topples. The most frightening effect of ultraviolet radiation may be that it is mutagenic. It destroys or alters DNA, the building block of life itself. In other words, the ozone layer protects all life from genetic damage.

I will address other issues which I believe have not been addressed previously. In the early 1970s, scientists discovered that supersonic flights by aircraft such as the Concorde, releasing nitrogen oxide, would destroy part of the ozone layer. This was one of the reasons the United States of America discontinued its supersonic travel program. Of course, military supersonic flights continue. Nuclear explosions produce tonnes of nitrogen oxides. Two years of above ground testing of nuclear weapons by the Soviet Union and the United States destroyed an estimated 4 per cent of the ozone layer. The burning of the Amazon forests, a disaster in its own right, has been linked by West German scientists to massive ozone depletion.

The chemical industry was predictably outraged when Nature magazine published the scientific findings about the ozone depletion in June 1974. Fluorocarbons were a $3 billion a year industry. But within a few years of that publication, the United States, Canada, Sweden, West Germany, and Norway had introduced bans. So the chemical industry has had a fair warning and ample time. In referring again to ventolin and other sprays, we are sure that Glaxo Pty Ltd could find substitute sprays, and Senator Coulter's legislation would give it time to do that. However, Glaxo has given a simple `no' answer. We are sure that, given time, just as there are substitutes for other products in non-important areas, substitutes could be available in the pharmaceutical area.

The Bill provides a legislative framework for methods to substitute or recycle CFCs used in all aspects of the industry. Our present voluntary system of withdrawing the use of CFCs is plainly inadequate. It is too little too late. I note also from an article in the Australian Financial Review in April this year headed `Aerosol industry under pressure' that researchers at La Trobe University have found cases of some companies falsely labelling spray cans to avoid consumer backlash against the ozone depleting characteristics of CFCs.

It has been stated that Australia uses a relatively small amount of CFCs on a world scale, but it has also been noted that Australians use, per capita, more than five times the world average of CFCs. In a previous debate on this subject an honourable senator from the Liberal Party of Australia suggested this was because of our insect population. It is true that we have a large insect population. We have a large one in the chamber now and outside Parliament House. We have learnt in an expensive way that simplistic chemical solutions are not necessarily the best way to solve insect problems. There has been considerable debate in this place on agricultural and veterinary chemicals and the problems that have arisen from their use.

It is certainly clear to ordinary Australians, although it is sometimes not clear to their elected representatives, that the issues of chemical poisoning, ozone depletion, the decimation of forests, and the greenhouse effect are all linked. Some people have spoken of the Gaia hypothesis. Whether this is seen as a scientific theory or a poetic truth does not matter. We are all in this together; and by all, I mean all of us-people, animals, plants, insects, even bogong moths and the microbes of the sea. Today we are charged with the responsibility of saving ourselves from ourselves and giving the world back to future generations. I wholeheartedly commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate and to put forward some of my thoughts on the legislation that was suggested in the first instance by Senator Coulter. I will also touch briefly on the legislation the Government will be putting forward next week. I have had some briefings already on this legislation today. (Quorum formed) The Government's legislation will be more than adequate to deal with the extent of the problem. In fact, I think it will be a good deal more adequate than the legislation proposed by Senator Coulter. It covers a number of the deficiencies which have already been referred to in Senator Coulter's legislation. It is more far reaching in its scope and it also provides a much more flexible means of exempting substances which may prove to be necessary. This point has already been touched on by other speakers. I am talking, of course, about asthma sprays. I am one of the few speakers so far who are not asthmatic, but I have a four-year-old child who is. I know that her mother and I, and millions of other Australians who are affected by asthma and who need these sorts of sprays and other pharmaceuticals, are very concerned to ensure that such people are not adversely affected by the sort of legislation which is being debated today.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to touch on a number of background issues with regard to the need for this legislation. We have already heard a number of comments about the depletion of the ozone layer which in turn has meant a global warming of about 0.5 degrees centigrade over the last 100 years and has resulted in major changes in the earth's ecosystem-not simply from chlorofluorocarbon build-up but also from CO2. This in turn has resulted in the fertilising of a number of plants, which to a certain extent has ameliorated the problem.

It now appears inevitable that some global warming will take place. Future government policies may be able to slow down this process. That is certainly what this Government is working towards now. I accept that this is consistent with changes expected from the greenhouse effect. There is a build-up of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere from human activities, particularly by the burning of fossil fuels-for example, coal, oil and gas. I understand that about 3.7 million tonnes of coal would be required to service a 1,000-megawatt coal-fired power plant, which would in turn produce about nine million tonnes of CO2. So for every million people whose electricity needs are provided by a coal-fired power plant, one is talking about nine million tonnes of CO2 per annum. Incidentally, four tonnes of U308 in fly ash is also produced.

A continuation of this warming can lead to rising sea levels, changing rainfall patterns and alterations in ocean currents. So far as Australia is concerned, a number of television programs have already dealt with the issues in recent weeks as a result of a continuing education program on the part of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Government. For example, Sydney Harbour would be even more magnificent; it certainly would be about 20 per cent larger. A number of marina and tourist developments in Queensland would be under water, as would, I understand, the new Brisbane Airport, which would be a considerable waste of the community's resources. There would be major climatic changes which would have enormous impacts on the Australian economy, particularly the economy of Queensland.

There is rare international scientific agreement that the greenhouse effect is occurring and that continuation of the effect at the present rate will double the CO2 content of the atmosphere in the next 40 to 50 years. This, in turn, would mean an increase in global mean surface temperatures of between 1.5 degrees and 4.5 degrees centigrade. There is considerable disagreement, as there always is, within the scientific community about the extent of that change. A global warming of this magnitude would lead to a sea level rise of between 20 and 140 centimetres over the next 40 to 50 years.

As I indicated earlier, the result would be social and economic disruption on a major scale and associated health problems. The industrialised world has produced most of the problem because of its heavy consumption of fossil fuels. Some of the information I have seen indicates that 20 per cent of the world's population has been producing 80 per cent of the CO2 pollution and the addition of the gases which are contributing, in turn, to the greenhouse effect. In fact, the Senate committee of which I am chairman is inquiring into the environmental impact of development assistance, which in many cases has arguably been--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the consideration of General Business has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, line 9, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
``(2 (1) Section 5 of this Act shall commence on 1 July 1990.
(2) The remaining sections of this Act shall commence on 1 July 1988.''.

Clause 2 removes New Zealand from the export market development grants scheme. Although there may be reasonable grounds for the removal of New Zealand from the scheme, the Government is proceeding in a way which can impose a fairly large burden on many of our companies who are exporting into the New Zealand market. The export development group of New South Wales-the Chamber of Commerce-has made the point that, in removing New Zealand from the scheme, the Government has failed to provide for any transition period for existing commitments and no consideration as to the treatment of export earnings from New Zealand. The abrupt removal of New Zealand from the scheme will also have a ripple effect on Australian exports, particularly export ventures with other countries, because some of our Australian companies, particularly the small ones that have initially concentrated on New Zealand because of transport cost problems will find they will have less income against which to claim grants.

The way in which the Government handled this particular removal and the way in which it handled the removal of South Africa from the scheme in 1985 are worth citing. In the case of South Africa, the Government gave extraordinary consideration to the long term obligations of exporters and their commitments to the South African market. These included continued and continuing eligibility of export earning generated from that market for the purpose of implementing the export earnings test and also providing for a period subsequent to the effectiveness of the amendment, whereby the long term commitments of exporters were honoured under the scheme until such time as they had expired. In other words, provision was made for an agreement with an agent who was being paid a retainer or expenses to carry out promotional work on behalf of an Australian principal.

While there were plenty of rumours around in the export industry about the continued eligibility of New Zealand and whether it would actually remain in the scheme, the formal announcement was not made until the May statement. That meant that exporters going about their business of exporting may not have been aware that there was any prospect of their going or they certainly could not have been able to make a commitment on the basis that New Zealand was about to be taken out of the scheme, until the time of the May statement. Hopefully if the scheme was operating properly, they would have made continuing commitments to that particular market. Many exporters would have had commitments running well past the starting date envisaged in the Bill.

The sudden announcement with no consultation with the industry of the removal of this market from 1 July 1989 obviously causes financial hardship and disruption to market development plans and funding. For example, there is no provision whereby companies which have promoted mainly to New Zealand can have previous grants removed from their claim record for the purpose of calculating the effects of the export earnings test. This means that a company which may have promoted mainly to New Zealand for the past three years will have to attempt to cultivate those new markets with fourth year export earning tests of 20 per cent applied to their new claim.

Our amendment is a modest one in scope and in cost and is directed at a single item. That is to provide more time for companies to make alternative commercial arrangements with regard to their New Zealand markets. I believe that our amendment also makes sense in the context of the 1988 review of the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement. That will bring Australia and New Zealand into full free trade of goods across the Tasman on 1 July 1990. That seems to be an appropriate point with a full free trade at that stage because it would obviously be inappropriate to look at some of the support mechanisms which are contained within this particular scheme.

I hope that the Opposition has changed its mind from the statement it made earlier, particularly having listened to the fiery speeches of so many people on the Opposition side on how terrible it was to remove New Zealand. For example, I will turn to Mr Sinclair, the Opposition spokesperson. In a letter to exporters he said:
. . . that the sudden dropping of New Zealand's eligibility for grants will be ``traumatic'' for many firms . . .

He then promises, in that letter, that the Opposition is committed to the maintenance of an effective program of export assistance. One way to do that would be to support this particular amendment. I hope that, as a result of the types of speeches that its people have made in this place with regard to this item, the Opposition will be able to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Opposition will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand many of Senator Macklin's comments. The Government will not support these amendments. In conducting a review of the export market development grants scheme, many exporters in industry associations wrote to provide opinions on the proposed amendments. Apart from exporters, almost exclusively dependent on New Zealand, it was interesting to note that there was general support for the exclusion of New Zealand. That does not answer Senator Macklin's point because he was talking about exporters who are largely dependent on New Zealand. The purpose of the scheme-and this was accepted-is aimed at assisting the development of more difficult export markets. The funds saved by excluding New Zealand are better directed elsewhere. A lot of people tell me it is easier to do business in New Zealand, in terms of export market development, than it is in Perth because the costs and distances involved are not as great. I think that the fundamental point is that the maintenance of such a scheme in New Zealand is inconsistent with closer economic relations. We have to think of Australia and New Zealand as one market, not separate markets. The more we clutter the pathway to that vision of one market, with bits of legislation like this, the more difficult it becomes. The Government will not accept this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Senator Macklin's point about South Africa is concerned, the opening of markets and development of markets in South Africa in 1985 was an infinitely more difficult problem than it is opening and developing markets in New Zealand in 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition that the Government has put to what I have moved seems to be somewhat directed towards a totally different amendment. The amendment that I put does not talk about whether New Zealand should be removed; it relates to when. I also mentioned that the closer economic relations trade agreement starts full operation from 1 July 1990, which is also the date in my amendment. I agree with the points Senator Button made and I in fact made them in support of my own amendment. It would be inappropriate to continue past that time. I was seeking a longer lead time to enable the types of commercial arrangements that were made to be honoured and carried through. The suggested time frame is far too small for the commercial operations which are in place. I suggest that that extra year will go a long way to alleviating the problems that I am quite sure Senator Button, as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, has heard about and certainly the problems that exist with the people who have been trading.

SPEECH.PARA: If this is a scheme to help people export, I would have thought that when one is phasing it out, one would do so in a way that does not damage those exports. The amount of money involved in this exercise is likely to be very small. I thought that it was a reasonable proposition in moving from one area to another or taking out New Zealand because of our closer economic ties and that we would do it in a way that does not damage those people.

With regard to the Opposition's position, I am not quite sure why it is doing what it is doing because Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, merely said that it was not supporting the amendment. I think that is interesting and illustrates the rampant hypocrisy of the Opposition in the speeches that were made in this place on this very Bill. I suggest that those exporters pick up the letter that they received from Mr Sinclair-a copy was sent to all of them-which refers to the traumatic results that this action would lead to and which said that the `Opposition is pledged to a maintenance of this program' and then determine how they would vote. The Opposition has shown its typical hypocrisy by coming into this place and talking big, carrying on and now doing what it is about to do. It is an absolutely extraordinary exercise.

It would be a change if members of the Opposition stopped writing letters and said what it is that they are going to do, because the exporters, the various groups involved and particularly the chambers of commerce in Sydney and Melbourne, believed as a result of the communication from Mr Sinclair that they had the support of the Opposition. The letter used the term `traumatic', and made the pledge that the Opposition would be committed to the maintenance of the scheme. This is one way in which the Opposition could go at least some way towards assisting in this exercise. It is interesting that those exporters have now discovered, like so many other groups in the community, how they managed to get sold out by an exercise of the Opposition.

The Opposition runs around saying that this is a Budget Bill, but of course the Senate will be dealing with a Budget Bill later, a taxation Bill, to which the Opposition intends moving amendments. It is quite happy to do that. It has done it before and it will do it again. So there is certainly no basis upon which it can claim some type of principle that it will not amend Budget Bills, because it is going to seek to do that later today. I hope that those exporters who undoubtedly will be reading the Hansard record of this debate, who have an interest in this area because it affects their industry greatly, will compare what the Opposition does with what the Opposition said it was going to do in that letter from Mr Sinclair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I envy whoever it is who is going to have dinner with Senator Macklin tonight because he will be in such a good mood. He is always in a good mood after he makes such speeches about the Opposition. I have heard Senator Macklin make that speech on many occasions. It is good political stuff but the reality is that he has been able to make it on many occasions for the simple reason that since 1983 the Opposition, unlike the Australian Democrats, has exercised something of a self-denying ordinance in matters that relate to the Government's Budget. That is based on a statement put down in a quite formal way by former senator the Hon. Dame Margaret Guilfoyle when she was the shadow Minister for finance. She put down the considered view of the Opposition that in the main-she admitted there would be exceptions-the Opposition would allow the passage of the Government's key vital financial legislation which went to Budgets or mini-Budgets.
—The capital gains tax wasn't.

—We admitted two exceptions. I am delighted to have the interjection, because that means Senator Haines can go and have a good time at dinner too. She can go off with that wonderful feeling because she enjoys this debate so much as well. I simply want to say that I have outlined in my speech during the second reading debate the position of the Opposition. The Opposition said at the last election that it would abolish the export market development grants scheme, and one could say that it would be a bit inconsistent now to carry these amendments moved by the Democrats. The truth of the matter is that as a result of the policy reviews the Opposition has undertaken since that election there has been a commitment to continue the scheme through to its conclusion should there be an election and the coalition is returned to government. But as I made clear in my speech during the second reading debate, we do not propose to support amendments. We do not believe that that is the correct thing for us to do, so what we have done is draw attention to the fact that it was the Government which promised the continuance of the scheme, without any nibbling away at the edges, but it is the Government which has gone back on the quite extensive campaign it waged amongst exporters at the time of the last campaign when Mr Dawkins, then the Minister for Trade, wrote on his official ministerial notepaper what a strong commitment the Government had and how awful the Opposition was. We note that campaign and we note that this is another case where the Government, in the interests of reducing government expenditure, has seen fit to change its position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney has made an interesting intervention, but his proposition so little matches up with history that I think everybody now realises that it is one of those cases where the Opposition waves something around and hopes that everybody believes that the shoddy little exercise it is engaging in is somehow a principled one. The Opposition voted against the capital gains tax, the assets test and the fringe benefits proposal, and it is now saying presumably that those measures were not of consequence to the Government's Budget. Yet this one, which involves keeping for one extra year the application of the export market development grants scheme to New Zealand, is suddenly of great moment to the Government's budgetary allocation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that Senator Chaney did not refer to the letter Mr Sinclair, the Opposition spokesperson, has been sending to exporters. I have been through the letter.
