For example, it says that the legislation is inimical to the interests of small exporters. The letter condemns the Government for giving so little notice to exporters of the change. It acknowledges that the dropping out of New Zealand will be traumatic, and then promises that the Opposition would maintain the scheme. It is an interesting exercise by the Opposition to have its spokesperson in the other place sending out a letter saying what the Opposition would do, while its spokesperson in this place says something else. In this place, unlike the other place, the Opposition could do something. Down there it can only talk, so Mr Sinclair sends out a letter and puts his proposition to the people in the hope that they will be fooled. Unfortunately he is dealing with a group of people who are a lot smarter than I think Senator Chaney believes. These are businessmen who have gone out there into the hard world, into the hard export world, and who can understand what the Opposition is up to. That has been communicated to us pretty clearly today.

It is a pity that we could not have seen the extra year's phasing in, through to 1 July 1990, when the closer economic relationship comes into force. That was the appropriate period, and it would have given exporters that extra year to engage in that exercise. That is what our amendment is asking for, and I believe that would be a more appropriate way of dealing with the matter. It would be a very small concession in terms of the overall legislation. I would hope that the Opposition can see that it is a small concession, and I am sure that if the Committee had pressed this amendment the Government would have accepted it. It is a small concession; however, it would have been a vital concession to those people who have invested heavily in the New Zealand market.

I say again that investment in the New Zealand market is relatively typical of a number of small firms going into the export exercise. Even Senator Button has acknowledged, as I acknowledge, the difference between the New Zealand market and the South African market. The New Zealand market is an easier market for Australian exporters for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that the similarity of regulations, the lower transport costs and the ability of a small company to cope with the transport and communications costs in New Zealand all make it a far different prospect from trying to break into the South African market. I acknowledge that, but what I was drawing on in relation to the South African analogy in 1985 and the changes that have been made was that those changes in the South African case were explicitly built in in a transitional framework in the clear acknowledgment that those firms may have made commitments which went over the closing date that the Government was proposing for export grants for the South African market. I think that was legitimate. I supported very strongly our disengagement from that market. I am not talking about that. What I am saying is that people have to make commercial commitments and the Government, in acknowledging those commercial commitments, was pleased to be able to organise them in such a way that those people did not have those commitments massively disturbed. I would have thought that this additional year could have been introduced. I am not talking about whether or not it should be taken out; I am merely talking about that additional year to assist.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Pages 3 and 4, clause 7, line 36 (page 3), to line 17 (page 4), leave out the clause, insert the following clauses:
``7. Section 14 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (4).
``7a. After section 14 of the Principal Act the following sections are inserted:
Persons eligible for grants
`14a. (1) Subject to this Act, a grant is payable to a person in respect of a particular grant year in accordance with this section.

`(2) Where the person is a body corporate that has an affiliated company in relation to a grant year, and the affiliated company has made a claim in respect of the grant year, then, for each $1,000,000 by which the aggregate of the export earnings in the grant year of the person and the relevant export earnings in the grant year of every body corporate that was an affiliated company in relation to the grant year and has made a claim in relation to the grant year, exceeds $15,000,000, the grant entitlement of the person otherwise provided for by this Act shall be reduced by 10%.

`(3) In any other case, for each $1,000,000 by which the export earnings of the person in the grant year exceed $15,000,000 the grant entitlement of the person otherwise provided for by this Act shall be reduced by 10%.

`(4) In subsection (2): `relevant export earnings', in relation to a body corporate that was an affiliated company in relation to another body corporate in relation to a grant year, means the export earnings of the first-mentioned body corporate while it was such an affiliated company.
Minimum eligible expenditure for a grant
`14b. A grant is not payable to a person in respect of a particular grant year if the amount of eligible expenditure incurred by the person in the grant year does not exceed $10,000.'.''.

The structure of this amendment is somewhat complex. It seeks to change the phraseology of the entire clause whereby the wording, which is `persons not eligible for grants', becomes `persons eligible for grants'. The effect of the clause remains basically the same with one major amendment. Instead of the automatic cut-off point, there will now be a phase-in exercise. Under the Bill as it stands the cut-off figure is $20m and fairly obviously problems will arise very rapidly in practice. The problem is that companies coming up to that cut-off mark will now have an incentive not to continue larger exports which will take them over the limit. In staying under that mark they will have the advantage of the export support.

As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, many citizens might find it difficult to understand why they are supporting a company that has $20m in exports. I think that is a fair proposition. I believe that we ought to be targeting these export grants in a way that is different from the grants scheme in practice at the moment. It ought to be a method that is linked to success. As Senator Button well knows, there are a number of instances, particularly in the primary industry area, where there is no grant in a subsequent year unless there has been a significant percentage increase in exports-in most cases a set percentage. Unless there has been that increase the company loses out entirely. So built into those primary industry schemes is an incentive for people to get out there and sell. The Government has now built into this mechanism a disincentive for people to get out there and export more.

While it is not possible by way of an amendment to this grants scheme Bill to put in the type of scheme I am suggesting, my amendment does something different. My amendment seeks to implement a phase-in operation. We would start at a $15m level and work up to a $25m level by increments of 10 per cent for every $1m. This would entice people to come into the scheme and to stay in it because the amount they would lose by increasing their exports would in no way be commensurate with the amount they would lose if, for example, their export earnings went from $19 1/2m to $20 1/2m. That grant would then cut out entirely. It is a case of the quick and the dead. I suggest to Senator Button that, if he were an accountant for a firm which was sitting near that mark, he would be giving advice to that firm to stay under the mark to bring in a better profit. Ironically, its profit could drop if it were more successful in the export area. That is not something that we would want to build into any export scheme.

In looking at costs under this arrangement, which I think is an important element, I have designed my amendment so that the total cost will equate as near as is practicable to the total cost under the Government's proposal. I suppose that one could design amendments that would vastly increase costs. I did not do that for the specific reason that I hoped the Opposition, in looking at this, would then say, `This proposition does not disturb the revenue and, because it does not disturb the revenue, we will be able to support it'. This proposition has also been supported by those people engaged in exports. I hope that Senator Button will look at it and see that it is a more sensible way of dealing with the matter than the sudden death exercise that is built into the legislation.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Jenkins:
That the Casino Control Ordinance 1988, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 72 of 1988, made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I wish to indicate our position on the Casino Control Ordinance-a position which is probably well known after the press coverage of the topic today. The Opposition has decided to oppose the motion of disallowance and therefore to allow the Ordinance to stand. The decision was reached after a great deal of careful deliberation, and we do not apologise for that. Some people, as I have noted from the press and elsewhere, have failed to understand why that due consideration should be given to this issue. But it is clearly an issue within the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), as it was within most of the States of Australia and in the Northern Territory, which raises emotions and which is regarded as a particularly serious matter by a great many people in the community. It has become clear from the debate in the ACT that not only does everyone in the ACT seem to have a view on the matter, but that they hold those views most passionately.

SPEECH.PARA: We thought it appropriate that all these views should be properly taken into account. We felt that there should be full consultation, that any individual or group that wished to put a view should have a proper opportunity to do so, and that all those attitudes should be taken to the various forums within the parliamentary party-to the shadow ministry and to the party room. We felt that ultimately within the party room all those on our side of the Parliament who wished to contribute to the debate should have the opportunity to do so. As the community tends to be divided on issues such as casinos-moral and social issues-so those issues raise the same differences of view within parliamentary parties. It is regrettable in some ways that the Government sees this issue apparently much more simply, although if one listens to the gossip around this place we hear that there are mixed views within the Government on this topic. However, unfortunately, any Labor members who expressed such a view in this place would be expelled for their trouble. Nevertheless, we do not apologise for the amount of effort and care we have put into making this decision and in the extensive evaluation of both sides of the debate that has taken place.

I stress that the Opposition has approached this question on the basis that it is a project which the Government is putting up. I am unable to say whether if we were the Government we would have been heading down the same path, but that is irrelevant. The Opposition parties have had to decide whether they are prepared to allow the Government's project to stand or would use the disallowance mechanism to force the project to a halt. As I have indicated, we are of the view that it should stand. In this type of exercise one tends to begin by saying that, where there are those in the community who want to enter into some course of commercial enterprise, the onus must be on those who oppose their doing so to make out their case. That is the way we have approached this debate.

I shall not keep the Senate long as the issues are well known and the arguments have been heard over and over, but I wish briefly to run through the arguments which have been most prominently put for the project and touch upon the arguments against it, and then put forward our analysis of the arguments. The first and major argument put for the project-and I talk of the project as a whole, the casino, the hotel, the theatre complex, the cinemas that we hope will be involved, and the shopping that will come with it-is that the benefits would contribute to what might be described as the overall tourism package of the ACT. We see some validity in that argument. We do not over-emphasise it, or see it in itself as the salvation of Canberra's economic difficulties now or in the future. Nevertheless, we believe that it will contribute to the overall package that Canberra is able to offer. One has only to reflect that the opening of the new convention centre in this city will not be to far away. When one is looking to attract conventions one has to offer a total package. The packages offered in my home city of Adelaide, or in the city of Hobart, are no accident and casinos are included as part of the night life in those cities. The ACT without those same facilities has that disadvantage in the total package offered.

We believe that the tourism infrastructure will be vital in diversifying the economy of the ACT. No longer can we look to continuing growth in the Public Service as offering the same economic future to the Territory that it has offered in the past. No matter which side of the Parliament is in government, there simply will not be the same growth. Furthermore, it is fair to say that there will not be the same expenditure on the national institution attraction of the ACT which has been the case in the past. We are not for a moment saying that that means the expenditure should cease. We on this side of the chamber are disturbed by, for example, the Government's attitude not to proceed at this time with the National Museum of Australia. We believe that there are worthwhile national institutional projects that should be proceeding at this time, but we regret that they have been dropped off the agenda. We recognise that the great expenditure on national institutions which has taken place in recent years is unlikely to continue at the same level in future years. Therefore, there will be a need to inject more private sector money into the tourism industry. In a way that is what will happen with this project because the casino and hotel will be built with private money, and the casino will provide some capital revenue for the purpose of adding to the community facilities of the city. The hotel that will be part of the total project also will add to the capacity of Canberra to service the top end of the market, particularly in the light of the market that will be available with the opening of the new convention centre. We therefore saw some merit in the tourism argument, although we do not intend to overstate the position.

It was also put to us quite forcefully that the project will provide jobs. Again, some suggestions as to how many jobs have been exaggerated, but a very large project of this type will create a considerable number of jobs in the construction industry. Similarly, a large tourism project of this type will provide a considerable number of jobs in the operation of the complex. One thing we can say about the tourist industry is that it is a job intensive industry. It creates employment and employment for Canberra is important.

It is particularly important. I touched upon the construction area. It is particularly important in relation to balancing the lessening of the other construction works that we have seen in the Territory. Whilst it might be said that jobs in casinos and hotels might be seen by some as somewhat lowly, nevertheless, they tend to attract young people. They provide opportunities for young people. It is regrettable that the level of unemployment among young people in Canberra, albeit a wealthy city, is particularly high. This project will offer increased job opportunities for young people. We would hope that they would use the skills and experiences that they gain in this industry either to build up a future for themselves in the tourist industry or to enable them to finance further studies that will allow them to move on to other areas.

I might say that this has been the experience in Adelaide. The casino does tend to attract a lot of young labour. People do not stay in it forever. They use it as a stepping stone to move on to something else that perhaps might give them greater job satisfaction and opportunity in the future. We in our debate on this matter certainly take into account the fact that increasing the tourist infrastructure in Canberra increases job opportunities.

I touched upon the fact that this project is to provide capital that will be reinvested in other community facilities for the ACT, in particular in the theatre complex, the performing arts complex and also in a central library of the Territory. Again, I need to say that we were unimpressed by the way in which the Government sought to provide to the people of the ACT an inducement, arguing that the only way in which they could achieve these community facilities was to accept a casino. We thought that that type of arm twisting approach to the issue was the wrong way to put serious matters to the community. The public has a responsibility to provide proper facilities through its Government. The casino should not have been offered as an inducement although it was more than that. It was a clear threat that if the people of the ACT would not accept the casino they could not expect the facilities.

We did not approach our analysis of this matter on that basis. We sought first to analyse the casino and any social costs that might flow from it. Only after satisfying ourselves that those costs in the experience of what has happened elsewhere in Australia were not great, did we then look to these ancillary benefits that could follow. Once you accept that the casino is not an unreasonable proposition for Canberra then it follows that there is nothing wrong with attempting to get the best price out of the project for the total benefit of the community. We look at the performing arts complex and the library in such terms. Both will enhance Canberra for the residents of Canberra. Of course, the performing arts theatre will enhance the total infrastructure of this city and this Territory. We would say in passing-it is not totally relevant to the question tonight-that there is a lot of work that needs to be done on the theatre complex itself and whether it is the most appropriate theatre complex. A lot of work is necessary, as the Government has admitted, on the library and what is the best way in which to proceed with the central Territory library in Canberra.

We recognise the reality that without significant private sector infusion of funds such projects would be a long way off. It will be difficult enough, I also say in passing, for the ACT to finance its recurrent expenditure if one looks at recent reports of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, let alone borrow some $40m odd as a basis for these community facilities. They would have been a long way off and if their development can be brought forward as a result of this total project, we in the Opposition think that that is worth while.

We note, and we remind the Government, that under the terms of the Casino Control Ordinance 1988 the Minister must be satisfied as to timely arrangements for these community facilities before the Minister can give the licence under the casino. We assure the Government that that is something which we in the Opposition will be monitoring most closely. I touch also upon the benefit that has been put of a revenue source that will arise for Government out of the casino. It becomes relevant out of what I have just said about the difficulty that the ACT will face in meeting its recurrent expenditure. There is no doubt that the casino will produce a reasonable revenue tax. The figures are debatable. On the research that I have done, comparing the Canberra casino with similar sized casinos in Australia, looking at their build up period, looking at the type of tourist industries that we have in the ACT and based on a 20 per cent tax on revenue, it seems to me that the figure of around $6m in the start-up years is likely to be achieved. It is not a great figure when we look at the overall revenue requirements of the ACT. It nevertheless broadens the revenue base of the Territory and we think that is important.

Let me touch upon the arguments that were put against the casino and the way in which we analysed those arguments. Firstly, it was put by some that a casino in the ACT is inconsistent with the image of the national capital. What I say to that is that the casino in Adelaide has not destroyed the image of the city of churches. The Hobart casino has not destroyed the attractiveness and character of Hobart. What they have simply done is add another perspective to those cities and so it will be with Canberra. Let me move to the second argument that was put, that revenue and jobs will be at the expense of other gambling establishments and hotels. We acknowledge that there will be some movement of business from these other establishments to this new project; there always is. There is always a certain attractiveness about a new project. But, we have noted that this project has the support of most of the licensed clubs in Canberra.

We know from obvious business experience that a new hotel will attract business from existing hotels, particularly at the top end of the market. There is nothing unusual in that. Those that were once at the top end of the market tend to fit into a different level of the tourism infrastructure. They adapt to the new market as it is and if they are managed and run well they will continue to operate profitability. They are, of course, well established and have lower capital costs. They are really competing on a different basis. I can see no reason why in the environment of the development of the new convention centre and the continuing development of Canberra they need feel any particular fear from another top end of the market hotel.

I move to the argument that has been put in this debate and has been put in every other casino debate around Australia and, that is, that such an establishment is at a social cost. There are always unfortunate cases that follow from any form of gambling. I remind honourable senators that the ACT has one of the most liberal gambling regimes in Australia, if not the most liberal gambling regime. There are many opportunities already existent in the ACT for which foolish people have the opportunity to lose their money. I must say, as I think I have said elsewhere, I find it somewhat ironic that we in South Australia believe there is a much greater social cost out of the gambling mechanism of the poker machines, whereas in the ACT it has been regarded as a much more socially acceptable form of gambling. It is even now endorsed by some of the churches which use it as a method of raising funds whereas roulette or blackjack gambling is seen as something that is of a greater social evil. Opposition members have had trouble seeing that argument. We recognise that there is an inherent danger for individuals in any gambling opportunity. We recognise that there is a need for public education and for public support for those who are unable to control themselves and behave sensibly in a gambling environment.

Let us put the argument in the context of the Adelaide casino. There has not been an indication of major increases in social costs. On the other hand, we see an establishment from Adelaide's point of view-which is probably the most conservative city in Australia-that is enormously popular both with local residents and with tourists, and, as I understand it, it still has long queues outside the front door almost every day of the week.

Let me move to the next argument that was put against the proposal, which is that casinos attract organised crime. We on this side of the chamber are of the view that with proper surveillance and monitoring, the capacity of a casino to facilitate organised crime is much reduced and is, by some, overestimated. Again, we can look at the experience we have around Australia. I remind the Senate of the Hobart casino, which has been operating for some 12 to 14 years. There has been no evidence of a significant increase in organised crime. South Australia has an organised crime problem, but it does not in any way relate to the casino. The casino is not seen as facilitating organised crime.

I have to bring to the Senate's attention the fact that on behalf of the Opposition I visited the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police in Canberra to raise this subject, to ask how concerned the AFP were about the potential for organised crime to be encouraged by a casino in the Australian Capital Territory. Commissioner McAulay, who has had experience of casinos in the Northern Territory, expressed the opinion, on behalf of his force, that they did not see it as a significant problem. Of course, there needs to be a proper regulatory mechanism. On our perusal of this particular Ordinance we accept that it has taken many of the stronger mechanisms out of each of the State experiences and has built up what could only be called a strict regime. In fact, some of my colleagues thought that some of the provisions were even somewhat draconian. We gave consideration to the organised crime argument but, on serious objective analysis, it did not seem to stand the contemporary test.

In the time available to me tonight I have presented the principal arguments-there are others as well-that were put for and against the casino, and the methodology we used to evaluate those arguments. I mentioned a moment ago that in accepting a development of this nature we say that there is a need for the continuing education of people to be responsible with their money in gambling establishments. We believe that that is a responsibility of the state. It is something that the Government should accept. I hope that projects will be developed within the Australian Capital Territory to educate people to be so responsible-it probably goes far beyond a casino-to educate people to understand that it is possible to treat a casino as a place in which they can enjoy themselves, as they do in the Adelaide casino, where they can spend what they can afford to lose and go home without any great social harm.

We use this opportunity to say to the Government that we would be unhappy if it sought to use the private investment which will be created by this project as an excuse for neglecting public investment. One has a suspicion that that is already the Government's approach to this matter. It is not an approach that we think is a legitimate one. The Government, on behalf of Australians, has a continuing responsibility to develop the national institutions that we have in this place and of which we are most proud. Our belief is that at the moment it should be proceeding with the institution that will be the National Museum of Australia.

Furthermore, as the tourist infrastructure continues to develop, we hope the Government will not believe that that in itself will offer sufficient diversification of the economic base of the Australian Capital Territory, because in our view it will not. We think the Government should be looking for continuing diversification. There has been insufficient effort put in in that regard in the Australian Capital Territory. If one looks at the opportunities in high-tech areas linking in with the institutions of higher learning in the Australian Capital Territory, one will see insufficient commercial exploitation of these opportunities. While the Government remains in office, we urge it to do more in this area. The community has a right to expect from government leadership in this field, to expect a diversification of the economy of the Australian Capital Territory. It is not receiving that leadership at the moment. In the same way, we have seen inadequate planning by this Government in the slowdown of construction jobs that the Government has known for years would inevitably follow the completion of this massive project, the new Parliament House. There has been inadequate planning and we believe that the Government should be condemned for that. It should not look upon this principally private sector development as a total substitute, allowing it to abdicate its responsibility for long term planning, which we believe has occurred.

That is what I wanted to put to the Senate tonight. We have evaluated most carefully, as I think is appreciated from the time we have taken, the arguments that have been put in favour of the project and the arguments that have been put against the project. We believe that we have reached the correct conclusion. In other words, we believe we have evaluated the strengths and weaknesses correctly, and that with proper planning, supervision and education, most of the genuine concerns that we have heard expressed by some people in the Australian Capital Territory can be allayed. As I said when I commenced my speech, our decision, therefore, is to oppose the motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion for disallowance and I welcome the Opposition's decision to join with us in this matter. Now is not the time to dwell on the process by which it came to that decision. I do not oppose the motion because I look forward with great enthusiasm to attending the casino or to participating in activities there, but rather because I believe that the onus of proof is upon those who wish to ban private activities, such as investment in the casino and attendance and participating in the activities there, to prove their case, and that case has not been proved.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance it appears that at least the Casino Control Ordinance will make it possible for individuals to invest in a major private development here in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) which will create a large number of jobs and other economic benefits. Some people wish to ban those people from going ahead with the essential economic generator of that particular proposal. In an approach not dissimilar to that which was adopted by Senator Hill-although I hope not to be repetitive-I think it is necessary to examine the arguments that have been put against allowing such a project to proceed. As I said, the onus of proof lies on those who wish to ban individuals from engaging in what would otherwise be lawful activities.

There is only one position that can be justified as a consistent, logical, legitimate argument against the casino, and that is if one is totally anti-gambling. I know some people in this city who have that view. They are opposed to all gambling in all places at all times. It is a perfectly legitimate position. It is not a philosophical position which I share, but I understand it, and they are entitled to hold it. Once one adopts that position one must come to the logical conclusion that one is opposed to a casino. I understand that. Many people hold that view.

I find that I am not persuaded by the other arguments that are put. Almost all of the opponents of the casino who have come to see me, who have written to me, who have written to others, who have spoken in public, are not anti-gambling; in fact, many are not anti-casino. They simply say that this would not be an appropriate place for it. They are concerned about the effect which gambling will have on our city, our society and upon the individuals within it, particularly with regard to corruption. They stress that this problem may increase in a city that is the national capital.

The problem of corruption is not an issue to be ignored. It is inexorable logic that it is much more likely that illegal casinos will be run by criminals than that legal casinos will be run by them. Illegal casinos are, by definition, run by criminals; legal casinos, particularly when they are to be run under an ordinance as strict as that which we are addressing tonight, are not-and there is no record in Australia that they have been-run by criminals. There is no record that legal casinos have made the activities of organised crime any easier or that public officials in the cities in which they operate have been corrupted. My colleague Senator Calvert from Tasmania is often an advocate of the benefits that flow to Tasmania from the casinos there. Certainly, governments of different political persuasions over the years may have had policies with which I disagreed, but none of them have flowed from any allegations of corruption associated with the casinos. That remains the case in Adelaide and in Perth. In Queensland, where the corruption problem might be said to have raised its ugly head, it has essentially raised its head because of the money that facilitates corruption that has flowed from illegal activities, some of them illegal gambling. It is a matter of inexorable logic that illegal gambling is more dangerous in terms of corruption than legal gambling. That argument falls flat very quickly.

There is, as Senator Hill said, a closely parallel argument that a casino is not appropriate for a national capital. That argument is either arrogant or sanctimonious and, in some instances, both. There are people in this city who say, `I am not anti-casino, I just don't think it should be in Canberra'. I regard that as fundamentally an arrogant position. It is a position that in some way we here are better than other people or that they as individuals are entitled to put some image of the status of the city in which they live ahead of the young people and the working people of this city who will gain pleasure and employment-later I will refer particularly to employment-from the development of this project. People from other States in which casinos flourish who say that a casino is unsuitable for this city are either ignorant or sanctimonious. I do not find either characteristic particularly attractive.

I find somewhat amusing the idea that a national capital will be in some way undermined by the operation of a casino. It makes one wonder how poor old London and Paris cope. One wonders how those cities continue to survive as national capitals, because the casinos in London are rather close to Westminster. I suspect that the odd member of parliament might have visited them once or twice. In fact, I think the odd Australian member of parliament has visited them once or twice. Nevertheless, London manages to struggle along as a national capital; Paris manages to struggle along; and Perth, Adelaide, Hobart and Darwin manage to battle along as well. I suspect that the capital of Australia will battle along also.

It has been said that perhaps, as this city is full of judges, politicians and public servants, there is some greater danger that these important public officials will be corrupted. In my travels over the years I have noticed that politicians, judges and public servants reside in Perth, Adelaide and London, and they still manage to survive. In fact, some public officials in cities around Australia, who I am too polite to mention, have been involved in corruption. Some have been to gaol for that activity. None of it has arisen from any connection with illegal gambling.

I do not wish to make light of all the issues raised by people expressing concern about the casino. There is the initial moral argument which I addressed and which I acknowledge. A serious question has been raised about the adverse social consequences of increased gambling outlets. I do not want to say that there will be none. The social impact study, which I thought was a comprehensive and very worthwhile analysis, did not pretend that there will be no increase in gambling, or in the social distress that might flow from gambling, as a result of the casino. It stated that it would be minor and incremental and that most people in the ACT who are susceptible to excessive gambling are not short of outlets through which to exercise that particular weakness. They may wish to visit the many poker machine institutions-too many, some might say-the Totalisator Agency Board or, the racecourse, they may wish to gamble in other ways or they may wish to visit an illegal casino. They are certainly able to do so. I acknowledge that point; I gave it quite a bit of thought. Until the social impact study was available, I declined to indicate my position on the casino because I wanted to examine that very question.

I have always had a very profound concern about the social consequences of unemployment. I think that the people who express a real and legitimate concern about the social consequences of gambling forget that one has to weigh in that scale the fact that if this project does not go ahead there will be substantial adverse social consequences, profound and lasting, arising from unemployment. The people who will suffer that particular adverse social consequence will not do so as a result of any activity of their own, rather, as a result of an activity of this Parliament.

It is also argued that there is substantial community opposition to this proposal and that therefore it should not go ahead. Some very interesting arguments were put earlier in this debate. There is an argument that a clear majority of the community is opposed to the proposal. Some reference has been made to an absolutely bogus write-in poll which I will treat with the contempt it deserves. There has also been an attempt to analyse the statistics from an AGB McNair Marketing Research poll on the casino project. So far as I can tell by any reasonable measure, as one who has been looking at market research for many years, it was a bona fide, legitimate piece of market research. It has been interpreted as saying that a clear majority specified that the feature about the proposal which they especially disliked was the casino. I looked at that report as a consequence of that statement. I did not remember there being a clear majority who said that. I found that this clear majority was 35 per cent. That sounds like a Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen definition of a clear majority. It may be that the party of the person who put forward that view is not used to getting more than 14 per cent of the vote, so it thinks 35 per cent would be manna from heaven and it must be a majority. I have to say that it is not.

In the same opinion poll 59 per cent of the people surveyed said either that they were in favour of the section 19 development or strongly in favour of it, as against 28 per cent who disagreed with the proposal going ahead. I do not intend to say that the proposal should go ahead simply because one opinion poll said that the majority of people were in favour of it. I think that is a very weak argument. I simply say that the argument that there is massive community opposition to the casino is neither supported by the subjective assessments which one makes from speaking with people in a fairly compact city nor from published opinion polls from respectable sources. On that basis the very best one can say about the arguments against the casino is that they are not proven. I suspect the opposition is substantially weaker than that.

It has also been argued that the money should be spent elsewhere. This argument is put, `Why should we invest money in a casino? We should build houses, the National Museum of Australia or refurbish the Royal Canberra Hospital', all of which I support. It seems to me a fairly basic question of public finance that one cannot take somebody's private investment and transfer it to some worthwhile public purpose. It is not possible to say to people who may wish to build a hotel, `Well, that's very nice; why don't you go and build the National Museum of Australia instead?'. That is obviously an absolutely irrational idea which flows from people who cannot tell the difference between public money and private money. It may well be-and I actually share the view expressed by Senator Hill-that it would be very good if the National Museum of Australia was built and built somewhat more promptly than the proposal that is currently the Government's policy. It is no big surprise to anybody in the Government that that is my view and I expect to be a slightly more effective advocate in the cause than some. It is absolutely irrelevant to the question whether a casino is built. It is not exchangeable investment. One is private, one is public. One is designed to make a profit and one is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you would tell that to the Western Australian Government.

—The Western Australian Government was certainly sensible enough not to invest in the casino and realised certain economic benefits that flow from it. There will be substantial economic benefits flowing from this casino also. I thank Senator Powell for the connection.

SPEECH.PARA: Principally, I wish to talk about the economic benefit that will flow from jobs. There are a large number of others, but to some extent they have been covered by Senator Hill and I will not waste people's time by duplicating his comments. The original estimates are that the initial creation of jobs in the building of the section 19 project-not the little casino that is in the middle of it, but the project that will be generated by it-will number something like 2,700; the number of continuing jobs is something like 1,800. I accept that it is arguable that people who are advocates of projects, such as this, exaggerate the benefits that will flow, although to the extent to which I have checked it from fairly impartial sources, those figures do not seem too far out of line. Even if they are 50 per cent out, they are very substantial contributions. There is a very substantial number of jobs in a city that will need those jobs very badly, initially and in a continuing way. It also substantially adds to the diversification of our economic base, and the essential synergy from tourism and the convention centre that Senator Hill outlined means that each will be more successful because of the presence of the other and particularly for Canberra which is a city suited to the development of a convention industry. The casino and the associated facilities that will flow from it will substantially add to the capacity of that convention centre to be successful.

I wish to make two alternative points about these jobs. I refer firstly to the timing of these jobs. It is a very key time for the construction industry; it is a key time for the economy of the ACT and the region as a whole. The rate of growth here is just about to decline significantly. We have the conclusion of this very large project, the new Parliament House. We have declined in population and economic growth at the same time as we are about to see a very substantial increase in the number of job seekers coming onto the market over the next few years in this city. It is important that various initiatives be taken to start to provide the capacity for jobs for those people. The initiatives will not do it by themselves. They are not sufficient. It is a necessary part of any such package; it is not sufficient; other elements are needed, many of which I have spoken about already.

As a first step, we have to get the construction industry on a plateau, at a realistic new level so that it can continue at a sustainable level after the peak of the new Parliament House. Therefore, we cannot go around building useless monuments because we need a construction industry. When there is a worthwhile proposal, the timing of it is very important and the sort of delay that some people spoke of would leave a very sagging gap, a very significant hiatus in the economic development of the city and of the Territory and the region.

I also wish to mention briefly that the jobs that will be created, particularly the continuing jobs, impact on that target about which we need to be most concerned. I refer to our youth. Although Canberra is blessed with a lower rate of unemployment than Australia as a whole, it still faces a substantial problem in youth unemployment. It is necessary that jobs are created that are particularly suited to the target groups.

The argument has been put about the substantial contributions from the casino tax. I suspect some of the top range assessments about the revenue that might flow are slightly exaggerated but when taken with payroll tax and other flow on benefits there is a significant contribution of between $5m and $10m to the revenue of the Australian Capital Territory. Although that is not a substantial amount of money in a $900m budget it is a significant increase in the discretionary expenditure that will be available to that ACT Government. It will not have $900m to do with as it wishes. A substantial proportion of it is dedicated to salaries and other long term commitments that are necessary but unavoidable. The percentage of that $900m that is discretionary is very low and the $5m to $10m that will be added will be a substantial increase in the discretionary expenditure available to the new Government of the ACT, which I hope will be elected in February or March of next year, to enable it to carry out many worthwhile social projects.

I could add to that, as Senator Hill has already discussed, the community benefits following from the theatre and the library. It does not make sense to build a casino because we want a theatre or a library. When there is a worthwhile project available that does not have consequences that are unbearable and where there are such potential, substantial community benefits as the improved theatre and library which would otherwise cost the taxpayers of this country something like $30m, it is an obviously substantial and worthwhile benefit that ought to be welcomed by everybody in Canberra and I think will be welcomed by the overwhelming majority of people. There are a number of other points that in other circumstances I would have made, but, given the fact that the Opposition has now decided to support the project, I will not take any more time of the Senate other than to conclude by saying that, if an individual or individuals wish to establish a casino with private investment, not public money, I do not support a proposal that they should be banned from doing so. I do not believe that the arguments for banning them from doing so have been established. Therefore, I will vote against the motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the disallowance of the Casino Control Ordinance 1988. There can be no doubt that this is an issue which has divided the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) community considerably and that there are very strongly held views on both sides of the argument. There has indeed been very intense lobbying on the issue over the last 12 months or so because we should not forget that it was in August 1987 that the then Minister for Territories-about three years ago-announced that there was to be a casino in the national capital.

SPEECH.PARA: There has, over the time from then to now, been criticism of the Opposition for having taken so long to make a decision on the matter. I point out to the Senate that the Government did not table the Casino Control Ordinance until 27 September of this year, more than 12 months after it first started talking about it. There has not been a proposition which we could adequately look at until that time. No-one can suggest that during that time we did not take an interest in the proposal. We ask the Government a number of questions relating to what it had in mind. We certainly discussed the project at length with people in the community who were both for and against this proposal.

The idea of a casino in Canberra, of course, is not a new one. It has come up in the past. The issues, to a significant extent, are unchanged and relate to the character of the national capital and whether a casino is appropriate, the social problems that are associated with gambling and the potential for criminal activities. The arguments for a casino have remained basically the same although there are some new elements in the debate this time around. The predominant issues in this instance are of course the creation of employment and the diversification of the economic base of Canberra. One of the new elements is that we are moving towards parity funding with the States, and in fact we now have our own budget. The other factor not present when the casino proposal last came up in 1983 is the total development of the section 19 area with the provision of community and other facilities. In 1983 the proposal was merely for a casino, with nothing else attached. The consideration of the total package of factors has led to the coalition parties accepting that Canberra stands to gain more than it will lose out of the development of the section 19 proposal.

The volume of correspondence I have received from those who are against a casino, with whom I have considerable sympathy, leaves me in no doubt that there will be many people disappointed at the decision the Opposition parties have taken. Equally, I am aware from the volume of correspondence I have received from those who favour the development that just as many Canberrans would have been disappointed had the decision been otherwise.

There are many people who see the need for development in Canberra and many, as Senator McMullan has just admitted, who are disappointed that the Museum of Australia has been pushed as far off the agenda as it seems to have been. We would all welcome the development of the Museum of Australia, not merely for the jobs it would provide during the construction stage and subsequently but for the heritage value for the whole of Australia that the museum, with its imaginative plan, would offer to all Australians. I hope that there will be an imaginative development along the shores of the lake, that there will be restaurants and other facilities, and that it will not close at 4.51 each day but will be a considerable attraction at night as well. I am even more disappointed that the Government is treating the redevelopment of the old Parliament House in a fairly offhanded way. I was on a committee some years ago that made recommendations about its future, which until now have been totally ignored. Any development has been put off for yet another 12 months, I imagine to the advantage only of the cockroaches who reside there.

As I have said, the debate on the casino development has been a divisive one. Equally, it is no secret that there are very strongly held views within the Opposition parties about it and, if I am right, amongst members of the Government as well. It has been suggested-and suggested by some of my colleagues-that this matter ought to have been left for the people of the ACT to decide. The fact is, though, that from Federation until this time the Federal Parliament has had responsibility for Canberra, and this matter is with the Parliament here and now. I am fairly confident that that will not be the case for much longer, but the fact is that self-government has not yet been established in the ACT. When that does occur the Federal Parliament will no longer be involved in the sorts of decisions it has made in the past. We have not shrunk from the responsibility that devolves upon us on issues such as the one before the Parliament.

As I said earlier, the 1983 proposal for a casino was that it should stand alone. We now look at a time when there is a need for employment opportunities in the building industry and for young people. We cannot go on forever merely building for the sake of providing jobs in the construction industry, but it is interesting to look at the most recent report of the Parliament House Construction Authority to see the impact this building has had upon the work force and the downturn that has flowed from its completion. That is no surprise, and one may be critical of this Government for not having looked at projects like the Museum of Australia and the development of the old Parliament House. By comparison, both are quite small projects, but perhaps they should have been dealt with and brought on much sooner. The work force here in June 1986 was 2,064; in June 1987 it was 2,241; in December 1987 it was thought to be 2,300; it was expected to have been 700 in June 1988; and in December 1988 it is expected to be 250.

Those figures cannot be lightly overlooked. The project we are discussing tonight will assist to provide work for skilled workers who are residing in Canberra, and there will be flow-on benefits for the building industry as well as the service industries, the real estate industry and other parts of the Canberra economy. There are still quite limited private sector employment opportunities in Canberra, especially for young people, as evidenced by the high youth unemployment in the ACT. Tourism is an important part of Canberra, although we need to develop other areas. The drawcard of this project and its casino may well encourage some additional visitors. It may well mean that some people will stay an extra night in Canberra, and I believe it will add to the attraction of the convention centre from a marketing point of view.

Canberra does not have the same means of raising income as the States. We have no primary industry, mining or fisheries, and we have only a negligible forestry industry and quite limited small scale manufacturing which, while promising and developing, cannot by any stretch of the imagination be regarded at this stage as a major employer or a major industry. Canberra has to look at other alternatives for raising income and providing opportunities. One might, with some nostalgia, think back to the grand prix that we lost to Adelaide. The success of it in Adelaide can only make one drool about the opportunity Canberra lost. The grand prix should have been here. The Liberal Government in 1981 proposed it, and I think we really lost something when we saw it go to Adelaide and did not fight to keep it.

The casino is not quite the same as the grand prix. It will be with us 24 hours a day whereas the grand prix comes and goes over a few weeks of each year. It certainly would have earned substantial income. The casino will undoubtedly have income, though perhaps not of the same substantial kind. It will mean opportunities and jobs, which cannot be dismissed out of hand. It is estimated that it will create around 3,000 jobs in the building and construction phase over three or four years and about 1,000 permanent jobs. These figures may be exaggerated; nonetheless it will create significant employment opportunities.

When one considers the consequences of the movement towards Federal funding and the basis of funding under self-government, additional sources of revenue must be identified. With an employer as large as the casino will be, one cannot help but contemplate that in addition to the revenue that will be gained from the licence fee, estimated to be substantial, there will be a significant amount of payroll tax, which is not available from many of the smaller businesses in Canberra. Without going into detail, one cannot help but think of the significance of the recent Commonwealth Grants Commission report. When we were discussing a casino in 1983 one of the reasons for thinking of it as being fairly unattractive was that any proceeds from it would have gone straight into Consolidated Revenue and been of no benefit to the people of Canberra. It would have been merely another income raising measure for the Federal Government. However, the money from this casino will remain in the Australian Capital Territory and will be dealt with, I confidently expect, by an Australian Capital Territory government, which will be answerable to the electorate for the moneys it spends and the way those moneys are raised.

It is also significant that in 1983 there was considerable opposition, and vocal opposition, from the racing industry and the licensed clubs in Canberra, both of whom have been silent in relation to this proposal. The Licensed Clubs Association has endorsed the proposal with the provison that there be no machines in the casino-only gambling tables. One club only has spoken to me about its concerns and worries about the casino, but the Association to which it and the others belong has, as I said, endorsed the proposal.

The other criticism voiced in 1983 was that there had been no social impact study of a casino on Canberra. That was taken care of in the 1988 debate. I refer to some of the points that that study made. It said that there was no significant evidence documented of any widespread problems to families and individuals resulting from casino gambling. It also said that, while there might well be a downturn in the revenue from other forms of gambling in the first few years after a casino opened, the level would return to pre-casino rates of growth thereafter. It also pointed out that the inclusion of the casino in the section 19 development would make the project more commercially viable than if it were not included and would support the inclusion of community facilities. It also reported that the majority of residents believed that a casino would make no difference to the character of Canberra as the national capital. Of course, I agree that that is a debatable issue upon which people have quite strong views.

There is little doubt that like alcoholism and drug addiction, gambling is a social problem which will not go away in spite of attempts at prohibition on occasions. For those for whom gambling is a problem Canberra already has many gambling avenues available with the poker machines in the licensed clubs, horse racing which takes place on Sunday in Canberra, Tattslotto, the TAB and lotteries of all kinds. In fact, there will probably be only about four additional games taking place which are not already here. Logic causes one to ask what difference could result from the addition of those games when one looks at what is already available. It is true that gamblers can perhaps lose money more quickly in a casino than in poker machines, but I suggest that this is not so when compared with betting on horses. I am told that it is as easy to place a $10,000 bet on a horse as on a roulette wheel. That is something I never expect to know or understand, but I have no doubt that substantial bets were placed on horses this very week. It is easy to place bets on horses through the TAB every day of the week. There is already plenty of opportunity for gamblers to lose their all if they are minded to do so.

There were outcries in Tasmania at the time about the effect of a casino in Hobart and about the possibility of organised crime being involved. It seems very clear that that is not the case. There is no doubt that some gamblers lose substantially, but no one is suggesting that Hobart has deteriorated. In fact, all comments on that city seem to suggest that it has benefited substantially from the casino and the social problems that were talked about at the time have not eventuated. However, it is important that we should not be complacent.

Having studied the Ordinance carefully, I believe that if we have a casino in Canberra it is necessary for it to be as stringently run as any other in Australia, with the requirements that this places on the developer, the operator and the authority that will be established to run it. The Ordinance includes a provision that the Minister must be satisfied that the community facilities will be provided within the proper timeframe and I believe that the Government has made commitments in relation to what will occur on the site. The theatre will undoubtedly benefit Canberra and enable Canberra people to see productions which would not otherwise be able to come here. Equally, I believe that although we might regard a theatre as a community facility which should be provided by government, there is little likelihood that this Government will provide one. I think there is also little likelihood that a Liberal government would produce the money for that purpose, much as one might like to think that it would do so. The economy of this country at present does not indicate that that would be the case. Local theatre companies will also benefit from the other facilities which will then be available as a consequence. There is, of course, also the question of a library as part of the development.

Many of my colleagues have told me of their reservations about casinos in their electorates but in time they have found that these casinos have not been harmful as predicted. In fact, as I have said, I have been told that in Hobart the casino has been of benefit to that city. It is with some very serious personal reservations that I talk about supporting a casino licence for Canberra, but to enable the other aspects of the project to proceed, I support the opposition to the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal before us is the motion for disallowance of the Casino Control Ordinance 1988 in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I have been preceded in this debate by the two senators for the ACT-my colleague Senator Reid from the Opposition and Senator McMullan from the Government side. Their speeches already clearly indicated-and my South Australian colleague Senator Hill, who is the shadow Minister in this area, represented the position of the Liberal and National parties-that both the Opposition and the Government are resolved not to support this disallowance motion. Therefore, in the eventual vote on this motion in the chamber, we all expect an overwhelming majority to reject the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak briefly bearing very much in mind the representations that have been made to us as senators on this matter. I am not a senator for the ACT; I am a Liberal senator for South Australia. I have participated vigorously in the preliminary debates on this matter because I am highly conscious of the fact that Canberra is the national capital and it is appropriate that all matters concerning the national capital be considered carefully by all of us, representing every part of Australia. With these representations that have come from all parts of Australia in mind, I rise to reassure those who have written to us that their views have been most carefully taken into account.

I was persuaded to give enormous sympathy to those who argued against the establishment of a casino in the national capital. The views expressed by so many people in Australia were that they wished to ensure that the national capital remained above any kind of corruption which so many see associated with casinos-in terms of laundering money and other vices which have, in some countries, developed around casinos. I make the point that this argument was put most carefully by myself and many other senators in the discussions which led to the decision by both the Opposition and, I presume, the Government during prior discussions on this matter. It is clear that the national capital should be seen as a representative place that heightens all that is sound and good in Australia. Whatever may occur in building developments in this city, Canberra will be known pre-eminently for this Parliament building, the Commonwealth parliamentary departments and all the decision-making and activities that go on within them. For the citizens who live and work here this city is known for its schools, playing fields, parks and, of course, the national monuments such as the Australian War Memorial, the National Gallery, the National Library and other great centres of considerable public interest.

A second matter that was put in representations to us was that we should weigh properly the serious disadvantages that flow to individuals and families who suffer great losses in gambling. It is the case that in every gambling institution in this country and overseas people lose. Ultimately, I believe that all but a very few who use gambling institutions lose. It is a fool who makes a habit of putting hard-earned money on the throw of a dice at a casino. There is no way that that person will ultimately go away richer. In my State of South Australia this loss has led to a number of small businesses no longer having capital to continue. Families are no longer able to own their homes. Family members are suffering from the loss of what many would call squandered money.

A third argument put to us was that the tourist attractions in this great capital city are so well established already that the proposal that a casino is needed to stimulate significant tourist traffic is not a convincing argument-it is marginal at best. With regard to the associated development of a theatre, shopping facilities, a cinema, or any other positive assets for this city and its residents, I would hope that the viability of these activities would lead to their being built anyway.

A fourth argument that was put to us was very compelling to me. By repeating it here I wish to reassure the many people who put their views to us that those views were not only received and understood by us, but also clearly put in the discussions that were held in our party meetings to determine the position that we should take in this chamber. They were received in a bona fide, genuine way by all my colleagues in the Opposition. The fourth argument concerns the getting something for nothing mentality which is overtly sweeping this country and undermining its values. In very many areas of Australian life, not least in the television media, advertising lures are put to the public as if to offer them something for nothing, or a lot for a little outlay. I believe that this is undermining a well-established concept-a positive value-reward for effort and the need to contribute to the community to get benefits from it. Clearly, this undermining of an established value is able to be represented by an institution such as a casino. There are thousands of Australians who, when they think of a casino, think of an enterprise which is luring individuals to enter into an activity in the heady hope of getting something for nothing.

This understanding of values is concerning thousands of Australians. I assure those Australians that the best way to reinforce those values is by their own behaviour, their own good judgment, their own lifestyles, by their own choice as to what they do with their lives, and by the way in which they educate those around them. I stand with them in wanting to educate people to contribute positively to the community to ensure that there is an expectation, especially in young Australians, that to get a reward it is necessary to put in some effort.

A final major representation to us concerned the reinforcement of family values. It is possible for many of us to speak in lofty terms about matters that are dear to our hearts and our lives. Most honourable senators are family orientated and they value the family more highly than any other social institution in their lives. So to talk about the importance of sound family values is particularly important to us, especially my colleagues in the Opposition, those honourable senators whom I know best. I know that Government members would want to assert this in similar terms.

In recent years there has been a cry that, because Canberra is the only place in this country that allows X-rated videos to be distributed-moreover by mail order-it is the source of that kind of pornography. It is banned in every other State and in the Northern Territory. Thousands of Australians, opposed to the circulation of pornography, have called Canberra, to its shame, the porn capital. I say to Senator Richardson that we still need a remedy. The Government should join with the Opposition, which has called for several years for the national capital to be brought into line with all the States and the Northern Territory. Whilst this is a matter that many of us see as compromising family values and whilst an overt emphasis upon gambling would also undermine family values, the point I especially want to make is that this consideration was very much before the Opposition and, I understand, the Government when the Ordinance and the disallowance motion that are before us were being assessed. The Opposition spent several weeks in discussion and debate before coming to the decision-not by a great majority-to support this Ordinance which I believe indicates the seriousness and the quite genuine way in which the various elements of the debate have been weighed by us. I do not know one Opposition member or senator who has not conscientiously attended to the discussions and debate on this matter.

My views, which take in some of the arguments that I have reflected upon in my speech tonight, were not compelling to my colleagues. Because I believe very strongly in the majority principle I am moved to support the majority decision arrived at by my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties and to vote with them on this matter.

Finally, as a sample of the representations I have spoken about, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this straightforward letter written to me by the General Superintendent of the South Australian Baptist Union insofar as it represents the views of 77 Baptist churches across South Australia. I am not a member of the Baptist Church, although I am highly sympathetic with it.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
THE SOUTH AUSTRALIAN BAPTIST UNION INC.
Baptist Christian Centre
134 The Parade
Norwood S.A. 5067
5th October 1988
Senator Baden C. Teague
6 Waterloo Street
GLENELG 5045
Dear Senator Teague,
Casino Proposal for Canberra
The on-going proposal for the establishment of a casino in Canberra is a matter of great concern to members of the 77 Baptist churches across South Australia on whose behalf I am writing to you.
In the strongest yet most sincere terms I want to express deep concern and opposition to any proposal that a casino be established in the Australian Capital Territory or within close proximity to it.
There are a number of reasons for our objection-

1. A gambling facility such as a casino should not be contemplated in the national capital because it is critically important that the government should not only be above corruption but also be seen to be meticulous in its avoidance of any possible appearance of corruption. The national capital should, from every point of view, be a model city in the life of our nation.

2. The effect of gambling, particularly the losses incurred through casinos, has already been to the serious disadvantage of many individuals and families throughout the nation. Together with other community service agencies we can bear testimony to the deleterious effects on people who become caught up in casino gambling.
3. From the tourist point of view Canberra has more than needed to attract tourists as the nation's capital.

4. We are becoming increasingly concerned at the extent to which gambling is becoming rife in Australia. Constantly the media, be it the press, radio or television, bombards the constituency with ways of getting something for nothing or at minimal outlay. Inevitably envy and greed can only be the product of such efforts to involve people by the sponsoring organization.

The Government speaks much about quality of life for Australian citizens. If that is a genuine expression then on that ground alone a casino should not be established in the nation's capital. If there is not a clear overt demonstration of quality of life in terms of attitude and community standards as well in things material in the centre of government and parliament, then how can quality of life be argued for the rest of the country?

Baptist people are proud of their nation and keen to see it become a country where every citizen is treated fairly without threat or exploitation and is able to enjoy a lifestyle in which the current trends of increasing violence and crime are halted and decreased. Such an improvement is going to take the strongest possible commitment by those in leadership and individual citizens if the welfare of the whole community is to be secured.
On behalf of Baptists of South Australia I appeal to you to oppose the establishment of a casino in the national capital.
Yours sincerely,
W. C. McFARLANE
General Superintendent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President--
—Be careful with those moths.

—I just do not have a love for the moths in the way that Senator Sanders does. I do not like them at all. Given the complexity of the casino debate, I think it is important that we look at what we are being asked to resolve today. The only issue to be considered in the debate is whether we should disallow an ordinance that allows casino gambling and provides for some detailed surveillance and control over that gambling activity. The only relevant questions to be decided in the debate are whether or not a casino is appropriate to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and whether those surveillance or control measures are adequate to protect the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not being asked to approve any particular package, any particular developer, any particular operator, or indeed any particular development conditions. Hopefully, those issues will be settled by appropriate ACT authorities and, given the goodwill and good sense of the Senate in the next few weeks, I hope that would mean by an elected ACT government. The new self-governing ACT obviously should have the last say on how this project will proceed. While it might be useful to canvass some of the wider issues of the total development package, we should recognise and I hope acknowledge that the Senate is not being asked to decide these matters.

Let us look at the arguments as they have been presented tonight and over the past 12 months-the main arguments that have been advanced against the casino proceeding-and I might attempt to rebut some of them. The first argument we hear is about whether or not it is appropriate for the national capital to house a casino. Obviously a casino should not be established in any of those capital areas of the capital, and we do not propose to set up one in the car park in Parliament House or on the lawns. Rather, it is proposed for the commercial heart of the city on an area of land which currently houses two car parks, a couple of very unattractive office buildings, the inadequate Canberra Theatre and of course the Civic Square, if it can be called that, all of which would be refurbished as part of this development. The development will enliven the city centre and provide it with a new entertainment focus. I think we are all conscious of the fact that it has oft been said that Canberra is not the most exciting place on the globe, or indeed on the map of Australia; that often there has not been much in the way of attractions and entertainment. This project, hopefully, will go some of the way towards addressing that problem.

Later on I would like to refer to the economics of this project, but I think it is worth mentioning in broad terms that the casino brings with it an investment of hundreds of millions of dollars, with 2,700 jobs during the construction phase and 1,400 permanent jobs on completion. It is very difficult for any responsible political party to deny the ACT that sort of economic opportunity. Over the years members of all political parties have stressed the need for the ACT to diversify, to widen its economic base. Here is an opportunity where all of us can assist the ACT in ceasing to rely almost totally on Public Service growth and Commonwealth capital works. Hopefully, it is an opportunity the Senate will grasp.

To prevent this development would be a total contradiction of all that those senators over the years have said on that very point. This nation cannot afford to keep Canberra as a mendicant city or a mendicant city State. I would be very surprised if that were not the view of the great majority of Australians. Indeed, the disallowance motion essentially proposes that we continue treating the ACT as a special, pampered place, that we attempt to quarantine Canberra from the economic realities the rest of Australia has to face. In this context it is interesting to refer to a survey conducted recently by Dr Geoff Caldwell as part of the casino social impact study. His team arranged for a survey of community attitudes outside Canberra on whether or not a casino was considered appropriate for the national capital. I was not surprised to find that the significant majority of respondents indicated a strong view that a casino would make no difference at all to Canberra in its role as the national capital. The National Capital Development Commission has indicated that there is no planning reason why Canberra is not a valid place for a casino. I cannot see any valid argument in terms of national capital planning principles or national sentiment that the national capital is in any way such a special or sacred place that it should not have a casino.

Senator Teague referred to some of the social problems that spring from gambling, and I think that is one argument that does need to be canvassed. If the argument is about gambling, the logic of it is that all forms of gambling, and in particular the insidious poker machines, ought to be banned. There is no logic at all in saying, `You should not have a casino and you should continue with poker machines'. I have seen at first hand the sort of damage that poker machines can do, the sort of destruction they can wreak on the weak. That is well known in this country now because poker machines have been around for a very long time. There is absolutely no evidence that casino gambling in any way adds to that problem. There is no evidence that it causes new problems or increases the problems that are already there. For those who have the weakness, the outlet is always found.

The social impact study was specifically asked to address the issue and it concluded without any equivocation that it had not been able to find any evidence anywhere in Australia of increased social problems caused by gambling in casinos. I am aware that ACT opponents of the casino have referred to statements made by volunteer social workers on the Gold Coast that the existence of Jupiters Casino has brought about these extra impacts. The social impact study specifically checked this and it was informed by the relevant Queensland family services people that they were not aware of any evidence at all to support the claims being made by people here.
