Really, it is very difficult to look at those Australian cities where we now see casinos-that is, Hobart, Adelaide, Perth, Darwin, Alice Springs, Launceston, Townsville or the Gold Coast-and claim that in some way life has changed dramatically, that civilisation as they knew it would never be the same again. There is no evidence that there has been a change for the worse in those cities because a casino has been established. In fact, I would argue directly to the contrary. Obviously, therefore, any reasonable person has to conclude that claims that casinos cause any large scale personal or social degradation are based solely on myth or prejudice. There is no evidence whatsoever to back up the claim.

Senator Reid, in her contribution, referred to the argument that in some way casinos present an opportunity for crime syndicates to flourish or extend their interests; that they have opportunities to launder money via the casino or perhaps to control some other criminal activities such as blackmail, prostitution, bribery or whatever. But if one looks at the eight cities I referred to a few moments ago, there is no evidence that any of those things happened in any of them. The Casino Control Ordinance was drafted in consultation with legal and law enforcement authorities. It is pretty tough stuff. It contains the most stringent supervisory and control provisions of any legislation of its kind in Australia. The Ordinance was released for public comment in the ACT in July. The only negative reaction from the public is that some provisions appear to be too strict. Obviously the Government will undertake to consider any suggestions from any quarter relating to the control and management of the casino operation. We shall continue to keep the matter under review, but the reality is that what we have prepared has already stood the test of time.

Let me place the casino in an economic context. Earlier I gave a broad outline of money and jobs involved, but if we are to give effect to the Government's aim-and I think it is the Opposition's aim also-of diversifying the ACT economy away from an over-reliance on the Public Service or on Commonwealth construction projects, we have no other way to go. The commissioning of an economic and industry plan for the ACT will identify potential areas of new industry and employment. We have already launched a new tourism strategy for the ACT which specifies targets in terms of visitor numbers, length of stays, and infrastructure investment. One hopes that the casino project will address part of the framework. First, as a private sector construction project the development will be crucial in assisting towards creating a gradual trend to more sustainable levels of construction investment in the ACT. With the completion of the new Parliament House there is a danger that levels of investment in the ACT will fall off dramatically. We must ensure that we can trend out of that problem, and this is a pretty logical way in which to do so.

If we look at Canberra's range of attractions, the best estimate suggests that if we could get one more night only from each visitor to the ACT staying here, this would involve additional expenditure of $100m a year in the ACT. That is an investment which the ACT simply cannot do without. Obviously the casino will provide one very big extra attraction. That argument is particularly relevant when one looks at the convention industry. It is to the area of conventions that Canberra has been looking for some significant and particular increase. Furthermore, an unusually large number of school leavers will be coming onto the job market between 1989 and 1993. This casino project will provide a particular focus to ease that problem. I suggest that that will be done in a way that no other project so far mooted ever could, particularly when one bears in mind the 1,400 new jobs which will be available. For many young people who will be leaving schools in those years there will be real hope of a job and they will not be forced to leave the ACT to seek employment elsewhere. The figures of 2,700 jobs in the construction phase and 1,400 permanent new jobs have never really been challenged. I do not believe the ACT can afford to do without this project. It must be remembered that practically every major group involved in private sector activity in the ACT recognises the economic value and need for this project. It is one time when the union movement and the private sector have been as one because they know the need for jobs and for investment.

To look at the development as a whole-it is not being decided tonight but it is worth saying a few words about it-there is provision for new community facilities, particularly a theatre and a library. The site is worth an enormous amount of money. Preliminary estimates of the site value by Jebb Associates in consultation with Price Waterhouse concluded that the value of the site would be $57m in 1990 prices, assuming that a 20 per cent tax rate applies to the casino operation. The value of the site would increase by $4m for each one per cent by which the 20 per cent tax might be reduced. For example, the site value in 1990 prices would go as high as $77.7m if the tax rate were 15 per cent. Those estimates show just what sort of investment will be required for this project.

In regard to community facilities, Tom Brown Pty Ltd in association with Rider Hunt estimated that a new 2,000-seat lyric theatre, a refurbished Canberra Playhouse and a small performing arts venue would cost between $36m and $42m in 1988 prices to construct and running costs would be of the order of $1.5m a year. In relation to the library, even with the savings that come from the scaling down or closing of the existing library service at Kingston, we are still looking at a very major investment indeed. This all adds up to some very big money, and I would have thought that an investment of that kind at the moment is precisely what the ACT needs.

Let me turn to the role of an incoming ACT government-and one hopes that government will be coming in the not very distant future, provided that Senator Hill and some others do the right thing. Decisions about this development will rightfully be made by those new ACT authorities. It is contradictory to suggest, when decisions on final project specifications depend upon market conditions at the time, that the Senate should disallow the Casino Ordinance today in order to allow a decision on the matter by the ACT in six months. Management of the development will require that the ACT government in due course will be in total control of this project. But to get maximum benefit in the decisions taken on the development itself one appreciates that a decision on this Ordinance will have to be taken as soon as possible. The Government will ensure a normal caretaker period of administration of the ACT prior to the House of Assembly election in February 1989, but we see no reason to stop taking decisions about the ACT in November this year. The Senate should simply vote on the casino issue on its merits. If it does, it has little choice but to vote against the disallowance motion which, if carried, would deprive Canberra of the only real light on the hill, the only real chance for employment and investment growth that Canberra so desperately needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly on the subject of the Canberra casino because I know many local people who will be very disappointed at the decision made by Opposition parties today which effectively will give the green light to the proposal. I come from Western Australia where we have a casino. It is out of the city centre on the other side of the Swan River away from the city, but I note that in Canberra the proposed site would form the third vertex of the parliamentary triangle. I feel that this is hardly suitable for the nation's capital; nor do I feel it is suitable for the nation's capital to become a gambling den. I am one of the people who were disparagingly referred to earlier by Senator McMullan as being opposed to gambling.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no demonstrable demand for a casino in Canberra. It is just seen as a way to raise money and, as has been made very clear by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), it is a dollars and cents issue. The dollar sign is largely before the eyes of the developers, the Australian Labor Party, and now, unfortunately, the Opposition as well. In the short term, of course, it will create some jobs in the construction phase. The trade unions and builders have seized on the casino simply because of jobs in the short term, but surely there are plenty of other building opportunities as alternatives in the near or more distant future-such as a national museum, the new town at Gungahlin in the 1990s, more hotels to cater for tourism in the national capital, and the oft-called for library-theatre-hotel complex without a casino.

I am also concerned about organised crime. The thorough inquiry in Victoria conducted by Mr Xavier Connor, QC, in 1982-83 pointed out that there would be a substantial risk that in one way or another casinos would be infiltrated by organised crime elements. This reflected an earlier warning in 1974 by Mr Justice Moffitt in New South Wales as well as from various experiences in the United States of America in places like Atlantic City. Both Victoria and New South Wales have rejected casino proposals and, I believe, for very good reasons.

Finally, I want to refer to the opposition by the churches. My own denomination in Canberra, the Religious Society of Friends; or Quakers, has spoken out strongly against the proposed casino. I note too the opposition expressed by the New South Wales Synod of the Uniting Church in Australia, the Anglican Diocese of Canberra and Goulburn and just about every other church group in the city. They referred to the inappropriate nature of a casino in the nation's capital, questioned the economic benefits and referred to a likely massive increase in social and family problems. This has also been the concern of numerous community groups dealing with various social welfare issues. I believe this issue should have been decided by the people of Canberra after self-government. It is obviously an issue which crosses party lines. I commend the opposition by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who has the guts to stand up for issues of moral importance, as well as some people in the Liberal Party of Australia who opposed it until this morning and, of course, the Australian Democrats.

In this matter I fully support my colleague Senator Jenkins's disallowance motion. My voice from Western Australia will not count for much but I feel that on an issue like this and, coming from a State with a casino, I should register my opposition and state my firm support for those people of Canberra opposed to a casino who have been denied a chance to express their opposition in the absence of self-government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly oppose this casino. I wonder why the Liberals crumbled under pressure. They opposed the casino. The National and Liberal coalition apparently opposed the casino until quite recently. Then it crumbled under pressure. I wonder who put it under pressure and what that pressure was that forced it to change its mind?

SPEECH.PARA: The Hobart casino has been mentioned in this chamber by Senator Reid and Senator Hill as an example of a wonderful establishment which has won the approval of all the local residents. That is utter rubbish. One of the most polite names it is called, that I can think of, is that giant white phallic symbol on the shoreline. It is besmirching the river view of local residents. It dominates the area. It has taken up valuable foreshore. As far as the effect on the community is concerned, if one walks around in it as I do, one does not see the high rollers coming from mainland States to play the big high stake tables. What one sees is the Moonah mums, the women from the working class suburbs of Moonah and Glenorchy, just mindlessly pulling away at levers on poker machines. It has disrupted the fabric of the community.

The fact that this is being debated now at all and that the concept has been accepted by the Government and the Liberal Party of Australia is curious in itself. Why are the Government and the Opposition so keen to ram this thing through just before the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) will get self-determination? Why are they so eager to put this in motion? They are eager because they are afraid that if this were left to the people of the ACT they would turn it down. That is why they are so eager to establish this now. They know that the people of the ACT do not want it. Yet, those who are behind this project and who have pressured the Government and the Opposition are so eager to go ahead that they do not want to take any chances because they want this thing to go ahead now.

What are we to do? We Democrats, and others in this chamber who would like to speak out against this but who cannot because their parties have already spoken for them, can continue to oppose it. We can oppose the casino now; we can continue to oppose it after the ACT elections. Hopefully we will have some members in that government. Hopefully other members will be in the ACT parliament who will be opposed to this. We have to continue the battle.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will need guts to stand up and be counted.

—As Senator Coulter interjected quietly, people will have to be gutsy enough to stand up and be counted. One thing that worries me is organised crime. We have bounced around this issue. Let us be serious. Let us look at this for what it is. Of course, this casino will be run by organised crime. Does anyone in this chamber or in this country really think that organised crime would let a money spinner like this go by? Does anyone really sincerely think that the present casinos are not run by organised crime? I come from America; I know about organised crime. I know about organised crime buying and selling labour unions and big businesses. Organised crime is not a sleazy little guy with a black shirt, a white tie and a fedora; it is big business. People in organised crime are in the business of making money. They run casinos. They run the casinos in Australia. They will run this casino. Why should we give them a leg up? Unfortunately we will.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue-I suppose I really should not be worried about it-is the economic viability of the casino. If it does not work well who will bail it out? How many casinos can this country take? When Hobart casino was the casino in Australia people used to come from the mainland. But now, as Senator Richardson I think pointed out, we have casinos in all the major centres, plus Alice Springs and Launceston. How big is the pool of gamblers? Will we have to increase the pool of gamblers to make this thing viable or will it simply be taking people away who would gamble on the dogs and horses? What will happen if, in fact, the gamblers do not come to the casino? Who is going to bail it out-the Government probably or the citizens.

We have also heard about the value of the casino as a construction project. How long will we try to run an economy on the basis of constantly building things? What a naive view; what a sophomoric view, a high school view, of how to run an economy by saying, `Build something else because we now have a Parliament House. Let's find something else to build'. I ask Senator Walsh: Is that the most imaginative economic prospect we have? Do we have to continue to build things? Is that the only way we can run an economy? Cannot we be more imaginative than that in the late twentieth century? I guess not. If we must build something, why not the national museum? That has been suggested before tonight and it has been suggested tonight in this chamber. Why not build a national museum if we must build something? Why not? We cannot build it because there is no big money in it. It is something that would benefit all of Australia and not just a few rich entrepreneurs. That is why we are not going to get the national museum. Why not build some low cost housing around Canberra? Why not do what the Australian Labor Party is supposed to be doing rather than just giving a benefit to its rich buddies, the rich multinationals and the rich Australian nationals? Let us do something for the people. The best thing we can do for the people is stop the construction of this casino immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this motion, which is, of course, a motion to disallow the Casino Control Ordinance 1988 which if not disallowed will provide for the construction of a casino complex in Canberra. In doing so, I want to express some personal views on this matter, personal views which in part, I concede freely, stem from the fact that for over 30 years, with some absences overseas, I was a resident of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) before wiser counsels prevailed, shall I say. Partly for that reason, I still have many friends and former colleagues in the Capital Territory. I am particularly aware-quite apart from the information which I imagine most senators have been deluged with on this matter over recent weeks-that the casino proposal has been vigorously opposed by many whom I make no bones about describing as the most decent people in Canberra. Many of them are my personal friends.

SPEECH.PARA: We have, of course, heard arguments, particularly from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, who has just left the chamber, that the ACT must have this casino in order to sustain the construction industry. What a total nonsense to put forward as an argument for such a proposal. What we have is an unholy alliance of contractors with the Builders Labourers Federation. There is a peculiar irony in honourable senators preparing to so move as to allow the casino complex to proceed. That is what it boils down to in practice. It is peculiarly appropriate that we should be doing that in this Parliament House which is itself, as we are rapidly coming to discover, a white elephant, a monument to the same unholy alliance to which I have just referred of contractors and the Builders Labourers Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been done in.

—I make that remark, since the Minister for Finance has in some slightly unintelligible manner interjected, on a bipartisan basis, on the basis of views on both sides of this chamber. But I do not propose to be diverted by the Minister, particularly at this hour of the evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it passing strange in any case to have it suggested that somehow the property development on section 19 in the ACT, in Canberra city, cannot proceed unless the casino is part of it. I do not want to spend time debating the rather sad issues now. Earlier this evening we heard speeches by three senators on my side of the chamber. We heard speeches by Senator Hill and Senator Reid in support of the proposal, and we heard Senator Teague expressing-I do not wish to misrepresent or criticise Senator Teague; he is no longer here in any case-the gravest doubts about the proposal while at the same time quite properly indicating his intention to vote in accordance with the decision on this matter of the coalition joint party room.

In coming to my own views on this matter, I find myself on balance in sympathy with Senator Teague's views. I repeat `on balance' because I am perfectly well aware that there are respectable arguments in favour of this proposal-not many of them have been advanced from the Government side of the chamber, but that is another matter-just as there are very respectable arguments, in fact more respectable arguments, at this stage against it. So I find myself a good deal more in sympathy with the views expressed on this side of the chamber by Senator Teague than with the views of his other two Liberal Party senator colleagues. But the key point I wish to make is that very shortly we shall have self-government in the ACT. This Government, I think with the support of this Parliament, is proposing to impose self-government upon the ACT whether the people of the ACT want it or not. In that sense, the procedure being adopted is precisely the same as the procedure being adopted in respect of the casino proposal. Whether the people of the ACT want it or not, it will be imposed upon them by this Government and, I have to concede, by this Parliament, including the coalition parties. I make it clear in passing that I, like Senator Teague-although I express the gravest reservations about the course being adopted on this matter-will vote against the disallowance of the Ordinance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because that is the decision of my joint party room on the matter this day. I do not happen to feel that this is such a matter of personal crisis-in my case at least-that it would in any way justify my abstaining from the vote or crossing the floor. I do not propose to do that any more than Government senators would in such a case. My only difference from Government senators is that I am expressing my view about the matter and not attempting to defend what I regard as less than wholly defensible.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular reason why I regard this outcome as disappointing is that, by its actions tonight, this Parliament will indicate that it simply does not trust the people of the ACT to make up their own minds on this matter. As I say, we are going to have self-government in the ACT in the very near future, and it would have seemed to me, in those circumstances, appropriate that this Parliament should mind its own business. There is no pressing requirement for Commonwealth parliamentarians to make up their minds on what is in effect a local authority issue. We could have left it for the proposed self-governing body of the ACT to come to a view upon this matter, whether in the exercise of its own authority or through what I personally would have regarded as the more appropriate course: the institution of a referendum of the people of the ACT as to whether they wanted a casino in this city, in their home town. It is highly regrettable that we have not taken that course. Nevertheless, I have indicated that I shall join my colleagues of the coalition parties in voting against the motion to disallow the Ordinance this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a sad, sick and, I would say, hopeless society we are when we have a matter being debated in the highest council of this land, the Senate of the Parliament of Australia, and a number of people who, in conscience bound, are saying that they are opposed to a very significant development in this city, and yet at the same time are saying that they are not prepared to vote according to their conscience. Where is democracy if the people who vote for people in this place cannot rely on those people using their judgment on each issue to vote on those issues according to their conscience, but are prepared to be persuaded by what I believe-in at least one party-to be a minority of a party to vote against their conscience on something that they feel as strongly about as does Senator Stone.

SPEECH.PARA: What a sad society it is when as a government we have to provide entertainment on an ever more frenetic and degrading scale by providing such things as casinos. I take on board the arguments posed by Senator Sanders and Senator Stone that we seem to have an economic system such that, when there is a downturn in the building industry, we simply have to build something more. What do we do when we have built a casino? Do we build a brothel or something like that? That would be a good money spinner, too. What do we build next? We simply cannot continue until the whole countryside is covered by concrete, bricks and bitumen. At some point it must stop. We should decide sensibly when to stop that process. We should not continue to cover the countryside with buildings simply because we have a difficulty in providing employment.

Senator Richardson argued that the casino would generate wealth. The casino would generate no wealth whatsoever. I sense that the Government and the Opposition do not understand what wealth is. One cannot eat casinos, live in casinos or dress oneself in casinos. Casinos provide a means of circulating wealth which has been created elsewhere in the economy. As Senator Sanders has pointed out, that wealth is circulated mainly from those least able to afford to spend money to those who are extremely wealthy. My God, we really are a sick society. I have visited the Adelaide casino only once. It distressed me greatly when the South Australian Government saw fit to build that casino. I went there one night when Senator Jenkins visited South Australia and, because this debate was coming up, she wanted to look at the casino. It was the most depressing spectacle I have seen in a long time. The only people in that casino who were smiling were some of the croupiers. Everybody else had a desperate appearance of sadness and a desperate sense of not knowing what the hell they were there for. There was certainly no sense of pleasure.

Where do we go in this frenetic search for artificial stimulation? What happens in casinos when we have exhausted the possibility of increasing the prize money, of providing more games for people to play? It was suggested in a very amusing but rather sick article that I read some years ago that perhaps negative prizes as well as positive prizes should be provided. Besides being able to win $10, $100, $1,000 or $250,000, which are some of the prizes that can be won, prizes might include a day in gaol or having one's left hand chopped off. The extreme prize in that scale would be winning the prize to be beheaded. Is that where society is heading? Does society need to gain cheap, artificial thrills by those sorts of mechanisms? I suggest that if that is the road on which we are travelling, we are indeed a sick society. There are a great many more productive things we could do with our money, our wealth and our ability to build things than to build casinos.

Senator Sanders mentioned the criminal element. Of course, it depends how one defines the criminal element. It might be defined very narrowly as those who go out as hired guns and shoot people. But it might be defined as including those people who have become extremely rich. There is a small number of people in our society who have become extremely rich under this Labor Government at the expense of the vast number of Australians who have become much poorer. In my view many of those people are criminals. At the moment in Western Australia there is the spectacle of a government which has, I believe, significantly repressed information from the Western Australian public who have been asked to subscribe large amounts of money to a number of enterprises, one of which was the Western Australian casino. I understand that the operation of the Western Australian casino was about to be investigated by the National Companies and Securities Commission. That investigation was called off because of other dealings in which the Western Australian Government was involved with those gentlemen who were concerned with the building of that casino.

It seems to me that the casino by its very nature will certainly attract, at the very least, those undesirable elements who will profit from a casino and who will also generate an attitude in society which certainly is not in the interests of lifting the quality of the society in which we live. If there has been an indication throughout history of the failure and dissolution of civilisation, it has been those societies which have tended to provide more of the bread and circus type of activity. That is precisely what this Government and other governments around Australia have been proposing recently. I think for these reasons we should strongly support this disallowance motion and support those people in Canberra who are, quite rightly, opposed to the establishment of a casino in this city.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to conclude this debate on my motion for the disallowance of the Casino Control Ordinance. I could have taken all the speeches delivered in the Senate this evening and used them to prove my own case. In fact, virtually every one who has spoken has given arguments against the development of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). It is the perception of the Australian Democrats that the people of Canberra do not want a casino. I know that a number of polls have been conducted. As I conceded when I spoke previously-I agree with Senator McMullan-some of the polls may have been suspect. But nonetheless it is our considered opinion that the majority of people in the ACT do not want to have a casino built in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: We also concede that there is some division of opinion in the community, and that has also been conceded by a number of other speakers. We believe for this and other reasons-unlike the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who spoke earlier-this matter should be decided by the people who will directly represent the people of the ACT, that is, the people who will sit in the future House of Assembly of the ACT. These people will, hopefully, be responsive to the wishes of the people of the ACT. We believe it should be left to them to decide on this issue.

I also agree with Senator McMullan that there is something intrinsically offensive about Federal parliamentarians from all over Australia deciding what is good for the people who live in the ACT. This is certainly a local matter. I am assured by the President of the ACT National Council of Women that surveys conducted in Canberra have shown that a majority of women in the ACT oppose the casino. A letter in the Canberra Times on 31 October 1988 stated:

The casino is one obvious example, and many of us who do not particularly oppose it as such are nevertheless furious that a decision is being taken for us just a few months before we can decide it for ourselves. Mr Holding has emphasised the jobs to be created in the Section 19 development, and remarked that ``no-one has come forward'' with an alternative to the casino. But how on earth can Canberra citizens gain access now to all the relevant facts? We need elected representatives with the energy and the powers to obtain facts and consider alternatives.
Mr Holding needs to realise that he is a caretaker; all major planning decisions must await self-government . . .

The Australian Democrats fully concur with those sentiments. The bureaucrats who, in the absence of a democratically elected assembly, currently really govern the Australian Capital Territory have decided that the Australian Capital Territory should have a casino. We read only recently in the Canberra Times the danger of having bureaucrats making planning decisions of that sort. The front page of the Canberra Times on Tuesday, 1 November, said:
One of the ACT Administration's most senior executives . . . has been detached from his duties . . . business interests were incompatible with him being a senior officer of the administration.
It went on to say:
`There is no suggestion of any impropriety and no suggestion that he has done anything wrong, but there is a possible appearance of incompatibility.

I am not suggesting that the bureaucrats necessarily make decisions which will personally help fill their own pockets. On the other hand, it is not correct that people who are not elected and therefore not directly responsible to people who live here should be making these sorts of decisions. The decision was made originally by bureaucrats. It was then endorsed by the Australian Labor Party Cabinet and presumably by Caucus.

As we know, because it has been in all the newspapers, and Senator Hill spoke on this, the Opposition took some time; it had meetings virtually every day this week while it made its decision. I agree with Senator Hill's statement that this is a very important issue and, as we are forcibly placed in a situation of having to make decisions on behalf of the people of the Australian Capital Territory, I agree that it is the duty of the people here to take time making that decision. It appears that the Opposition did change its mind during the week. It was placed in a position of having to decide whether to support the will of the people or the will of the developers or whoever else is pulling the strings. Some details of the debates that were held by the coalition Opposition were in the newspapers. We know that earlier in the week there were 14 speakers against the casino and three in favour. I believe, in a later debate, there were seven speakers against and two in favour of the casino. At the latest meeting, I believe that there were six speakers for and six against. It was after that meeting that the final decision was made, not as a result of a vote.

It appears, therefore, that the decision was finally reached in a very strange way. I see it-and I think a lot of people in the ACT will see it-as a betrayal. It appears that the final decision was caught up in a leadership battle which is going on. There can be no greater treason than the wrong thing being done for the wrong reason. We know that the shadow Cabinet, which was in favour of it, finally won the day. This is a matter of extreme regret to us all.

I spoke earlier of strings being pulled, and I am not the only person to speak in this direction. The honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) whilst speaking in the lower House said, `Somebody up there wants a casino. ``Jump'', he says. They answer, ``How high and how soon?''.' Minister Holding said that the decision on a casino `can't wait'. There appears to be an indecent haste as far as this issue is concerned. I think this was what happened as far as the Opposition was concerned when it was making up its mind: it was caught between a rock and a hard place. It knows that most Canberrans do not want a casino.

The President of the ACT Liberal Party also wrote an article in the Canberra Times and, unlike Mr Holding, he is unhappy about the decisions which affect the people of Canberra being made by people who live somewhere else. Even he, as a Liberal spokesperson, conceded that perhaps a majority of Canberrans are not so readily convinced of the benefits of a casino. I quote from an article in the Canberra Times on 6 October of this year by the President of the ACT Liberal Party:
It is one of the enduring ironies of the ACT's pre-self-government status that all the crucial decisions about our future are being made by outsiders.
Chief among these is the decision whether or not to build a casino in Canberra.
The ACT Liberal Party, like the Canberra community in general, has been heavily divided on the issue.
Some, . . . see nothing but good flowing from a casino and believe the problems it might generate, if any, can be addressed at some time in the future.
Others, perhaps a majority of Canberrans, are not so readily convinced.

Senator Hill has also admitted that about 50 per cent of the Canberra community will be unhappy anyway: all the more reason to allow the ACT local government assembly, which is likely to be in place in the early months of next year, to decide on the casino issue because there are a lot of issues at stake here. There is the issue of whether to have a casino or not; the location; and the whole of the section 19 development, with the theatre and the library. It is far more appropriate that an assembly to be elected, I hope democratically, by the people of the ACT should be the decision-makers on this issue.

It is also appallingly insensitive of the Government to seek to push the casino development through by ordinance. I know we have no option because that is the way Territories are governed, but self-government is so near and an ordinance for Territories under the control of the Federal Government is not one of our most democratic legislative procedures. It reeks of the old colonial days. There is no scope for open and formalised introduction of a measure into the House and there is also no possibility of amendments or open discussion during the committee stage as we have with legislation. It is just a `take it or leave it' situation. If an ordinance is not disallowed then no debate is possible and it simply passes through unseen.

To impose a casino on the people of the ACT by way of ordinance, which is supported by the two bigger parties in the Senate-I exclude the National Party of Australia because it has seven senators, the same number as the Australian Democrats have-I feel is improper, especially with self-determination and self-management for the people of the ACT just around the corner. I regard that as nothing short of a political disgrace.

I gave the reasons for the Democrats' opposition to a casino in Canberra in my speech on 14 October. I think a lot of things I have said have been summed up rather nicely by other speakers in this debate. Since then there has been even more debate. There has been debate in the media on open line shows and on Pru Goward's show earlier this week, when 21 people phoned on the morning of 1 November. There were 19 against the casino and two in favour. I listened very carefully to the reasons given by the people who were against it. The main reasons were that Canberra, as our national capital, is not a suitable location for a casino and that the rationale that it will create plenty of jobs and be a great economic investment has flaws in it. They also looked at what is happening in other States in Australia. They believe it will bring undesirable influences into the city. Of the two people who rang in favour of the casino, one gave as the reason excitement; and the other, entertainment. I addressed those issues in my earlier speech so I will say no more on that score at the moment.

Senator Hill raised the issue of night life. There is no casino in Melbourne or Sydney. Does that mean those cities have no night life, no excitement, no entertainment? Senator McMullan stated that we should have a legal casino, otherwise we will have an illegal one.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already got it.

—If we followed that argument, we would legalise everything. There would be no criminals at all, would there? Senator McMullan also asks the Senate to accept the economic value of the casino without our having any real details about it. I believe his argument is a spurious one. Senator Teague made a most sincere contribution and advocated that we as legislators and parliamentarians should promote family life and seek to educate people. If he was also saying that a casino is good enough for the uneducated, the disadvantaged and those without any family life, he should think again.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid mentioned the old Parliament House, and I too am most concerned about what will happen to that building and the fact that the cockroaches are the only ones rushing around there. I would like to take up that issue with her later. Senator Richardson said that he could not see why the Federal Parliament should be hesitant about allowing a casino for the national capital, but a number of people believe that it is simply not appropriate. Canberra, as well as being the national capital, is home for the majority of permanent residents of the ACT. As I said before, they should have a direct input into the decision through their now assembly. Senator Richardson said there was no way to go other than the path we are now following, but let an ACT assembly be the judge of that. I can see no reason to accept that statement on trust, or the suggestion that levels of investment would trail off.

We also heard that the casino would induce many people to spend one extra night in Canberra, which would indeed fill the coffers. I guess we could do lots of things to persuade people to spend one extra night in Canberra. Perhaps there could be a public hanging, because I am sure people would stay an extra night to watch that. I guess that is something else that could be legalised. Just as people's opinions on gambling are divided, so are some for and some against capital punishment. It was suggested that casino gambling is no different from other forms of gambling. It is different. I think it is discriminatory for people to oppose casino gambling but not any other form of gambling, just as it is discriminatory to ban chemical weapons-a ban with which I think we would all agree-when there are other forms of weapons available. A similar analogy is our treatment of hard drugs and headache powders.
A number of other issues were raised, including tourism. I quote a report of comments by Mr Issenberg, a director of tourism with the consultants Horwath and Horwath:

Contrary to popular myth, Mr Issenberg said, casinos did not lure more international tourists into the market . . . With fewer locals gambling interstate, the casinos are now vying for what the trade calls `high rollers'.

I think the point has already been made about the building industry, but I make it as well: we cannot cover the whole continent with buildings just to provide jobs. There has to be a rationality to the building programs. The Federal Government has been in charge of the building program for Canberra, and it is a poor state of affairs for it to have left the construction workers in the lurch, as it appears has happened, and to bribe them with jobs, using the casino project as an issue, not in order. I quote also from a letter in the Canberra Times of 26 September written by the Vice-President of the ACT branch of the Society of St Vincent de Paul about the effects of the casino in Queensland:

. . . we have at least a few tourists each week who lose everything (often early in their holiday) and do not have funds with which to continue their holiday or to return home. If they have prepaid their accommodation, we help with food vouchers or we are asked to provide a bus fare to where they came from.

We saw in the press quite recently the story of a public servant who admitted that he had forged or falsely presented 232 cheques totalling $2.3m, most of which he used to maintain his gambling addiction in the Alice Springs casino. The cases go on.

I conclude briefly by saying that opinion is divided. I am disappointed that when we divide now it will be along party lines. It would have been far more appropriate for there to have been a conscience vote as to a great extent it is a moral issue. I am disappointed that the major parties have not allowed their members a conscience vote.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Jenkins's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As it was advanced in the debate that the racing industry in the Australian Capital Territory might not benefit from the casino-and indeed might suffer as a result of it-I thought I should declare that I have had an interest in two racehorses in the ACT. I might add that that fact did not influence my vote substantially and, secondly, the form of those horses has been such that I have been a net contributor to that industry for some time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of considerable importance which is particularly relevant this evening-that is, the matter of the greenhouse effect and, specifically, the contribution which nuclear energy may make to solving that problem. This is particularly relevant because tonight we have the beginning of a three-day conference in all capital cities and many lesser cities around Australia on the greenhouse problem. That conference is being organised by the Commission for the Future and tonight there will be a national television and satellite hook-up between all those cities participating.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also relevant because in the newspapers in the last couple of days there have been a number of letters and articles which involve senators and in which a number of statements have been made which can be demonstrated to be completely false. For instance in today's Melbourne Age under a heading `Minister says nuclear power an option to beat greenhouse' we find that the Minister for the Arts, Sport the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is quoted as saying:
. . . nuclear energy was an option that might have to be re-examined to counter the greenhouse effect.
In today's Australian Financial Review we find, under the headline `Absurd political restriction on uranium', a letter from Senator David Hamer stating:

. . . Senator John Coulter . . . is correct in stating that we must offset the greenhouse effect through alternative and more efficient energy sources. However, he fails, in the true tradition of the Australian Democrats, to offer any viable and worthwhile solutions to a very serious problem.
He goes on:

There is no doubt that the cause of the greenhouse effect is the rising level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere as a result of the widespread use of fossil fuels for electric power generation. There is no reasonable likelihood of a reduction in the worldwide amount of power generated.

Both those statements are completely false. There is also an article in this week's Bulletin headed, `Back to the minefield', which discusses the possibility of problems within Australian Labor Party ranks over uranium mining. Again it has Senator Richardson claiming that nuclear power may well be an answer to the greenhouse effect.

There are a number of reasons why these assertions are false and I think it is important to get them into the record. The principal among them is that the contribution which carbon dioxide is making to greenhouse warming will be approximately 50 per cent over the next 40 to 50 years. Over the next 40 to 50 years approximately 50 per cent of greenhouse warming will be generated by non-carbon dioxide gases-by a number of other gases, principally methane, nitrous oxide, water vapour and a range of gases of lower concentration, such as chlorofluorocarbons, nonetheless adding up to approximately 50 per cent of the warming. Addressing the problem of carbon dioxide through the use of nuclear energy could affect only 50 per cent of the problem.

The situation is much more pessimistic than that because, at the moment, nuclear energy can provide only electricity. Around the world only some 10 per cent to 15 per cent of energy is used as electricity. So the contribution which nuclear power could make to solving the greenhouse problem, even if the whole world were to go to nuclear power for electricity generation, would be somewhere between 5 per cent and 7 1/2 per cent. So 5 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent of the greenhouse problem could be addressed if the whole world shifted from coal generated electricity and electricity generated from natural gas and petroleum totally to nuclear power.

There are a number of other reasons why nuclear power is not a solution to the greenhouse effect. In fact, the advent of nuclear power will exacerbate the greenhouse problem. Throughout the 1960s and 1970s the argument for nuclear energy was based on a continuation in the growth rate of energy consumption that had occurred in the 2 1/2 decades after the Second World War. This scenario led to wild predictions that large numbers of power stations would be built. So far these predictions have failed to materialise. But it was in these growth scenarios that the consumption of fossil fuel continued to rise along with, and to some extent because of, the advent of nuclear energy. The sixth report of the United Kingdom Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution, entitled Nuclear Power and the Environment, chaired by Sir Brian Flowers, himself a commissioner of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Agency, looked quite specifically at whether the advent of nuclear power would reduce the consumption of fossil fuel in the developed world. It came to the conclusion, and it states this quite specifically, that the advent of nuclear power would increase the consumption of fossil fuel. It stated:

The proposition seems plausible but we are not convinced by it. The high demands of industrialised countries for fossil fuels will continue for many years, not least to sustain the economic growth which would be required to support large and costly nuclear programmes. We find it hard to see that nuclear development will release fossil fuels to an important extent unless-
and this is the important consideration-
the political will were to exist in industrialised nations to bring this about by a large re-distribution of income and this does not appear likely.

The reasons for that conclusion were several. Firstly, as I have already indicated, nuclear energy provides electricity only. To the extent that this electricity is used in factories in a growth-orientated economy, increasing amounts of materials must be transported to, and finished goods transported from, the factories. Transport is based on fossil fuels and will continue to be into the foreseeable future. Moreover, not all the energy-using processes in factories use electricity. Most extraction and processing which makes materials available to manufacturers is fossil fuel based-for instance, metal smelting and chemical manufacturing. Moreover, nuclear energy is capital intensive. It is particularly capital intensive at the front end. To generate this upfront capital to build nuclear power stations implies a growing economy with sufficiently rapid growth in investment capital. This is an economy which uses more fossil fuel, at the very least, while it makes the transition to nuclear power.

In this connection it is highly significant that, in 1973 and 1974, when the price of oil went up there was not an increase in the building of nuclear power stations as we might have expected. On the contrary, with the exception of France, nuclear power station orders went into a steep decline from which they have not yet recovered. Thus, in both its development and its use nuclear power is linked to increasing fossil fuel consumption-not to decreasing fossil fuel consumption.

As I have said, around the world electricity accounts for only about 10 per cent to 15 per cent of the energy processed by man. I stress the word `processed' because a great deal is misunderstood about our use of energy. The total amount of energy used by human beings is about 99.99 per cent solar energy. We have only to consider the enormous inputs of solar energy in the growing of crops and the processes of drying those crops and in other products to realise that. In Australia, about 50 per cent of processed energy is used in transport and practically all of this is derived from liquid fossil fuels. As yet, there is no practical technology which would allow energy used in transport to be derived from nuclear sources.

If nuclear could substitute for fossil one would have expected an increase in nuclear power station orders following the 1973-74 oil price rise. But, as I have already mentioned, this did not happen. Nuclear power station orders were cancelled in droves. To the slight extent that oil was being used for electricity generation at that stage, there was some conversion to nuclear. However, it is clear that in the last 15 years-and there are abundant articles which attest to this fact-conservation of energy has made a far greater contribution to United States energy availability than to nuclear. For instance, in 1980 the world used energy at the rate of just under 10 terrowatts. This was made up as follows: 4.2 terrowatts from oil; 2.4 terrowatts from coal; 1.7 terrowatts from gas; 1.7 terrowatts from renewables; and 0.2 terrowatts from nuclear. In other words, we were getting about one-eighth of the amount of energy from nuclear sources as we were getting from renewable sources.

These changes which occurred post 1973-74 illustrate a number of things: firstly, the close linking of nuclear and economic growth with the associated growth of fossil fuel consumption-a point to which I have already referred; secondly, the inability of nuclear to substitute for fossil either technically or economically; and, thirdly, the greater contribution that can be made to energy availability and to reduction of carbon dioxide release by conservation.

The greenhouse effect describes the transmission of short wave radiation from the sun, through the atmosphere, to the earth's surface and the blocking of longer wave radiation, radiating back from the earth's surface out into space. As I have indicated, there are a number of gases which contribute to this greenhouse effect, and it turns out that approximately half of the greenhouse warming is due to carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide has increased from about 270 parts per million in the pre-industrial age to about 345 parts per million since industrialisation. At present, the rate of increase of carbon dioxide is approximately half a per cent per year. Nitrous oxide is increasing in the atmosphere at approximately 0.6 per cent per year-substantially faster than carbon dioxide. Some of this arises from fossil fuel combustion, but substantial amounts come from the use of nitrogen fertilisers and the clearing of forests. Atmosphere methane is increasing at 1.1 per cent per annum-more than twice as fast as carbon dioxide. The principal sources of this are ruminant animals, rice paddies and extensive areas of water-covered and anaerobic soils. The increase in atmospheric methane has closely paralleled world population growth over the last 600 years, and there are very good statistics on this from ice core samples. The two freons which we debated at some length this afternoon-freon 11 and freon 12-are increasing at between five and seven per cent per annum. They are some 10,000 times more effective as greenhouse gases than carbon dioxide. The only reason that carbon dioxide overshadows them is that it is present in much higher concentration.

The increase in all these gases is arising from population and economic growth-more people demanding more from a finite earth. This pattern of population growth plus economic growth is being promoted by precisely the same people-we have many of them in this chamber-and interests that are promoting nuclear energy. If this growth model continues to be pursued, the greenhouse problem can only get worse. It will become more intractable and these serious consequences will become inevitable. Nuclear power will do little to mitigate this problem and it is likely to exacerbate it.

In the alternative conserver society model which is proposed by the Australian Democrats, nuclear energy is unnecessary. Much more efficient use of energy is readily achievable, and that has been demonstrated in a number of countries, given the political will. I point to the figures for Australia, the United States and China because it is often argued-I think Senator Hamer argues-that Third World countries do not have an option but to increase their consumption of energy. China uses energy at about one-quarter the efficiency of Japan. For instance, China uses 40.9 megajoules of energy per dollar value added, compared with only 19.3 megajoules in the United States and 9.7 megajoules per dollar value added in Japan. So there is enormous scope, even in countries like Japan, to increase availability of energy by going down the road to greater efficiency.

The final argument that I think is worth stressing is that in considering alternative paths to a solution to a problem-and here we are considering alternative paths to a solution to the greenhouse problem-we need to look at comparing those paths which will be most efficient, in other words, give the best return-in this case the greatest reduction in carbon dioxide addition to the atmosphere-for a given investment. A recent study carried out in the United States looked at the capital and running costs of nuclear energy and compared the costs of implementing increased efficiency programs. The figures work out like this: increasing the efficiency of use of electricity is seven times more productive in terms of cost than building nuclear power stations; seven times more effective for efficiency improvements compared with nuclear power stations.

What that means in dollar terms is that for every $100 invested in nuclear power that could have been spent on improvements in efficiency, an extra tonne of carbon dioxide is added to the atmosphere. In other words, pursuing nuclear energy as a solution to greenhouse again increases the problems of greenhouse rather than decreases it. I point out that this very thorough study used extremely favourable costing for nuclear power and yet even so showed that with a greatly accelerated program of nuclear power station building-that is, of 1,000 megawatts every 1.6 days and the expenditure of $787 billion each year, representing a 29-fold worldwide expansion over the next 40 years-greenhouse warming would only be ameliorated by between 20 and 35 per cent.

For all these very sound reasons, nuclear power is not a solution to greenhouse and attempting to argue for nuclear power in this way is extremely counterproductive because it diverts attention from those areas to which we should be giving our greatest attention, namely, improvements in efficiency. On the contrary, the argument for adopting nuclear power is predicated on assumptions, all of which will make the greenhouse problem worse. The one lesson we should have learnt by now, not least from the major global greenhouse weather shift, is that attempting to apply technical solutions to what are basically social, political and economic problems usually compounds these problems and makes them even more intractable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My subject is not nearly as exotic as that put by Senator Coulter. It is directed to you, Mr President, and I am certain that you have the matter under control and have all the answers. It would not have escaped your attention that the moths that have now invaded this building are at the stage where they are almost intolerable, even to a most patient type such as myself. Not only are they infesting the inside of the House; they are clearly infesting the ceilings, and the outside is now a sight to behold. I assume that there is no suggestion that they should not be sprayed because of some bizarre opposition by the Australian Democrats or some other quaint and curious party who have an objection to the use of insecticides or chemicals of any type in sprays. It really is something less than reasonable that such a grand building and such a stately chamber ought to be infested in the way that this one presently is.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to Senator Crichton-Browne, I would agree that the situation is becoming intolerable. There are some offices in which it is now impossible to work and spraying is taking place in those offices. One of those is my own. I have received advice from the CSIRO dated 2 November, which I will read:

INTERJECT.PARA: Following a visit yesterday by Mr Ted Edwards and myself, we wish to make the following observations. As discussed, the moths are migrating through Canberra from their breeding grounds in NSW and south Qld to the `summer-sleeping' . . . areas in the mountains in southern NSW and Victoria. They are trapped on the Parliament House building by the strong lights on the building. Since the lights on and inside the building are switched on all night and the moths do not fly during the day, they cannot leave the building.
We suggested that reduction of building lights is the solution; the best would be if all or almost all lights could be switched off during the last half of the night.
I believe that as from tomorrow afternoon all the lights will be progressively switched off for Friday, Saturday and Sunday. We hope that that cures the problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was distracted, Mr President. I was just wiping a moth off my sleeve. Whatever you can do about the moths, I am sure we will all appreciate it. My office is one that is becoming most difficult to work in but the chamber has become much worse in the last 24 hours and we will have to do something about it pretty soon. We really cannot go on like this.

SPEECH.PARA: I note the comments of Senator Coulter. Certainly energy conservation is a far better alternative than nuclear power or, indeed, any other form of energy, and I would hope that we can go along that path. However, it is not the only solution. We will need more than simply conserving energy. That may get us through some years; it certainly will not get us through 50 or 100 years. We will have to tackle the energy needs of the future, and I can only repeat what I said today; I hope nuclear energy is the last resort, but I find it difficult simply to rule it out as one of the options for a future generation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister confirm that the Federal Government has a policy of not employing retired Senior Executive Service (SES) public servants who have accepted termination payments in any capacity in the Public Service, for twelve months after they have left the SES.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under section 76R of the Public Service Act the Public Service Commissioner may give notice to a Senior Executive Service officer that if the officer retires from the Service within a specified period the officer will be entitled to a special benefit.

Officers who retire from the Service under section 76R are not disbarred from returning to the Service via the normal competitive recruitment process. It is, however, the Public Service Commissioner's expectation that a person who has retired under section 76R will not be re-engaged, either by appointment or continuing temporary employment, for a time equivalent to the specified benefit.

Under the Public Service Act, the Public Service Commissioner is responsible for all appointments to the SES. The Commissioner is therefore in a position to ensure that retired SES officers are not reappointed to the SES.

The possible engagement of retired SES officers as consultants is a matter for individual departmental management, subject to the general principles, detailed in the guidelines on engaging consultants, that departments ensure that they get the best possible value for money.
It is relevant to note that consultancies and part-time appointments do not entail the overheads and long-term add-on costs associated with employment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people were prosecuted in the courts by the Australian Taxation Office in 1987?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Taxation Office prosecuted 26,773 cases in the courts in 1987. Those cases involved individuals, companies, partnerships and trustees.

(2) The Australian Taxation Office carries out prosecutions for a wide range of offences, e.g. failure to lodge returns for income, sales or fringe benefits taxes, making false or misleading statements, failure to remit prescribed payments system or PAYE deductions.

The following table compares the number of cases prosecuted in each State with the number of taxpayers for that State. Because some ATO functions within a State are centralised at particular Branch Offices, it is not possible to make useful comparisons between Branch Offices of the percentage of cases prosecuted.
A number of factors bear on prosecution levels, including availability of hearing times in the various State courts and differences in procedures in some of those courts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Royal Australian Navy permit young recruits under the age of 18 years, and as young as 16 years, to drink alcohol in bars on Navy property and are they entitled, as a condition of enlistment, to 4 cans of beer, free of charge and subsequently unlimited amounts, provided they pay for the alcohol themselves.
(2) What provisions of the normal licensing laws apply to the recruits.
(3) Is this practice observed in all three Services.
(4) Does not such indulgence encourage alcoholism.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under Section 123a of the Defence Act 1901, a Chief of Staff has, notwithstanding any provision of the law of a State or Territory, the power to determine conditions for supply, sale, purchase or possession of intoxicating liquor within their respective arms of the Australian Defence Force.

Pursuant to this Section of the Act, Determination No. 1d made by the Chief of Naval Staff on 27 January 1987 forbids the sale or supply of intoxicating liquor to a person who has not attained the age of 18 years.
There is no condition of enlistment which entitles a recruit to 4 cans of beer, free of charge, and subsequently unlimited amounts, provided they pay for the alcohol themselves.
(2) The Navy adheres to the provisions of the licensing laws of individual States and Territories.
(3) The other two Services similarly prohibit under age drinking.

(4) Defence Instructions (Navy) direct Commanding Officers to discourage practices and customs which promote or glamorise the excessive use of alcohol, and to ensure that whenever alcohol is served at Service functions an alternative selection of beverage is available. Low alcohol beer is also encouraged in preference to other beer.
